story:
Short Summary

Your generous giving will help me be able to work with the local university's specimen collection and create more scientific based apocalyptic art as well as art based on the culture and life of Argentina, home of my grandmother. 

What We Need 

I will be working and selling my own possessions in order to pay for rent back at home while I am gone, but I need your help in order to make this dream a reality. Here is the financial breakdown:

$2000 will go to purchasing a plane ticket to Beunos Aires and a ticket coming back to the States.

$3000 will go to the Residency as part of their fees for their solo exhibition program for two months. 

$1000 will go towards living (such as groceries) and traveling fees for two months in Argentina based on the previous artists who have gone.

Any extra will go towards art supplies, the more I am able to raise, the more art I can make! 

Art Supplies with Additional Funding:

$20 - Paint Thinner and other supplies I will not be able to fly with

$270 - Portable French Easel to fit more paint/paintbrushes for traveling while painting

$120 - Portable Canvas/Panel Carrier so I may carry premade panels to Argentina and back

$190 - Watercolor Stretcher so I can stretch and keep watercolors flat without warping. Usually I rely on my school's studio to flatten my watercolors, but I won't have access to their equipment in Argentina.

$20 - Palette Carrier so I can safely travel with my pallette and not have to waste any  expensive oil paint before I leave.

$100 - Money to buy panels and watercolor paper while I am in Argentina 

$346 - Macro lens for a Pentax k-70 camera. This is so I can take high quality reference pictures of my muse (preserved animal specimens :D) and to also take high quality pictures of my work while I am down there. If I raise enough to also get this lens, contributors will be able to keep up with high quality progress pictures and of my life in Argentina! 

If I raise more than the essentials and am able to purchase art supplies/etc. for my trip, I will post them here so you can see what your money is creating.

The Impact

  • My art will officially have global impact with scientific specimens from another country included in my art. For those who value the importance of the existence of artists (especially in Oklahoma) this is a great way to fund your local/country's art community.
  • Art I make will be professionally photographed and able to purchase as prints.
  • I will be able to meet my extended family and learn more about my heritage in Argentina, while also working on becoming bilingual. I look forward to having this experience that I can share with my grandmother, who was the one who inspired me to start painting as a little kid. She grew up in Buenos Aires, which is just a short drive away from where I will be staying. 
  • The opportunity to have my own solo show as a recent college graduate is HUGE. I will be doing an artist talk and workshops there as well. Many galleries don't like artists unless they have shown at a substantial amount of places, but having my own solo show will greatly increase my success as an artist.  

Risks & Challenges

  • Rent while I am gone. Since I most likely won't be able to have someone sublease where I live, I will still have to pay rent while I am not living in America. (However if you are looking for a place, feel free to message me!) I will be working on raising my own money to pay off rent and fees owed to the school for a class I am taking right now. I hope that whatever I am not able to make from my job I will make from selling my possessions. I will also be posting items I am selling on my own social media accounts.
  • Learning Spanish. I have always been exposed to the language from growing up with half of my family being bilingual and taking classes in high school, but I am not bilingual myself. I have been learning Spanish from Duolingo and I also hope to learn a bit more before leaving by attending conversation programs offered by my school's Spanish department. Regardless of how much I learn beforehand, I aim to become fully immersed in the culture and the language and learning the language of my heritage. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially but still want to help, consider sharing this fundraiser to your social media accounts and to others you know! Contact me with a screenshot, and I'll enter you into a raffle to win a free signed print of your choosing! Deadline to enter is May 18, 2018. 

More About the Artist

Website: rkhadzeriga.myportfolio.com

Instagram: @Rkzeriga

Twitter: @Rkzeriga

Facebook Page: www.facebook.com/hadzerigaart

Feel free to give me a shout out! 

Who is the artist?

 Reese Kat Hadzeriga uses oil paint, watercolors, and other mixed media to introduce a narrative on the end of the world. These paintings depict animal specimens in imagined landscapes inspired by nature. Hadzeriga has previously won several awards including winning the Green County Watercolor Scholarship and winning the Dean’s Purchase Prize in the Where Art Meets Science competition. Hadzeriga has also exhibited their paintings previously at the Senior Capstone Exhibition at the Gardiner Gallery, the 13th Annual Members Exhibit at the Museum Broken Arrow, Summer Exhibition 2017 at the Student Union Underground, Student Juried Exhibition 2017 at the Gardiner Gallery and at the Seascapes Art Exhibition at the Light Space & Time Online Art Gallery. R.K. Hadzeriga graduated with a Bachelor’s in Studio Art and a minor in Entomology December 2017.

story:
Summary

My name is Megan, I am an artist, performer, educator and human rights activist living in Canberra, Australia. Over the last 17 years I have helped a lot of people in the Canberra Community in my various roles.  Over the last 7 years I have had health problems, and at the beginning of 2018 I was diagnosed with an auto immune illness.  This illness is not curable. It may improve on its own, or it may get worse, and I have to learn to live with it.  I also lost my job in 2017 and because of this, and my illness, I haven't been able to work again.  Currently, my illness effects me in ways that mean most jobs would not suit my needs. I also turned 50 this year, my age adding to my disadvantage in the job market. My partners support me, however money is very tight and I am not entitled to any government benefits.  I have been completing a Certificate III in Micro Business Management, and learning what I need to do to start my own business. My aim is to have on online retail business selling items I have made. I am holding this campaign to raise business start up funds.  Money raised will help me launch my business in a manner which will be more likely to provide a sustainable, meaningful income.

Where the funds will go

Money raised will help me to hit the ground running with my business, rather than slowly adding parts to my business over time.  As I will be without a steady income during the startup period, the start up funds will help cover the costs of set up (see below), allowing me to achieve a strong professional impression for people visiting my business, and freeing me up to create a large number of items to list all at once, open with an established product base, encouraging customers to return, as well as spending time marketing products and building up connections.

I hope to raise $3000 through this campaign.  The cost of various aspects of the business are as follows:

Domain name (3 years)                                           $     50

Business name registration                                   $   200

Accountant  fees (advice and tax)                       $   400

Business stationery (cards, packaging)            $    150

e-commerce set up (Wix- 12 months)                $    372                         

Initial listing of items e-commerce (Etsy)         $      30

Marketing                                                                      $  500

Insurance                                                                      $  500

(part of home, public liability, car)

photography                                                                $   500

Equipment upgrade (printer etc)                         $   250 

total= $2952

The items are listed in order of importance. If I am not able to reach my goal, I will use the funds received on the items according to the order of the list.  Any amount received will be useful and alleviate the pressure of having very little money of my own to contribute. The marketing budget might be considered high, however marketing will be key to getting the business moving. It will be used to attract new customers and create ongoing connections, important to business success.

Perks

There will be a number of perks of different values which can be claimed.  The perks will all be hand made by me.  They will all relate to the theme of peacock spiders (including the Sparklemuffin spider), and peacock feathers and spiders.  This is all in connection with my branding. These perks are all limited and most will not be available after my campaign.  The perks are available to people living within Australia (and postage costs are included in the value of the perks and have been carefully considered). If you do not live in Australia but are interested in claiming a perk, this could be arranged, please contact me to discuss postage costs. NOTE: Perk items have been made in an environment with pets (cats and dog), so please consider if you have allergies.  The colours of the items may vary as compared to what is seen in the images, however colour combinations will remain the same (for example in the peacock feathers).  The due date of when items can be expected is the maximum time frame. I will endeavour to make the items as soon as possible and get them sent out, however it may depend on costs of materials etc.  I may not be able to make some items until the campaign is over.

The impact

Any money donated will have an impact on my personal quality of life and ability to get my business started.  I currently have a small amount of money each fortnight, which I can invest in my business, however, in doing so it means that I have less to cover costs such as medical appointments and other things that most people consider to be a part of daily living.   My business will give me an income, which at the moment is nonexistent. I also need to change my lifestyle, hopes and dreams fairly dramatically.  My illness has meant I had to stop doing many things that were important to me and gave my life meaning. This business is the beginning of these changes.

In the past, I have done a lot of voluntary work and helped other people, and now I find myself in the position where I need that help. However, I am community minded and I hope to continue to give back to the communities that have helped and supported me into the future.  Flossie's Kitten Rescue is a local cat rescue that works to find homes for unwanted cats. I plan to work with Flossie's, in that I will be making 'Cat Pods'.  Flossie's will help let people know about my cat pods, with a percentage of any sales made through Flossie's, being donated back to Flossie's.

I have a strong track record of successful projects and endeavours in my working and volunteer lives. Some of the things I have done as a volunteer include:  Implementing two art exhibitions for women subjected to sexual violence, which involved every stage of the process from mentoring and helping the women to make the art, through to hanging and opening the exhibitions; Running a course for same sex attracted women coming out or questioning their sexuality for 7 years; and producing three different variety shows to raise money, awareness and build community for gender diversity, LGBTIAQ communities, and mental illness.  These accomplishments have demonstrated my ability to plan and execute large projects successfully from start to completion, including organised all aspects of the shows, from finding the performers and supporting them, through to the marketing of the shows and performing in them.

Risks and challenges

The greatest risks and challenges to the success of my business, at the moment, is my health. However, I am very determined to make this all work and I believe I can through pacing myself and understanding how much and when I can achieve what, in regards to the various aspects of running my business. I have particularly chosen to start a business selling items I have made, because I do have to spend a lot of time resting, and while I am resting I am making things.  So this choice of business, at the moment, seems the most viable to me. I am someone who has been used to doing everything myself. However I have learnt in the course of 2018, that I can and do need to delegate tasks or ask for help at times.  This is something I can also do if I need help with my business.

Other ways you can help

Other ways you can help me is by spreading the word about my campaign. Directing people to my facebook artist page https://www.facebook.com/MrGreenTeal/ which will be one of the entry points (eventually) to my web page, once it has been developed.  You can request to go onto a mailing list, so I can keep you in the loop about my business as it develops.  You may have skills or tangible items you wish to donate to me to help me out.  I am open to discussion.

story:
Ghost Ranch Adventure - Claire Boyce

 

  • I am a fine artist, photographer and writer based in Boulder CO
  • I have been selected as a recipient of a scholarship to attend a painting workshop in Ghost Ranch, New Mexico: https://www.ghostranch.org/retreat/outdoor-land...
  • The scholarship is for $200, and I need some extra funding to help with transportation, supplies and lodging
  • This will be a huge boon for me professionally and personally and will help advance my painting career and my spiritual connection with the Land of Enchantment
  • I have been recovering from a health issue for the past few years and I am still getting back on my feet financially
  • This trip will help my recovery and my art career

Funding Specifics

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Total cost of the workshop, with lodging: $995
  • $995-$200 scholarship = $795
  • Travel expenses, gas: $100
  • Food: $155
  • Art supplies: $150
  • Total: $1,200

The Impact

  • This will be a boon to my art career as well as an opportunity for personal healing and enrichment
  • By boosting my creative inspiration, I can, in turn inspire others and create more beauty in the world
  • I have successfully completed many art classes and workshops and have been able to share my skills as an art teacher and mentor to other artists

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't financially contribute, you can still help!

  • Share this project! 
  • Use the Indigogo share tools!

story:
On January 21, 2018, the Pasadena Museum of California Art (PMCA) opened its Spring 2018 round of exhibitions, including Testament of the Spirit: Paintings by Eduardo Carrillo.

As a part of this exhibition, the Pasadena Museum of California Art (PMCA) has unveiled the monumental and historic mural Chicano History for the first time in 28 years. The mural was created in 1970 by artists Eduardo Carrillo, Ramses Noriega, Sergio Hernandez and Dr. Saul Solache for the UCLA Chicano Studies Research Center, just before the start of the Chicano Moratorium. This is considered the first Chicano mural at a U.S. university, and a powerful statement of the times.

While the mural was scheduled to be displayed at a future exhibitions in Sacramento, it was not originally scheduled for display in its hometown of Los Angeles. Realizing the artistic and historic nature of the mural, the PMCA immediately committed to exhibiting the mural at its own expense, giving denizens of the Greater LA area the opportunity to view the mural, live on display, right here in Pasadena.

As part of fulfilling and funding that commitment, the PMCA has launched a fundraising campaign specifically dedicated to covering the expenses related to installing the mural in our gallery. We would be remiss were we not to offer YOU—our dedicated, art-loving public—the opportunity to help in the funding of this rediscovered masterpiece.

Be part of history by supporting the Pasadena Museum of California Art’s current exhibition of the mural Chicano History. Simply click on the link to our Indiegogo campaign portal to make your donation today. All donations are welcome!

Funds raised through this campaign help to cover costs of transportation, installation, and insurance of the mural for the duration of our exhibition Testament of the Spirit: Paintings of Eduardo Carrillo, which opened to the public on January 21, 2018 and will close on June 3, 2018.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, you can help spread the word by sharing our Chicano History Mural Exhibition campaign with your friends and family through social media.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, you can help spread the word by sharing our Chicano History Mural Exhibition campaign with your friends and family through social media.

Thank You

Your generosity will play a key role in helping the PMCA continue its mission to bring talents and creations of California artists to the world. Thank you.

Susana Smith Bautista, Ph.D.

Executive Director

Pasadena Museum of California Art

All donations are welcome!Funds raised through this campaign help to cover costs of transportation, installation, and insurance of the mural for the duration of our exhibition Testament of the Spirit: Paintings of Eduardo Carrillo, which opened to the public on January 21, 2018 and will close on June 3, 2018.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to contribute, you can help spread the word by sharing our Chicano History Mural Exhibition campaign with your friends and family through social media.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to contribute, you can help spread the word by sharing our Chicano History Mural Exhibition campaign with your friends and family through social media.Thank YouYour generosity will play a key role in helping the PMCA continue its mission to bring talents and creations of California artists to the world. Thank you.Susana Smith Bautista, Ph.D.Executive DirectorPasadena Museum of California Art

story:
The Museum of Tarots is pleased to give an opportunity to all artists who have been working on this subject matter and will bring to light what is often at risk of remaining hidden and of being forgotten. Whatever lied concealed has been existing and living with a persistent zeal. The Museum of Tarots assumes responsibility in giving visibility to the symbol which lodged inside the Arcana, so that everybody can admire their splendour in the sphere of the new millennium. 

For this is with great pleasure the Tarot Museum, proudly presents these original tarot decks, inspired by distinguished works of two unforgettable plays by William Shakespeare: Hamlet and Macbeth. Little Emi, often inspiring the works of Coletti (the artist), guides us through this enchanted world. These two decks of tarot are presented together inside a wooden box as a limited edition set of only 200 copies, hand signed by the artist. A very special offering for lovers of Tarot and Shakespeare!

Among the various offerings, including this limited edition Tarot set, will be the original hand drawings created by the artist... a truly unique opportunity for serious collectors.

To make a high quality work almost all the contribution will be spent for the realization of the two tarot decks and for the wooden box that contains them. While about 20% will be devolved to the artist Franco Coletti for the realization of these art works.

Cost of production:

Printing: 200+200 high quality Tarot decks = €. 2000 Euro

Drawings by the artist = €. 1500 Euro

200 + 200 Boxes = €. 1600 Euro

40 wooden boxes = €. 400

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will still produce a portion of this unusual project.

HAMLET TAROT (22 MAJOR ARCANA)

Please, share this great opportunity!

story:
Hello. My name is Fawne DeRosia.

I am an artist living & working in Thomaston, Georgia.

Full transcript of the video:
I started this campaign to help with the purchase of my studio building. I’m currently renting & have been for the past 8 years or so. I think that taking the next step & investing in the community & in this property is my best decision.

But first here’s a little bit about me:
I like to try all kinds of art. I’ve painted a school bus, a large mural in the local fine arts center, another mural in the middle school. I’ve painted a flag on the side of a building. Last year I painted murals in Knoxville & Memphis, Tennessee. I’m currently learning how to make awesome ceramic things. & here’s a fun fact: I have the first Etsy shop ever.

Every year I gather a bunch of friends & we make & carry lanterns in the Christmas Light Parade. Last year I led the parade in a reindeer onesie. Check it out!

I am also a chalk artist. I’ve created chalk art in several states. Here’s me in Arkansas. Florida. Alabama. & Minnesota.

Y’all, I really like making art. I mean, really like it.

Now let’s talk about the studio:
I started a storefront art studio back in 2012. A year later I moved that studio to a bigger space. Then I moved the studio again to the other side of the square. I changed the name to Flint Rose Studio, and celebrated finally having air conditioning by hosting my first Kids Art Camps & a variety of classes and art shows.

Then I had to move the studio AGAIN. Every move presented its own set of challenges that we overcame somewhat gracefully. Sure, there were tears & a lot of frustration & thoughts of 'maybe I can’t do this anymore’, but you know what? We are still here. We are still kicking & I hope to do so for many more years.

I’ve hosted classes to people of all ages. I often say that I really don't teach art, I just grant permission for your creativity. I feel that everyone has the ability to become an artist.

My studio is 1600 square feet. Enough space for classes, a work area for myself, a gallery space, and lots of storage for art supplies. The space next door is 700 square feet. Ideally, I’d like to move all of the classroom activities next door so I won’t have to worry about accidents around my personal work.

Let’s talk about Perks! You can give at any level that is good for you. Every bit of money will go towards the sale price of the building. Rewards include t shirts, & mugs, & stickers, & postcards. A lot of cool things! Wow!

Please share this crowdfunding campaign with all of your friends and family and anyone that would like to help out a small town artist. Thank you! I appreciate you & I will see you later. Bye!

End of video transcript.

What We Need & What You Get

Let's break it down:

  • I set the goal at $25 000 to help me with a down payment on the property.
  • About $2500 will be set aside to help with creating & shipping perks. Any unused portion of that will go towards the down payment. 
  • If the entire goal isn't met, then I'll work harder to either reach it through art sales or classes. But I feel that any amount would help. 

The Impact

Flint Rose Studio has become a beacon of creativity in the community. Kids love coming in and painting whatever their hearts desire. Did you know that most elementary kids in Upson County don't have art classes in school? Flint Rose Studio hopes to fill that artistic need.

  • Future plans include bringing in artists to teach workshops, creating community projects, & coming up with outreach programs for all members of the community.
  • The new space next door can be used as rental space for birthdays and a variety of other parties. We can even start Open Mic night again!

Risks & Challenges

Purchasing of a property will happen. I feel I have been renting a space for way too long & need to commit to a permanent space in Thomaston. While I haven't made an official offer on the space yet, I'm close to doing so. If plans for purchasing the studio (or another property) falls through, all money raised through this campaign will be refunded.

  • Worst case scenario, if I lose the space altogether, I do have a back up property in mind.
  • If you're unhappy with anything, let me know & I can make refunds asap. However, if your reward has already shipped then our transactions are final. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Become a patron of Fawne on Patreon 
  • Shop on Etsy (watercolor paintings & stickers)
  • Shop the Shopify store (paintings & ceramics)
  • Stop by the studio to shop (open by chance or by appointment).
  • Like Flint Rose Studio on Facebook
  • Follow along on Instagram
  • Share this campaign on all of your social media accounts

story:
Mission Statement:

Wildfire Ceramic Studio (WCS) is a new and exciting ceramic studio and gallery in the heart of Missoula Montana! WCS provides studio space, professional experience, and gallery representation for emerging artists. 

WCS believes that emerging artists benefit from having a dedicated space and community to expand their practice.  With this belief, WCS strives to create an environment of creative enrichment, while contributing to the greater art community in Missoula.

A Little More on WCS:

Montana is a very special place for ceramic artists and provides incredible and invaluable artistic and networking opportunities for Ceramic Artists at all stages of their careers. However, there was a need for a place that specifically focused on helping and supporting new and emerging artists. 

WCS was co-founded by Ryan Caldwell, Sarah Conti, Stephanie Dishno, Krissy Ramirez, and Bruce Kitts in May of 2020. One month later the WCS crew found a brick and mortar and began the long process of turning it into a fully functioning ceramic studio!  

While starting any business endeavor has its challenges, starting a business during the pandemic proved to add a lot of unexpected setbacks along the way. 

To help ensure the health and safety of the resident artists at WCS and the greater community of Missoula, WCS upheld strict safety protocols and decided to hold off on engaging with the public until it was safe to do so. This meant making the difficult decision to cancel potential business opportunities and paying for all start-up expenses out of pocket. 

Now that all residents are vaccinated, events can be held outside with windows and doors open. WCS is excited to start opening to the public! 

Supporting WCS is not only supporting a small business or incredible art community in Missoula but it is also supporting individual artists during critical and challenging times in their career! 

 

Where will the money go?

UPDATE: Wildfire Ceramic Studio hosted a fundraising night at Highlander Brewing Co. and raised $2500.00 to fully fund our BIPOC Women in the Ceramic Arts Fellowship! This is such exciting news and we are more than grateful to be able to provide this opportunity! 

Minimum Goal $13,500.00

Money earned from this campaign will help cover initial start-up costs, studio enhancements, and support for artists at WCS! 

First off, WCS is committed to stepping up and supporting underrepresented artists who need it most! To do this, WCS is creating the BIPOC Women in the Ceramic Arts Fellowship. This fellowship will fully fund one BIPOC identifying Woman a year, for a one-three month residency at Wildfire Ceramic Studio. This would assist in covering studio rent, materials, firings, and cost of living.

So here is the breakdown:

BIPOC Women in the Ceramic Arts Fellowship: $2,500.00

Gallery lighting and furniture: $800.00

Kilns: $4,600.00

Wiring, vents, etc: $1,000.00

Kiln furniture: $800.00

Glaze cart and start-up materials: $ 600.00

Sinks:  $200.00

Studio setup: $2,200.00

Slab roller: $800.00

What if we do not reach our goal of $13,500.00?

Any amount raised will help! WCS is passionate about the BIPOC Women in the Ceramic Arts Fellowship and 30% of funds will be allocated to the fellowship. The rest of the funding will be used to enhance and improve the studio and gallery to make the best working environment possible for the artists at Wildfire Ceramic Studio! 

What if we exceed $13,500.00?!

The yearly cost for an artist to have a space at WCS is $3,000.00. This does not cover materials, firing fees, or outside living costs that require many emerging artists to have part or full-time employment. This takes precious time away from their studio practice. WCS would love to raise an additional $7,500.00 to help financially support the artists at WCS. This would bring the monthly studio cost for each artist down to $125.00 a month allowing more time in the studio for each artist! 

WCS also plans on selling ceramic tools, underglazes, and clay to the public within the next year. Any extra funding will help to expedite this exciting endeavor! 

What if you cannot donate?

Help us spread the word! Share this campaign with any and everyone! Not only can this help us meet our funding goal but it will also spread the word about our incredible studio and gallery to help us grow in other ways! So please do not be shy, use those Indiegogo share tools!

Perks

Along with the different merch available for this campaign we have an assortment of donated artwork that will be raffled off at the end of this campaign! Purchasing raffle tickets will go into a general raffle draw for the pieces.

When you purchase raffle tickets they will not go in for a specific piece.

story:
Short Summary

For the past fourteen months creative outputs have been inextricably bound to our collective state of confinement. Artists have been forced to reconfigure their practices without ease of access to studios and gallery spaces. What was once been a myriad pool of opportunity and inspiration has been closed off. Lockdown shrunk our perspectives down to fit the parameters of our homes, but the escapist powers of imagination and creativity allowed for those boundaries to be widened.

Across the River will showcase six young artists who continued to make art in drastically altered circumstances from those which they were familiar. It will show how these selected artists responded to a situation defined by isolation, one we all experienced in both similar and fundamentally different ways. The pieces will present vibrant, other-worldly paintings which have been born from this period of collective myopia, from the shrinking of perspective.

The exhibition will be hosted in a new exhibition space in West London which doubles as the garden flat home of its owners. By transforming from a domestic living space to an exhibition gallery, what was once a place of isolation and refuge transposes into a place of communication, connection and bustle.

What We Need & What You Get

An exhibition with 7 artists is quite an organisational fest. We need £2,000 for the following:

- Framing the work

- Transportation of the work

- Installation of the work

- Promotional assets

- Signposting and way-finding

- Health and safety equipment

- Covid safety equipment

- Staff

- Marketing

- Insurance

In return, our beloved fundraisers will get to attend an awesome show on a hot summer's evening in the company of beautiful people against the backdrop of some pretty spectacular art. There'll be drinks and music to accompany the visual journey across the magic garden we have been preparing all summer. People who donate £100 or more will receive a print by photographer Daniel Delikatnyi.

The Impact

The struggle for emerging artists to get exposure for their work has been dramatically increased by covid. Galleries closed, graduate shows cancelled and budgets cut. I myself, a recent graduate can sympathise with being deprived of the opportunity to put my work in front of the right people and more importantly just people. My graduation show was insensitively called off.

Through our collective contacts we are hoping to have over a hundred visitors: art buyers, agents, journalists and like-minded people. This will help our up and coming artists to connect with a wide network of creatives, which will lead to jobs, commissions and further opportunities. 

No less important than all of the above, this is an opportunity for artists to sell their work so they can continue funding and developing their practice. 

Young artists are looking for a leg up and this exhibition hopes to give them that opportunity. We are all young, down to earth creatives who want to bring the community together in the name of art once again. We would appreciate any help from you to put on this inspiring show in the heart of our neighbourhood, in the garden next door.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if funds are thin atm, young artists can sympathise with this predicament more than anyone. The only other way you can help is to share this campaign and the exhibition far and wide and then come and support our talented team on the day. We can't wait to see you all :)

story:
CONTEMPORARY ARABIC SCRIPT ANIMATIONS

Throughout my extensive experience as a motion designer and my background in broadcast design in the Middle East region for the last 17 years, I have come to realize that many challenges are faced trying to animate Arabic script because of its cursive nature and its letters that change form depending on their position within a word. Most of the existing animation tools are designed to be used exclusively with Latin scripts. Utilizing them with Arabic script results in broken Arabic letter-forms and hence aesthetically poor and grammatically incorrect animations.

 

ARABTATION

Arabtation is a proposed plugin dedicated to animators (freelancers as well as employed) in the fields of broadcast, advertising and film and that allows the creation of more sophisticated, creative and elaborate Arabic script animations while respecting the grammatical rules of the Arabic letter-forms. All the Arabic letter-forms within the plugin are built using the spiral unit system devised based on the motion study of the whirling dervish dance. This gave the letter-forms the flexibility needed to animate, to morph into their different instances within a word and to connect to each other to form words. The initial form of the spiral unit can be easily changed and manipulated according to a series of parameters controlled by sliders. The modifications applied will affect the design of the letter-forms. The plugin is highly customizable and allows the creation of a wide range of animations by playing around with the spiral units, the letters and the words.

 

This plugin offers a first of a kind solution that boosts the quality of the Arabic script animations, granting them a modern and contemporary edge. Its user-friendly interface, based on easily manipulated sliders, makes it highly customizable and allows the creation of a wide range of animations. 

 

 

FUNDING AND ROADMAP

Funding needed: CHF 30,000.-

I have reached a phase now where I need to create the plugin with the help and technical capabilities of a developer over the course of the coming 3 months. The amount needed will help me pay the developer for his/her services and permit me to advance in my project and set an important milestone on the roadmap of my startup.

Raising this amount will also give me a psychological boost to carry on working on the plugin with many future steps ahead:
- create several versions of the plugin linked to other dance disciplines and body movement
- link the plugin to performances/projections where the Arabic typography will be controlled by live dance or music
- organize workshops to raise awareness about the plugin and about the Arabic script animation in general 

 

PERKS

Funders will receive one of the following:
- smartphone lock screen with the first Arabic letter of their name
- Arabic script animation of their name or a word of their choice
- 10% off when/if they decide to buy the plugin

This gave the letter-forms the flexibility needed to animate, to morph into their different instances within a word and to connect to each other to form words. The initial form of the spiral unit can be easily changed and manipulated according to a series of parameters controlled by sliders. The modifications applied will affect the design of the letter-forms. The plugin is highly customizable and allows the creation of a wide range of animations by playing around with the spiral units, the letters and the words.

 
This plugin offers a first of a kind solution that boosts the quality of the Arabic script animations, granting them a modern and contemporary edge. Its user-friendly interface, based on easily manipulated sliders, makes it highly customizable and allows the creation of a wide range of animations. 
 

 
FUNDING AND ROADMAP
Funding needed: CHF 30,000.-
I have reached a phase now where I need to create the plugin with the help and technical capabilities of a developer over the course of the coming 3 months. The amount needed will help me pay the developer for his/her services and permit me to advance in my project and set an important milestone on the roadmap of my startup.
Raising this amount will also give me a psychological boost to carry on working on the plugin with many future steps ahead:- create several versions of the plugin linked to other dance disciplines and body movement- link the plugin to performances/projections where the Arabic typography will be controlled by live dance or music- organize workshops to raise awareness about the plugin and about the Arabic script animation in general 

 
PERKS
Funders will receive one of the following:- smartphone lock screen with the first Arabic letter of their name- Arabic script animation of their name or a word of their choice- 10% off when/if they decide to buy the plugin

story:
GEORGE® ARMATURE INTERVIEW

Like all GEORGE®ARMATURES products, our new armatures are packed full of features and meticulously engineered. These are designed from the ground up to be both the best animation armatures and the best figure for the animators, students and artists in the world.

In questi ultimi anni l’animazione stop-motion si è imposta come scelta tecnica per raccontare storie per il cinema e oggi si vedono in sala sempre più film realizzati fotogramma dopo fotogramma. Nella scorsa edizione degli oscar c’erano tra le candidature ben due film realizzati in stop-motion, La mia vita da zucchina e Kubo e la spada magica e nelle prossime settimane usciranno I Primitivi, del colosso storico Aardman Studios e il nuovo gioiellino d’autore, fuori da qualsiasi schema, di Wes Anderson.  

-In recent years, stop-motion animation has become a technical choice to tell stories for the cinema and today we see more and more films made in the room frame by frame. In the last edition of the Oscar there were among the nominations two films made in stop-motion, My life from zucchini and Kubo and the magic sword and in the coming weeks the Primitives will be released by the historical giant Aardman Studios And the new designer gem, out of any scheme, by Wes Anderson.

 E in italia? In Italia ancora non si sono visti film di lungometraggio realizzati in stop-motion, ma possiamo affermare che vari progetti sono in cantiere e ci auguriamo che possano a breve trovare la giusta strada produttiva. Si fa intanto molto lavoro di ricerca, si realizzano cortometraggi, l’animazione a passo uno è insegnata nelle scuole, come ad esempio allo IED Roma (https://www.ied.it/roma/scuola-arti-visive/cors... ) e bisogna assolutamente segnalare una novità tecnica tutta italiana: la produzione di un’armatura per burattini interamente sviluppata e realizzata nel nostro paese. L’elemento più importante per il burattino da stop-motion è proprio lo scheletro, detto anche armatura. Un burattino con uno scheletro non ben realizzato risulterà di difficile gestione durante l’animazione, se non addirittura impossibile. Sapere che anche in Italia qualcuno ha deciso di dedicarsi alla fabbricazione di armature per stop-motion è sintomo certo dell’inizio di una bella avventura. Il nome di questo piccolo gioiello tecnico è GEORGE® ed è stata sviluppata e prodotta da stopmotionengineeringstore.com  

-And in Italy? In Italy there are still no feature films made in stop-motion, but we can say that various projects are in the pipeline and we hope that they will soon find the right production path. In the meantime, a lot of research work is being done, short films are produced, the animation at step one is taught in schools, such as at IED Rome (https://www.ied.it/roma/scuola-arti-visive/corsi- specialization / animation-stop-motion / CRAVBNI001_01) and it is absolutely necessary to point out an all-Italian technical innovation: the production of a puppet armature entirely developed and realized in our country. The most important element for the stop-motion puppet is the skeleton, also called the armor. A puppet with a skeleton is not well realized will be difficult to manage during the animation, if not impossible. Knowing that even in Italy someone decided to devote himself to the manufacture of armor for stop-motion is a sure sign of the beginning of a good adventure. The name of this little technical jewel is GEORGE® and has been developed and produced by stopmotionengineeringstore.com-

Uno scheletro per burattino da stop-motion deve essere robusto, ma al tempo stesso estremamente leggero, stabile e di facile mobilità. Deve muoversi agilmente, mantenendo la posizione senza subire modificazioni dovute ad assestamenti o cedimenti e non deve perdere questa caratteristica dopo pochi movimenti a causa dell’allentarsi di viti o snodi. Il giusto movimento dello scheletro permette al burattino di non assumere posizioni che potrebbero apparire innaturali e fa sì che non si creino rotture o deformazioni nei materiali di rivestimento. In tutto questo GEORGE® risponde perfettamente alle aspettative.  

-A stop-motion puppet skeleton must be robust, but at the same time extremely light, stable and easy to move. It must move easily, maintaining the position without undergoing changes due to settlements or subsidence and must not lose this feature after a few movements due to the loosening of screws or joints. The right movement of the skeleton allows the puppet not to assume positions that may appear unnatural and causes no cracks or deformations in the coating materials to be created. In all this GEORGE® perfectly meets expectations.-  

L’armatura GEORGE® durante i test al corso di specializzazione in stop-motion dello IED Roma  

-The GEORGE® armature during the tests at the stop-motion specialization course of the IED Rome-

Grande attenzione è stata posta anche sull’utilizzo di soluzioni innovative per l’uso più largo dell’armatura. Di particolare nota è il sistema di fissaggio rapido utilizzato per gli arti e il collo, che permette di creare diverse mani, piedi e teste, pur mantenendo lo stesso corpo. L’arto viene rimosso con estrema facilità e sostituito con un altro. L’attacco rapido è realizzato mediante lavorazione CNC in acciaio inox. Il torso superiore è realizzato completamente in carbonio  in tre diverse versioni: una base, una sezione rinforzata migliorata per giunti di spalla e un altro con un collo dinamica speciale.  

-Great attention has also been paid to the use of innovative solutions for the wider use of the reinforcement. Of particular note is the fastening system used for the limbs and the neck, which allows you to create different hands, feet and heads, while maintaining the same body. The limb is easily removed and replaced with another. The quick coupling is made by CNC machining in stainless steel. The upper torso is made entirely of carbon and was created in three different versions: a base, an improved reinforced section for shoulder joints and another with a special dynamic neck.-

 

 
 

 

Lisa Barnstone, a puppet animator based in New York City is creating the character "Pocket Watch Jr." for her series, "TRINKET". Pocket Watch Jr. is inspired by and created with GEORGE®.

"Dopo aver provato l armatura sono rimasto davvero soddisfatto! Ottenere un risultato del genere implica centinaia di test e sperimentazioni. Un' ottima armatura made in italy".  

"After trying the armature I was really satisfied! Getting such a result involves hundreds of tests and experiments. An excellent armature made in Italy."

 

 

 

GEORGE® is available now on Indiegogo on Demand, in the SL-SERIES size 10" (25cm) . The SL-SERIES is completely made by carbon fiber, stainless steel with quick attachments in aluminum. The joints have spheres with a larger diameter and the hands are made by aluminum. A particular challenge was the solution to the carbon bonding and stainless steel parts. After long and severals tests of glues with different polymerization processes, we decided to choose an aeronautical glue and defined a specific polymeriation process. This property allows you to secure technology, high strength and durable connections that are ideal for the most demanding professional use. We believe that the strategic adoption of a structure made entirely by composite material is the maximum expression of technology industries in the field of stop motion ield . The considerable advantages of this material (lightness and mechanical strength) were the basis for the creation of a single, high-quality and reliable armature. Last but not least, there is the aspect. The natural carbon finish conveys a high technology and superior image that emphasizes research and the quality of the project / product. 

GEORGE® is extremely strong, has maximum fluidity of movement, and maintains mobility over time and during filming, with great versatility and modularity of parts. The joints are made from carbon fiber. . The upper torso is made completely from carbon fibre. Special technology is the base of project but great focus has also been placed on the use of innovative solutions for the widest use of the armature. Of particular note is the rapid attachment system used for the limbs and neck, allowing you to create different hands, feet and heads whilst maintaining the same body. It is very easy to remove the limb and replace it with another one. The armature can be used in the most varied of contexts such as stop motion animation - the most advanced technological puppet field and for didactic purposes in schools and universities.

 

10" SPECIAL PACK RIG

 

 

 

Choose your country in the pre-order process, to find out the shipping fees.

 

 

The first studies to create a highly innovative professional product were undertaken in early 2015. The decision was immediately taken to use a material that had never been adopted in the animation sector: CARBON FIBRE.   The products and armatures (the supporting skeleton of the puppets used for the creation of videos) currently on the market are all in metal, carbon or stainless steel.  These are quite light but rather unreliable and may deform when subject to stress. In contrast, carbon fibre is extremely light, yet rigid and will not deform.  The project was developed in various phases. First, a long period of meticulous solid modelling generated the first version of the armature. It featured: - limb stems made 100% from carbon rod - joint plates from carbon sheet cut and worked with CNC machining centre - hip block and other large parts from thick carbon sheet cut and worked with CNC machining centre - spherical joints in perforated and rectified stainless steel. The carbon sheets are cut and worked by tool machinery, controlled by CNC to guarantee the highest level of precision and cutting quality. The carbon rods are rounded and 3mm in diameter.

As a result, GEORGE® has become a versatile, precisely calibrated professional tool for artists and animators to create their own images.

story:
IN STOCK NOW.

The book is already printed and published, in stock and ready to ship.

“DRAWINGS” is a limited edition of only 250 copies “Made in the USA” project. 

Do not hesitate to contact me if you need further information.

 

I am Chris Lopez (Cristobal Sanchez-Lopez), a classically trained, multimedia artist from Barcelona, Spain. I have been living in South Florida for the past 25 years and run my art, clothing, and design company Chris Lopez Studio from my Fort Lauderdale based home studio.

I am also a teacher, a husband, and daydreamer. And, believe art is food for the soul.

My art spans 40 years of creating paintings, drawings, photography and illustrations. In that time I have created and amassed an indelible collection of original drawings. My pencil and charcoal drawings have appeared in top galleries across the US and have graced the covers of magazine and print articles. I also have had the honor of having my drawings included in international art books and publications celebrating the male form.

Most artist are humble slaves to their craft, we do it because it feeds us. It’s how we survive. It has taken me a very long time to embrace who I am as an artist. And, there has been no better time in my vast career to celebrate my body of work than now. "DRAWINGS" is the first in a series of coffee table art books that will act as a retrospective of my work, showcasing a variety of “artistic languages” and mixed medias I have explored.

"DRAWINGS" is a limited edition of 250 copies, 10x10 hard cover coffee table book with 104 pages of high quality uncensored nude reproductions of bears, daddies, and alpha males created with charcoal, graphite and mixed media on surfaces such as: wood, black paper, gesso textured panels and marble. This collection of drawing spans from 2008 to 2020, which I believe has been my most prolific period as a matured artist.

My desire with "DRAWINGS" is to share my retrospective with art enthusiast and lovers of the natural, male form. This is a dream project come true. Your support makes it a reality.

Come celebrate male beauty with me.

-Chris Lopez

IMPORTANT:

This book contains uncensured artistic nudity and it's intended for adults from 18 years and older.

story:
THIS CALENDAR IS FUNDED, PRINTED AND NOW ON INDIEGOGO FOR THE FIRST TIME!!!

Did you miss the "Big Guns" Kickstarter campaign? No worries, back it now and you will receive your perks right away and exclusive add-ons not available anywhere else!

BIG GUNS is a 12 month collector's edition wall calendar entirely dedicated to Lorenzo's paintings of sexy outlaws and provocative sharpshooters. A long journey from western to sci-fi, passing through steampunk and fantasy.

 A beautifully printed 12" x 12" glossy calendar that opens out every month to an impressive 24" x 12" artwork. Two glamorous pinup each month for extra fire power, uncensored, the way he originally created them!  

Plus a calendar template with squares big enough to write notes if you want to!

These are not simply pin-ups. These are killer pin-ups.

story:
Makers are taking over Union Station. 

Strange Folk Festival is switching up it's venue to a beautiful and unique, yet sparsely occupied, mall in downtown St. Louis, MO over the weekend of September 26th -27th, 2015. We have chosen 200 indie entrepreneurs who will occupy nearly every empty retail store on the 1st and 2nd levels. 

Bands will be playing out to the audience both inside and out from the old Hooters on the 3rd floor. We promise that it will be kid friendly, but might ask all the bands wear bright orange bloomers, just for giggles. 

Visitors can treat themselves to 25 food trucks/concessions, adult beverages + a singing fudge shop and Subway. We're all in this mall together, after all.  

You'll experience unique atmospheric installations and exhibits. The Hunt for Craft October is our craft supply scavenger hunt and Fort Featherbottom, our handmade children's playground, will be re-imagined. Many unique and simple hands-on activities will be free to make too!

We promise that admission to Strange Folk Festival will always be FREE.

We can't promise that there will be another Strange Folk Festival after this.


Festival founder, Autumn Wiggins, summarizes and reflects:

"After years of grappling with Strange Folk's former venue and payment processor over allocated funds, I ended the festival indefinitely in O'Fallon, IL at a meeting with the parks department mid-January 2015. Soon after, the city engaged in some odd behavior. They sent legal notices demanding Facebook and website passwords, asked the police to confiscate my laptop, and crudely edited a 2014 web graphic of the festival illustration to say '2015.' They emailed that image to a list of vendors that they had processed payments for over the years. It told them to 'Save the Date,' with no mention that I wasn't involved. 

My vendors caught on right away. #NoFakeFolk begat Glittergate and the widely publicized battle for Strange Folk's intellectual property that I clearly won without ever stepping foot in a courtroom. 

During this time, vendors and fans encouraged me not to give up, and to move the festival somewhere new. I decided to see if any place really inspired me, and I remember my trips to Union Station as a child fondly. 

That is was even a possibility...to create a mall full of makers! I dove in, and made sure Strange Folk's guaranteed revenue sources would more than cover it's total annual expenses. Expenses that have never included the mass-customization machines and tools I have been dreaming of using to produce installation pieces, upcycled graphic elements, hands-on project components and much more. Nor have those expenses ever included anything but a scant salary for myself for a decade. That just can't continue. 

I'm not going to gouge vendors or impose lines and ticket scanners on our guests that have been able to come and go as they please all these years.

My store, The Upcycle Exchange, has operated as pay-as-you-wish retail for 5 years. This concept can be a bellwether for what a community values, and I have experienced a remarkable amount of common ground and generosity through it. 
By initially ending Strange Folk, I had hoped to focus on Upcycle. Under updated circumstances, I decided on the opposite approach. 
I've scaled back my shop momentarily and moved to a private headquarters so I can work non-stop on Strange Folk 2015. 

If this campaign is successful, Strange Folk will not end at Union Station. I'd love to take it back to a park after this and to keep producing it in the authentic manner that I always have. I refuse to compromise the integrity of what I've created. 
No matter what, I will continue to pursue exciting creative projects that benefit the St. Louis region and the maker community at large, and am endlessly grateful to contributors and supporters of the spirit of Strange Folk. You enable pioneering retail platforms and modes of fabrication. This isn't just a craft show. "


It's simple. If you like Strange Folk Festival, then you can buy a ticket to support it, even though you don't need one to attend. 

That said, we are ever-enterprising, and have thought up some enticing perks! For $10, you'll get a one-time use coupon for 10% off a single purchase from any mall vendor. Spend $100 with that vendor, and your ticket is paid for. Plus, the ticket includes locally harvested organic seeds to plant in your garden by Quixlan Seed Co.

Festival merch in the works will feature 2015's whimsical gnome drawing by Jeffrey Johnson of Red Herring Illustration. Get a tote bag at $25, and a tote +T-shirt at $50. 
At the $100 level, you'll additionally receive a copy of the children's book that Jeffrey and Autumn are self-publishing. It teaches both kids and adults the basics of intellectual property law. This perk level includes real estate on our interactive "Wall of Strange Folks to Follow." That includes one photo with one social media profile that you would like attendees to follow. You can put that selfie stick to work, or maybe you'd rather show off the crackers you ate for lunch. Who are we to judge?

If you are interested in a business sponsorship, get in touch with a comment here or with Magan at magan.strangefolk@gmail.com. We have a wide range of options that include low-price base sponsorship and bartering possibilities. We'd love to find out more about your company and determine if it is a good fit for Strange Folk. 

The Impact

By purchasing a "ticket" you'll be helping to support one of the Midwest's largest and most loved indie craft shows. 

  • Strange Folk Festival has been produced independently for 10 years with little to no financial sponsorship. It has grown in attendance from 1,200 to 40,000 people in that time. Your contribution will cheer us on to continue. You are supporting a diverse network of independent makers who have worked hard to build a vibrant and authentic culture that propels small businesses in the St. Louis region. 
  • Strange Folk Festival continues to be an important outlet for local small businesses to get out in front of a huge crowd. By chipping in, you'll even help the vendors you don't buy anything from to continue to make a living at making what they love. 
  • We are investing in equipment to MAKE Strange Folk's exhibits and decor even more amazing and sustainable.  A robust crowd-fund campaign would help pay for the mass-customization devices, tools, storage and supplies that will launch Fort Featherbottom and other installations in to the stratosphere of coolness!

Risks & Challenges

The risk is that Strange Folk Festival will no longer be produced after 2015. The challenge is to see if the hive mind is willing to chip-in without any requirement to.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about tickets! Anyone can buy a ticket to Strange Folk Festival, even if they will only be there in spirit!
  • Visit and share our website anywhere: www.StrangeFolkFestival.com
  • Invite your FB friends to join our event page...5.2k have RSVPed as of the launch of this campaign! You can like and share our Facebook Page too (7k fans and counting)
  • Take pictures of gnomes in the wild, and tag @StrangeFolkFestival on Instagram. 
  • Tag #StrangeFolkFestival everywhere
  • Tweet @AutumnElayne, Strange Girl in Charge
  • Come to the festival and support the artists, makers, designers, and curators that work hard to give you creative alternatives to mass-produced retail merchandise.
story_txt:
Makers are taking over Union Station.  

Strange Folk Festival is switching up it's venue to a beautiful and unique, yet sparsely occupied, mall in downtown St. Louis, MO over the weekend of September 26th -27th, 2015. We have chosen 200 indie entrepreneurs who will occupy nearly every empty retail store on the 1st and 2nd levels. 



Bands will be playing out to the audience both inside and out from the old Hooters on the 3rd floor. We promise that it will be kid friendly, but might ask all the bands wear bright orange bloomers, just for giggles. 


Visitors can treat themselves to 25 food trucks/concessions, adult beverages + a singing fudge shop and Subway. We're all in this mall together, after all.  You'll experience unique atmospheric installations and exhibits. The Hunt for Craft October is our craft supply scavenger hunt and Fort Featherbottom, our handmade children's playground, will be re-imagined. Many unique and simple hands-on activities will be free to make too!


We promise that admission to Strange Folk Festival will always be FREE.



We can't promise that there will be another Strange Folk Festival after this.



Festival founder, Autumn Wiggins, summarizes and reflects:
"After years of grappling with Strange Folk's former venue and payment processor over allocated funds, I ended the festival indefinitely in O'Fallon, IL at a meeting with the parks department mid-January 2015. Soon after, the city engaged in some odd behavior. They sent legal notices demanding Facebook and website passwords, asked the police to confiscate my laptop, and crudely edited a 2014 web graphic of the festival illustration to say '2015.' They emailed that image to a list of vendors that they had processed payments for over the years. It told them to 'Save the Date,' with no mention that I wasn't involved. 
My vendors caught on right away. #NoFakeFolk begat Glittergate and the widely publicized battle for Strange Folk's intellectual property that I clearly won without ever stepping foot in a courtroom. 
During this time, vendors and fans encouraged me not to give up, and to move the festival somewhere new. I decided to see if any place really inspired me, and I remember my trips to Union Station as a child fondly. 

That is was even a possibility...to create a mall full of makers! I dove in, and made sure Strange Folk's guaranteed revenue sources would more than cover it's total annual expenses. Expenses that have never included the mass-customization machines and tools I have been dreaming of using to produce installation pieces, upcycled graphic elements, hands-on project components and much more. Nor have those expenses ever included anything but a scant salary for myself for a decade. That just can't continue. 

I'm not going to gouge vendors or impose lines and ticket scanners on our guests that have been able to come and go as they please all these years.
My store, The Upcycle Exchange, has operated as pay-as-you-wish retail for 5 years. This concept can be a bellwether for what a community values, and I have experienced a remarkable amount of common ground and generosity through it. 
By initially ending Strange Folk, I had hoped to focus on Upcycle. Under updated circumstances, I decided on the opposite approach. I've scaled back my shop momentarily and moved to a private headquarters so I can work non-stop on Strange Folk 2015. 
If this campaign is successful, Strange Folk will not end at Union Station. I'd love to take it back to a park after this and to keep producing it in the authentic manner that I always have. I refuse to compromise the integrity of what I've created. 
No matter what, I will continue to pursue exciting creative projects that benefit the St. Louis region and the maker community at large, and am endlessly grateful to contributors and supporters of the spirit of Strange Folk. You enable pioneering retail platforms and modes of fabrication. This isn't just a craft show. "






It's simple. If you like Strange Folk Festival, then you can buy a ticket to support it, even though you don't need one to attend. That said, we are ever-enterprising, and have thought up some enticing perks! For $10, you'll get a one-time use coupon for 10% off a single purchase from any mall vendor. Spend $100 with that vendor, and your ticket is paid for. Plus, the ticket includes locally harvested organic seeds to plant in your garden by Quixlan Seed Co.
Festival merch in the works will feature 2015's whimsical gnome drawing by Jeffrey Johnson of Red Herring Illustration. Get a tote bag at $25, and a tote +T-shirt at $50. 
At the $100 level, you'll additionally receive a copy of the children's book that Jeffrey and Autumn are self-publishing. It teaches both kids and adults the basics of intellectual property law. This perk level includes real estate on our interactive "Wall of Strange Folks to Follow." That includes one photo with one social media profile that you would like attendees to follow. You can put that selfie stick to work, or maybe you'd rather show off the crackers you ate for lunch. Who are we to judge?

If you are interested in a business sponsorship, get in touch with a comment here or with Magan at magan.strangefolk@gmail.com. We have a wide range of options that include low-price base sponsorship and bartering possibilities. We'd love to find out more about your company and determine if it is a good fit for Strange Folk.   The Impact By purchasing a "ticket" you'll be helping to support one of the Midwest's largest and most loved indie craft shows.   Strange Folk Festival has been produced independently for 10 years with little to no financial sponsorship. You are supporting a diverse network of independent makers who have worked hard to build a vibrant and authentic culture that propels small businesses in the St. Louis region. 

Strange Folk Festival continues to be an important outlet for local small businesses to get out in front of a huge crowd. By chipping in, you'll even help the vendors you don't buy anything from to continue to make a living at making what they love. 
We are investing in equipment to MAKE Strange Folk's exhibits and decor even more amazing and sustainable.  A robust crowd-fund campaign would help pay for the mass-customization devices, tools, storage and supplies that will launch Fort Featherbottom and other installations in to the stratosphere of coolness!

story:
My goal is to get my artwork known worldwide and into well established galleries. As most artists know....shipping artwork to galleries, crating, travel and production costs are very expensive. With your help, I can get my art out there and add beauty into the world of art. All of my art is for sale on my website at: http://www.monikajensenproductions.com

You will be making a big difference and supporting the arts. Every bit helps and would be appreciated! Thank you
Bio:

Contemporary artist, Monika Jensen is recognized in the entertainment industry as "The celebrity artist". She is nationally and internationally published around the world in several contemporary master books, magazines and has since launched her own book. 

She is the founder of a new style of painting called Stereographic Dimension. She specializes in commissioned works for her elite clientèle, celebrities and large corporate clients who desire a unique art piece in their art investments. 


All her works are one of a kind, original art pieces that explore her unique style with color and extreme texture. Each piece is layered with oils. Over a time of one year to create each piece, these unique paintings have become most wanted as they are not duplicated.

Her unique art technique has made her brand a household name. Making appearances on the red carpet at The Grammy Awards and also being the exclusive artist at The Oscars Lounge GBK, her notoriety in the industry has exploded.

story:
Short Summary

Art In The Yard is my annual labor of love.  Art In The Yard 7 will be held  on August 8th from 4:17p-9p at Art Produce Garden (3139 University Ave., SD, Ca 92104).  It is an urban art experience that originated as a way to showcase my art.  I use to hold in my front yard.  It has grown every year.  A couple of years ago we moved the event to the Art Produce Garden.  Since then our turnout has continue to grow and grow.  Last year we had over 300 people attend!!  Now it is a way to bring recognition and visibility to artists and vendors (especially in our community) that might not show or sell anywhere else.  I want to help foster other creativity and talent and really celebrate the arts.

In years past I have paid for the event out of my own pocket.  This year, as I am trying to grow this event, I am adding other features.  I'm so pleased to officially announce the artists, vendors, and performers that are participating in Art In The Yard 7. 

Artists:

Rudy Flores- http://serolfrydur.deviantart.com

Clee Sobieski- http://cleesobieski.prosite.com

Norma Brinker- http://www.noricfineartgallery.com

Tim Stockton- http://www.timsearthart.com

Michael Richardson-

Demar Douglas- http://www.demardouglas.com

Daniel Jaimes- http://www.dansartworksd.com

Old Man-

Oriya Rae- www.soulmapstudio.com

Anya- http://www.art1923e.com

Vendors:

Kiyyah's Kitchen- https://www.facebook.com/KiyyahsKitchen

Lynora Simmons, CMT, HHP

Elisea Mercado-

Denise Devall- Seacret Skin Care- https://seacretdirect.com/devall55

Retail Therapy & Treat Therapy by Anya- https://www.facebook.com/art1923e

Performers:

DJ Katzgroove
DJ Pokkey
DJ Lord Sandwiches

Dawn Mitschele- http://www.dawnmitschele.com/

Miki Vale- http://www.mikivale.com 

Open Mic hosted by Sauce @ 8p- https://www.facebook.com/wordsbysauce

The larger and more successful the event is the more it costs.  That's where all of you come in!! Your contribution will help all involved be able to show their skill and talent at another level and provide a culture rich atmosphere for the community.

What We Need & What You Get

Okay kind folks were trying to raise $4500.  This money is to pay for the venue (use of it and insurance), the advertising (fliers, posters, print media, online media, etc), art supplies (canvas, hanging material, paint, wood), other supplies (lights, sound equipment, easel rentals, food & drink ingredients, food services supplies, etc).

There are lots of perks ranging from accessories, to custom artwork, to a gourmet dinner by and with one of the artists.  

If for some reason we don't raise the entire amount all the money raised will still go towards covering the costs of the aforementioned necessities.

All perks are to be claimed at the actual Art In The Yard 7 event.

The Impact

Art In The Yard was created to help folks get "out" there.  I started this event originally because I was painting but didn't know how or where to show my work. Most galleries want commission and a reputation and you have to know people to get into art shows typically.  A friend of mine suggested that I hold my own event to showcase my art.  So I did!!  I started realizing a lot of artists and other very creative people felt the same way so I invited them to show their work and sell their wares.  

It has grown every year.  The first year we had 30 people and as I stated before, last year we had over 300!!  Art In The Yard is allowing unknown talents to show their work, feel a sense of accomplishment.  Can you imagine being an independent or underground artist or vendor that has never shown anywhere and then showing and selling at a well attended show?  It completely changes the way one thinks about themselves and their craft.  It's an AMAZING feeling!!  I have seen unknown artists that have participated in this event go on to be well respected in the art community and show their work all over, regularly.  That has been the real mission of this event.  I just hope to see it more often.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest obstacles we face this year are time and space.  This year the I have been happily inundated with requests to be involved in/with the show.  While that is great the space in which we hold the event is finite and currently evolving which has the potential to limit how many people can participate.  If were, able to raise enough money in time we may be able to expand the event into the adjoining the alley.This would allow us to add more vendors and artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!!
  • Come to the actual event on August 9th!!  Bring people with you too!!  It starts at 4:17p (yes, 4:17p I'm random LOL!!) and ends at 9p.  It will be held at Art Produce Garden at 3139 University Ave., SD, Ca 92104

And that's all there is to it.  Thank you all in advance for you support.  It's truly appreciated.

story:
Our Project

During Nepal's recent and massive earthquakes, the world watched as hundreds of thousands of Nepalis lost their homes, livelihoods, and, in many cases, their loved ones. While the work is far from complete, dozens of governments and multinational charities, together with millions of donors worldwide, are addressing this immense and pressing humanitarian challenge.
To compound this tragedy, however, Nepal's cultural heritage was dealt an awesome blow as dozens of irreplaceable cultural sites were devastated. Among them, the venerable Char Narayan - a central monument and the oldest multi-tiered temple of the Patan Darbar Square - collapsed to an unrecognizable pile of rubble atop its historic plinth.

In a modest effort to play a small role in Nepal's recovery, The DeVos Institute of Arts Management Global Fellows Network and the New York City-based Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust (KVPT) are leading this campaign to support the reconstruction efforts of the Char Narayan temple, a source of immense national pride and identity for the people of Nepal.

About the Char Narayan Temple and its restoration
The temple's four-faced Visnu icon has long been a part of daily religious life for the people of Patan. Built in 1565, the temple is architecturally significant as an example of the early multi-tiered roof temples comprised of two levels, an inner ambulatory, and an extensive program of early door and window timber carved elements in its facades.

Char Narayan anchors the Patan Darbar Square, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, whose square and adjacent lanes constitute one of South Asia's great architectural ensembles. Facing the temple and defining one side of the square, the restored Patan Royal Palace houses the critically-acclaimed Patan Museum and Architecture Galleries, attracting more visitors than any site in the country.

KVPT began damage assessment in the Square shortly after the quake and set up temporary storage facilities for collected rubble. Due to this timely intervention, all of the temple's historic carved portals and other key elements were recovered and are already under repair. KVPT is working with engineering specialists in the field of reinforcing historic structures. A U.S.-based charity with full tax-deductible status, KVPT is Nepal's only international organization registered in the field of architectural preservation, having restored some 45 buildings since its founding in 1991.

This initiative is represented locally in Nepal by  by Sangeeta Thapa, 2014 DeVos Institute Fellow and Curator and Director of the Siddhartha Art Gallery and Kathmandu Contemporary Arts Centre in Kathmandu, Nepal, an institution that supports Nepalese artists, fosters intercultural communication, and leads arts education programs.

With so much of Nepal's architectural heritage gone in a flash, please support this project and the incredible Nepali staff of architects, stone masons, gilders, and builders arranged by KVPT in reconstructing this important temple and preserving Nepal's rich cultural heritage. This is a vote of confidence in the future of Nepal and in the importance of protecting our shared cultural treasures.

The Funds

  • The goal of this campaign is to raise $200,000 for the restoration of the Char Narayan  temple in Patan Darbar Square, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Nepal. These funds would go primarily toward rebuilding the roof of this historic site.
  • The funds donated to this campaign are being directed to the Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust (KVPT), Nepal's only international organization registered in the field of architectural preservation. KVPT is a non-profit organization with a long history of historic preservation and reconstruction in Nepal, having restored some 45 buildings since its founding in 1991.
  • As KVPT has the existing infrastructure, expertise, and personnel in Nepal, your entire donation will be directly spent on emergency cultural relief work.
  • KVPT is a 501c3 New York-based charity. As such, donations from U.S. citizens are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.
  • Reconstruction on the structure is set to begin in the summer of 2015, with the full project to be complete by January 2017.

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope that you will join us in this campaign and in spreading the word that rebuilding is imminent. We hope that the reconstruction of Char Narayan will be a symbol of regeneration for the people of Nepal.

Thank you for your support in restoring Nepal's cultural heritage.

For More Information

The DeVos Institute of Arts Management provides training, consultation, and implementation support for arts managers and their boards.

It operates on the premise that while much is spent to train artists, too little is spent to support the managers and boards who keep those artists at work.

DeVos Institute of Arts Management Website

The Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust (KVPT) was founded in 1991 with the mission to safeguard the extraordinary and threatened architectural heritage of the Kathmandy Valley in Nepal. The negative impact of today's development pressures poses a threat not only to individual monuments but to the future of public space and urban life in the valley life.

Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust Website

Sangeeta Thapa is the Founder of The Siddhartha Arts Foundation which was built on the extensive networks amassed by its sister project, the Siddhartha Art Gallery which was established in 1987. She has curated over 300 art shows of Nepali and international artists, regularly consults for collectors of Nepalese art, and initiates community art projects. She is the publisher of three volumes of poetry (Kulla Dhoka, Nirantar Khulla Dhoka, and A Thousand Earths Thousand Skies), has written a book on the drawings of Nepali artist Manuj Babu Mishra entitled In the Eye of the Storm, and is author of the narrative collection Telling a Tale. Ms. Thapa is the sole organizer of the Kathmandu International Art Festival (and any/all of its satellite programs).
