The negative impact of today's development pressures poses a threat not only to individual monuments but to the future of public space and urban life in the valley life.Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust WebsiteSangeeta Thapa is the Founder of The Siddhartha Arts Foundation which was built on the extensive networks amassed by its sister project, the Siddhartha Art Gallery which was established in 1987. She has curated over 300 art shows of Nepali and international artists, regularly consults for collectors of Nepalese art, and initiates community art projects. She is the publisher of three volumes of poetry (Kulla Dhoka, Nirantar Khulla Dhoka, and A Thousand Earths Thousand Skies), has written a book on the drawings of Nepali artist Manuj Babu Mishra entitled In the Eye of the Storm, and is author of the narrative collection Telling a Tale. Ms. Thapa is the sole organizer of the Kathmandu International Art Festival (and any/all of its satellite programs).

story:
A long-time dancer on the Venice Beach Boardwalk who became a legend in the world of West Coast street dancing and hip-hop culture in film and television, Vincent “Mr. Animation” Foster died at age 49 when he was struck by a taxi cab while in Las Vegas on September 23rd.

Mr. Animation’s early Venice Beach performances coincided with street dance’s emergence into mainstream culture. At age 18, Foster was discovered by Hollywood where he was hired as a principal dancer for the film 1984 Breakin’ 2: Electric Boogaloo, starring Ice-T and other breakdance legends like Shabba-Doo and Boogaloo Shrimp.

From there, Foster joined an existing street dance group called Air Force Crew, started by dancers Lil Cesar and Wilpower, which gained worldwide recognition for expanding the art of b-boying and street culture with tours to Japan, Germany, Italy, UK, and Australia.

After touring the world with Air Force Crew, Foster returned to Southern California where he became a fixture on Venice Beach for over 30 years, while also performing at Santa Monica’s Third Street Promenade and Hollywood’s Walk-of-Fame. Mr. Animation often drew hundreds of on-lookers as he mixed his dance moves with comical skits and audience participation.

“I chose to make people laugh for a living,” he once said.

Mr. Animation was born Vincent Forster on October 16, 1966 and raised in South Central L.A. as one of ten brothers by a single mother, and became a member of a gang by age 15. He then came under the influence of Carmelo Alvarez, the director of Radiotron, a youth center that acted as a safe haven for kids who wanted to get out of gang life. Alvarez introduced Foster to Venice Beach Boardwalk and opened up a whole new world of street performing.

When a kid in his audience one day remarked that he animated well, Vincent Foster’s new moniker “Mr. Animation” stuck. Taking inspiration from by Michael Jackson, Richard Pryor, and James Brown, Mr. Animation developed signature moves such as “The Moonrun” and “The Lean” that have since become part of the street dance lexicon.

Passing on the lessons from Alvarez’ Radiotron, Mr. Animation mentored dancers and choreographers including Wade Robson, Eric Nash, Lil Buck, John Boogs, and Jacob Jonas, who now leads the L.A.-based Jacob Jonas The Company.

Jonas described Mr. Animation as a true entertainer who will be greatly missed.

“Mr. Animation’s legacy of positive energy and his contributions to the culture of hip-hop and street theater will live on forever in the memory of those who saw him perform, dancers like me who benefited from his mentoring, and the hip hop street culture at large,” said Jonas.

Additional credits include performances on America’s Got Talent, The Tonight Show Starring Jay Leno, My Wife With Kids, Rhyme and Reason, and concert tours with artists such as Missy Elliot, Wu-Tang Clan, Kurtis Blow, Xzibit, Fatboy Slim, and Run-D.M.C.

Mr. Animation deserves to be remembered for years to come. Please donate and share this campaign to help us reach our goal. We are doing all we can to ensure this mural will be around for many years to come. He deserves it, because he contributed so much to Venice Beach history... And we want to make sure he will never be forgotten...  Thanks for your time, prayers and donations, God bless you all!

story:
• Sheep Uy Colors is a family company founded on February 5, 2014 by two brothers, Adrian (34) and Marcelo (33).

    Coming from a family of craftsmen , we understood the passion and dedication to craft work at a very young age, our parents were great artisans dedicated to handmade leather work.

    Having dedicated most of our lives working for major textile companies in Uruguay , we decided it was time to start our own project, or as we call it , our dream.

    Having great expertise in yarns and natural fibers as well as being experts on hand dyeing techniques, what unites us most is the passion and dedication we feel to create something with our own hands.

    At the beginning, we set up a small workshop with large pots where we began to develop and dye colors for our first color chart, then through social media many people began to follow our work and showed their admiration and affection for our work.

    Almost without realizing it , we were sending our first samples abroad  with great success! 

 

  • Thanks to these funds can we bring our yarns and colors to fairs and also to visit new stores. 
  • Our main objective is to ensure that more people can try the excellent quality of our yarns. 
  • One of the main fairs which we will attend is the TNNA, it is here where concentrates the greatest number of potential customers for our yarn.
  • Another of our aspirations is to be able to establish a subsidiary of our company in the United States, to improve the time of delivery to our customers.

  

  • We are sure that with your help we can grow and help various craftsmen of my country training them in this beautiful art.
  • Also with these funds we will be able to add elements of advertising and marketing to our product.
  • Also you can help us spreading our project and come to more kind persons like you.
  • Not to reach the amount established the funds could be used for any of the several objectives.

Our dream is very close, with your support our dear project soon will convert in to success.

Many, many thanks

Adrian Olivera and Marcelo Olivera

story:
My Story

           Hi I'm Jenna Anderson and thank you so much for your interest in my project.  By request this "Part II" is in an effort to open back up the opportunity for those of you that have expressed an interest in contributing but missed the window for the first one!  Check out the new perks and grab your gift or message me with a special request! And, help raise that last 23% percentage of the goal to fulfill my project!   I've been dreaming of making this idea a reality for a while now and I'm so excited to finally jump in! For nine years I've been focusing on commissions and teaching to support myself, family and business while working at becoming a better painter. I feel blessed to be able to be an artist and I've just learned so much over the years through working on commissions and teaching- that it's been the most enjoyable time of my life.  With that being said, I also feel I haven't had the invaluable time needed to be able to focus fully on evolving my own visions/feelings in my work and I'm ready now more than ever.  I’ve invested in myself, applied to grants and I'm always looking for opportunities that may help me achieve this goal-they have lead me here.  So, I'm ready to let go of the reins and stop looking at other art, quiet the voices of the outside world and truly tap into my own.  This break from these distractions will allow me the opportunity to build a powerful body of work that I can pour myself into fully, heart and soul.  Work that I can carry into the future, pursuing gallery representation, having solo exhibitions and other opportunities that will open many more doors to explore.  

The Funds & Perks

I’ll need 9,000 to cover and complete this project. 

To create the new paintings there are some supplies I will need.  They have come out to $4650.  They are as follows: Paint, Substrates, stretcher bars, studio and application tools, brushes, updated lighting, mediums, varnish and frames.

Other Expenses have come out to $4350: Studio/gallery yearly rent (I've had a public gallery space at LibertyTown Arts in Fredericksburg Va since 2009 that I LOVE and cannot afford to stay, and am trying to keep it for another year-as it's been very helpful exposure), Living expenses, New Website yearly fee, shipping costs of my work to different galleries in the USA, and Perk fulfillment. 

Here is the link to LibertyTown Arts!: http://www.libertytownarts.com/site/

And, here is me in my studio/gallery space through out the years there!: 


So...Perks! The fun part! 

I'm so excited about sharing these with you. I'm offering original charcoal drawings and oil paintings for lower prices, email critiques, wildcards, VIP invitations to see the Solo Show work first, art discounts and other surprises.   I'm also putting together some rad handwritten thank you cards because I appreciate you all so much.  

Below are photos of the pieces you are purchasing when you make a donation. They are listed in order to match up with the perks on the main page.  For more details or questions, feel free to message me here: jennaanderson2016@gmail.com  (Scroll down to the bottom of the story to view the images)

The Impact

               This campaign is just the beginning of the path I wish to be on, moving forward towards my goals.  My overall goal as a painter is to paint what I love.  And, I've been working hard for nine years now during which I've been eagerly gathering the reference material for these "love" paintings, and they've been patiently waiting for me to bring them to life.  I think..Honestly,their patience is running low... but that's a whole other story.  But, my point being, I've wanted nothing more in my life than the chance to paint them and it's Time.  At the end of this journey of a year I will hold a Solo Exhibition, unveiling this new library of paintings all together as a series.  The difference you will be making in my life will be more profound than I can possibly express, both mentally and spiritually.   With your help I can grow and evolve as an artist, building upon the foundation I’ve started- towards something even more amazing and authentically me.  And, I'll be able to keep my studio/gallery space that I love at LibertyTown Arts which will help me even further and keep me going strong on my journey! Now is your opportunity to give a little bit that will help me for a lifetime.  

I hope to share with you this new work and new energy it brings out.  I’ve never had a campaign or done anything like this, but I don't give up and would love the chance to prove myself to you.  Because, I’m obsessed with creating art, with painting and if I don’t get this chance I may go a little crazy.  And, I'm looking forward to sharing this journey with you as I keep you updated on my progress throughout the year. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute there is another way you can help!:

You can get the word out and make some noise about my campaign- I will be so grateful.  Indiegogo has some great share tools available to help make it easy! I thank you so much for your time and helping me make this happen! 

Want a quick way to peek in on my progress? You can Follow me on Instagram! 

https://instagram.com/jennaandersonfineart/

Or facebook!

https://www.facebook.com/jenna.anderson.3766 

************************************************

$75                                                Bird Painting

This is the series your bird will be plucked from.  I'll personal hand pick one just for you!  


                                                                         (Detail)

                                                                                  *

$150                                                 Rose Painting

This dried rose painting was done from life - Alla Prima, in my studio.

                                                                              *

$500                                        Wildflower Painting

This painting was done from wildflowers I handpicked in a field and brought back to the studio <3

Progression of Wildflower Study, oil on panel. For this piece I explored a starting method I felt suited my subject most. I went from the parts to the whole. Selecting a small part of my subject, finishing it, selecting the adjoining part, finishing that and so on until all is whole. This approach allows you to explore all the elements in the subject at once, having fun with the subsequent stages of the painting.

                                                                 (Studio shot) 

                                                                               *

16 x 20 charcoal and acetone on quality bristol paper (Framed)

$725                                       Painting Dove Pendant

14 x 18 oil on panel (unframed)

This poor dove flew into the glass of my front door.  I came home to find him on the welcome mat and immediately set up a still life in his honor.  I always wanted to paint a dead bird and one literally showed up on my door step!!

                                                                               *

$800                                     Self-Portrait in Charcoal      

My first full face-intense study of myself.  I experimented with charcoal and acetone on mylar.

                                                                       (Detail)

Now is your opportunity to give a little bit that will help me for a lifetime.  I hope to share with you this new work and new energy it brings out.  I’ve never had a campaign or done anything like this, but I don't give up and would love the chance to prove myself to you.  Because, I’m obsessed with creating art, with painting and if I don’t get this chance I may go a little crazy.  And, I'm looking forward to sharing this journey with you as I keep you updated on my progress throughout the year. 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute there is another way you can help!:
You can get the word out and make some noise about my campaign- I will be so grateful.  Indiegogo has some great share tools available to help make it easy! I thank you so much for your time and helping me make this happen! 
Want a quick way to peek in on my progress? You can Follow me on Instagram! 
https://instagram.com/jennaandersonfineart/
Or facebook!
https://www.facebook.com/jenna.anderson.3766

                                                                              *
$500                                        Wildflower Painting
This painting was done from wildflowers I handpicked in a field and brought back to the studio <3


Progression of Wildflower Study, oil on panel. For this piece I explored a starting method I felt suited my subject most. I went from the parts to the whole. Selecting a small part of my subject, finishing it, selecting the adjoining part, finishing that and so on until all is whole. This approach allows you to explore all the elements in the subject at once, having fun with the subsequent stages of the painting.


                                                                 (Studio shot)                                                                                *

$725                                       Painting Dove Pendant
14 x 18 oil on panel (unframed)
This poor dove flew into the glass of my front door.  I came home to find him on the welcome mat and immediately set up a still life in his honor.  I always wanted to paint a dead bird and one literally showed up on my door step!!

                                                                               *$800                                     Self-Portrait in Charcoal      
My first full face-intense study of myself.  I experimented with charcoal and acetone on mylar.

14 x 18 oil on panel (unframed)

story:
(Rokudenashiko solo exhibition at Shinjyuku Ganka Garou, May, 2014)

Thank you for your time and support!


Our goal is to realize an exhibition ‘Gender, Genitor, Genitalia - Rokudenashiko Tribute', the exhibition that was inspired by the incident of Megumi Igarashi, as known as Rokudenashiko who was arrested by her art works and now in the trial.


Firstly, we think it is important to let people know what is happening in Japan. Not only with Rokudenshiko, but also those LGBT artists in Japan who have been warned or arrested under the Obscenity Laws in the past three years. People in Hong Kong are aware of freedom of artistic expression and we believe that it is significant to realize this project in Hong Kong, a hub in Asia and also a location that is highly aware of, even threatened by, authoritarian politics. 
Secondly, relating to Rokudenashiko's incident, we will try to examine feminism in art and digital obscenity in this exhibition, within the context of the Hong Kong and Japanese experience. Through the works of art in this exhibition, and information provided about the Rokudenashiko case, we will be rethinking issues around feminism and genitalia in a cultural and political context. 
Additionally, hold a feminist exhibition featuring relatively young artists in Asia is important as not many shows have had this focus. 
Overall, we attempt to 1: revisit feminist art and works that directly refer to genitalia,  2: raise the issue of censorship through the case of Rokudenashiko, and 3: support Megumi Igarashi (the artist known as Rokudenashiko), who was arrested for creating artwork representing her vagina, and distributing 3D data of her vagina on the internet. 

We support Rokudenashiko by exhibiting her works and selling her 'Sof Vi Manko Chan' character, and donating the proceeds to the cost of her trial.


Title: Gender, Genitor, Genitalia –Rokudenashiko Tribute

Date: 29th August 2015 to 20th September 2015

Venue: Woofer Ten  活化廳

404, Shanghai Street, Yau Ma Tei, Kowloon, Hong Kong

Participating Artists:

  • Makoto Aida 会田誠
  • Michael Leung 梁志剛 
  • Phoebe Man 文晶瑩
  • Lam Hoi Sin 林愷倩

  • Ling & Comma （ Gao Ling &  Elaine W. Ho, 高靈&何穎雅 ）

  • Sputniko! スプツニ子!　　

  • ROBOT (John Miller and Takuji Kogo)　ロボット（ジョンミラー＋古郷卓司）

  • Rokudenashiko ろくでなしこ

  • Ryoko Suzuki 鈴木涼子
  • Chan Mei Tung 陳美彤
  • K Y Wong 黃嘉瀛
  • Yuk King Tan

(image: KY Wong, He, glass, silkscreen print, collage, ink, acrylic and oil paint,
, 2015)

Events:

-Talk event with artists, including Rokudenashiko, Ryoko Suzuki and participating artists

-Performance by Chan Mei Tung


Background:


July 2014 in Tokyo, the artist Megumi Igarashi (also known as Rokudenashiko) has been arrested for distributing her vagina 3D data onto an internet crowdfunding site. This is believed to be in violation of the Japanese Obscenity Laws. She was released after a few days, then arrested again in December 2014. This time she was in police custody for the maximum duration in this type of case, 23 days.


The male genitals can be seen sometimes at traditional Japanese festivals, the ‘secret treasure’ museums and in some contemporary art works. Rokudenashiko believes that the vagina is overly hidden compared to the penis. She started working on this theme because she wants to liberate women from thinking of their vaginas as a dirty image. Her intention is to liberate women to become more open and uninhabited over their vaginas, and thus, equalize males and females. Her trial started in April 2015. She and a group of attorneys denied obscenity charges and argued censorship of artistic expression and Japan’s double standards. Pornographic cartoons are numerous in Japan, why were her works of arts selected for punishment?

In March 2015, there was a symposium organized by The Coming Society in Hong Kong. There was a presentation about the Rokudenashiko incident by Ai Kano, PhD student at the Tokyo University of Fine Art. At the post-symposium dinner, a member of the audience, the Hong Kong based designer and a farmer Michael Leung, said "We should do an exhibition for her in Hong Kong!”

At the table there were several people from Woofer Ten, including Professor Mouri of the Tokyo University of the Arts and Hitomi Hasegawa, Hong Kong based Japanese curator. They decided to do an exhibition for her. Ms Hasegawa created the concept and selected some artists, and Lee Chun Fung, an artist and initiator of Woofer Ten, added several emerging artists from Hong Kong.

More about this project


There are several issues raised by Rokudenashiko's case such as: censorship, infringement of freedom of expression: Japanese legal issues (conflicts of the Article 175 and the Article 21, concerning freedom of expression): digital art, internet issues, new technology such as 3D data, printing and obscenity: feminism, feminist art, including how genitalia has been applied to visual art.

Rokudenashiko uses her vagina as the main theme of her art, and believes that her art helps to heighten women's self esteem and create gender equality. The project will start by gathering some works relating to genitalia. The works (by Aida, Rokudenashiko, Suzuki, Lam, Man, and Leung) will examine why those art works about genitalia are made and how they vary in concepts such as identity, political provocation, sexuality, an aesthetic point of view and so on.


Secondly, feminist art is usually a rare category of art in Asia, and not many exhibitions on the theme have taken place in the past. We would like to align the works within a feminist context in Hong Kong and Japan, and consider whether the artists think they are feminists or not. Feminism is not a unified ideology, and several groups have different ideas. The exhibition includes different concepts of feminism, from different points of view; from 'Lipstick Feminism' (Robot, Sputniko!) to the more classical ideal of liberating woman from oppression (Suzuki, Man, Rokudenashiko). 

Gender issues in the digital world are an emerging issue. Some of the works deal with sexual desire and body politics in internet culture (Suzuki, Lam, Chan), which relates to our theme as Rokudenashiko was arrested for distributing her 3D vagina data.

How your funds would be used?

We will use your help to invite some artists and experts, including Rokudenashiko, to create a dialogue and discussion. And to realize the exhibition, we need:

  • Airfare and accommodation costs for the artists and talk guests,
  • Installation and exhibition cost,
  • Insurance, transportation, and  personnel cost,
  • Venue fees for exhibition and events,
  • Documentation cost,
  • Catalogue design and printing,
  • Equipment rental fees (as we have several videos).


Why should you support us?

We are highly dependent on volunteer work as Woofer Ten is an independent organisation run by artists and activists. Due to the controversial content of this exhibition, it is difficult for us to get any public or institutional funding. 

Again, it is important to let people know what is happening in Japan. Many members of the LGBT community, including Ryudai Takano, Leslie Kee and Mao Sugiyama, have been warned or arrested under the Obscenity Law in the last three years. 

In Hong Kong people are very aware of the authoritative interventions used against freedom of expression due to the Umbrella Movement and its aftermath. It would be important and intriguing to inform what is happening in Japan now through this exhibition.

Thanks for your time and please consider helping us. If you cannot, please spread the link to your friends and talk about the exhibition. Thank you!


More information about Rokudenshiko here:

Japanese artist goes on trial over 'vagina selfies'
April 2015
http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/15/ja...

Japan charges Tokyo 'vagina artist' with obscenity
December 2014
www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30595378

story:
Description

The mission of St. Louis ArtWorks is to broaden educational and career opportunities for youth in the St. Louis region through apprenticeships in the arts and through community collaborations.

Over the last 20 years, St. Louis ArtWorks has provided thousands of teens (14-19) exposure to the arts through our innovative job training program. Teens are apprenticed to professional artists and work in teams developing works of art for sale, commission, and public performance. The teens receive workforce development, arts education, and life skills training, all while earning a stipend.

In 2015 we are dreaming big and need your help to provide more opportunities to St. Louis youth.


Your Support helps....

This historic move to a new flagship location will enable us to provide 45 additional paid apprenticeship positions to St. Louis youth in the first year alone; that’s a 22% growth in services! We anticipate being able to serve more than 200 youth by the end of the first year and offer new and innovative services with this expanded space.

These funds will support our state of the art technology lab, where apprentices and their professional teaching artists will create videos, animations, and other digital media under Boomerang Press/Media, our oldest of three social enterprises.

We will create The Garage @ ArtWorks, a member-driven community space for makers, tinkerers and DIYers of all ages to create and collaborate. A Makerspace is a learning environment that connects teachers and community members by placing innovative tools in the hands of a wider audience.

Our lower level will feature a Cafeteria and Meeting Space where we can serve nutritious meals and provide life skills workshops during both the after school and summer programs.

  • $30 can cover the cost of 1 participant in our After School Program for 1 week.
  • $75 can provide uniforms for 12 Apprentices.
  • $1000 is enough to fund an Apprentice stipend for the summer session.

Perks

20% discount on art at our Holiday sale!  $10 

ArtWorks @ Loop East Postcards! $25

Funders Party!  $50  (and above)

Boomerang Press Greeting Cards!   $75   

*Limited Edition* Haiku Book!  $100

Boomerang BikeArt!   $150 

Painted Rain Barrel!  $300 


Risks & Challenges

Funds raised will be support the build out of our new space. As with any construction project, additional costs come up during the process. Your support means greater benefit to the hundreds of teen apprentices St. Louis ArtWorks educates throughout the year. Thank you for helping us to complete the picture!
story_txt:
Description 

The mission of St. Louis ArtWorks is to broaden
educational and career opportunities for youth in the St. Louis region through apprenticeships in
the arts and through community collaborations. 
Over the last 20 years, St.
Louis ArtWorks has provided thousands of teens (14-19) exposure to the arts
through our innovative job training program. Teens are apprenticed to
professional artists and work in teams developing works of art for sale,
commission, and public performance. The teens receive workforce development,
arts education, and life skills training, all while earning a stipend. 
In 2015 we are
dreaming big and need your help to provide more opportunities to St. Louis
youth. 

  Your Support helps....This historic
move to a new flagship location will enable us to provide 45 additional paid apprenticeship
positions to St. Louis youth in the first year alone; that’s a 22% growth in
services! We anticipate being able to serve more than 200 youth by the end of the first
year and offer new and innovative services with this expanded space.
These funds will
support our state of the art technology
lab, where apprentices and their professional teaching artists will create
videos, animations, and other digital media under Boomerang Press/Media, our
oldest of three social enterprises. 
We will create The Garage @ ArtWorks, a member-driven
community space for makers, tinkerers
and DIYers of all ages to create and collaborate. A Makerspace is a learning
environment that connects teachers and community members by placing innovative
tools in the hands of a wider audience.
Our lower level
will feature a Cafeteria and Meeting
Space where we can serve nutritious meals and provide life skills
workshops during both the after school
and summer programs.    


$30 can cover the cost of 1 participant in our After School Program for 1 week.
$75 can provide uniforms for 12 Apprentices.
$1000 is enough to fund an Apprentice stipend for the summer session.

Perks


20% discount
on art at our Holiday sale!  $10  
ArtWorks @ Loop East Postcards! $25
Funders Party!  $50  (and above)
Boomerang Press Greeting Cards!   $75    
*Limited Edition* Haiku Book!  $100
Boomerang BikeArt!   $150  
Painted Rain
Barrel!  $300  
Risks & Challenges

Funds raised will be support the build out of our new space. As with any construction project, additional costs come up during the process. Your support means greater benefit to the hundreds of teen apprentices St. Louis ArtWorks educates throughout the year. Thank you for helping us to complete the picture!

story:
A Living Chance is a multimedia storytelling project created in collaboration with people serving Life Without Parole (LWOP) in California state women's prisons. This project aims to educate the public about LWOP sentencing and to give a voice to those who have been sentenced to live the rest of their lives in prison. These portraits are a part of this larger project and will serve as a visual reference for the recorded and written testimonials of the participants. 

This project is supported by California Coalition for Women Prisoners, a grassroots social justice organization with members inside and outside of prison. 

www.alivingchance.com

www.womenprisoners.org 


WHY IS THIS PROJECT IMPORTANT?

As Misty Rojo, survivor of 10 years in California's state prisons states, "Prisons permeate everything. They affect everyone; not only people imprisoned but those who love them. We are told they fix people but they really break them. They destroy the potential of living for people sentenced to LWOP."

People sentenced to LWOP will spend the rest of their natural lives behind bars. They are often prohibited from participating in the few programs available in prison or from joining in work assignments. This is a punishment that often destroys hope, and has come to be known as the "living death sentence". 

There are approximately 172 people serving LWOP sentences in California's state women's prisons. The majority of them are survivors of childhood abuse and/or intimate partner battery. In most of these cases, evidence of their abuse was not presented at trial. In order to redress LWOP, we must first amplify the voices of those living under it. We need your support to help carry their voices beyond the prison walls, and we hope that through this combined effort we can bring greater social and political attention to the "sentence that kills us slowly." 

WHAT WE NEED:

I'm seeking $6,000 to help cover the production and exhibition costs of the portraits. Funding will allow for framing, photographing, prints, packaging and shipping. Prints and poster copies will be sent to those inside and the original paintings will ultimately be gifted to the families or loved ones of the participants. Additionally, we aim to exhibit this project throughout California, and we need your help to bring it to multiple venues. 

Your support can make all this possible. 

Thank you so much!

MORE WAYS TO HELP:

•Tell people how important this project is and ask them to contribute

•Forward this email/video/post to your networks

•Host a dinner party fundraiser

•Consider collecting donations to sponsor this project as a group or as an organization 

•Identify or connect us with spaces to host educational workshops and presentations, including community spaces, event halls, art galleries, etc.

•Write to someone inside, let them know you saw the project and you are standing with them

Wanna help? Be in touch: lilbelo@gmail.com / adrienne@womenprisoners.org

A LITTLE ABOUT THE PAINTINGS:

The paintings are all oil on wood panel, 11x14. They were painted from reference photos that were chosen by and sent from the participants. 

BIOGRAPHIES

California Coalition for Women Prisoners (CCWP) is a grassroots, social justice organization with members inside and outside of prison. CCWP challenges the institutional violence imposed on women, transgender people, and communities of color by the prison industrial complex (PIC). CCWP understands the struggle for racial and gender justice as central to dismantling the PIC and prioritizes the leadership of the people, families, and communities most impacted in building this movement. CCWP began in 1995 when people inside the women's prisons filed a lawsuit against then-governor Pete Wilson rightfully claiming that the healthcare inside prison was so terrible it violated their 8th amendment rights. For nearly 20 years, CCWP has been organizing against prisons and all forms of imprisonment and social control and for the human rights and dignity of people forced to live behind prison walls. More here: womenprisoners.org

Billie Simões Belo was a social worker for 6 years and worked with adults living with HIV and/or mental illness in San Francisco and New York City. In 2012, she left social work and moved home to San Diego to pursue her passion for oil painting. Her website simoesbelostudio.com is currently housing the A Living Chance portrait project; you can visit it to see photos of the works in progress. 

Special thanks to:

The staff and members at California Coalition for Women Prisoners for their untiring work and dedication to this cause, Adrienne Skye Roberts for this opportunity and support, Pat Kelly (patkellystudio.com) for her mentorship and expertise, and to everyone reaching out from Chowchilla and CIW women's prisons

story:
nowhere/now-here is a devised piece . The play centers itself around the experience of the immigrant artist , gathering both confessional autobiographical material, and quotations from all sorts of produced material (poetry, plays, songs). The play is mostly, but not only, about identity. 

The framework of the piece plays around the idea of time, dividing it in past, present, and future. The piece in fact was born out of the urgency of a limited time in which the actresses and creators of the piece would be present in US territory, struggling to stay, or wanting to go. 

The piece uses movement, imaginary, audience interaction and multilingualism as narrative devices to recreate the sensations of the world of the artists. 

Location: TheaterLab 

357 WEST 36th Street - 3rd Floor - NEW YORK

Performance Dates & Times: 

July 24th at 8.00pm

July 25th at 8.00pm

July 26th at 3.00pm

Cast: Audrey Ross

Samantha Hoefer

Mouna Rmiki

 Creators: Audrey Ross

Samantha Hoefer

Mouna Rmiki  

Directors: John Gould Rubin, co-director

Kat Yen, co-director



Check us out on: 

http://www.nowhere.nyc

Connect with us on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/nowherecollective

story:
This campaign has a part 2. See here https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/three-kingdoms-miniature-lion-dance-head-part-2/x/10709053#/story

Who are we

Traditional Arts is a registered business in Singapore since 2013 with a mission to preserve the Chinese culture starting with lion dance.

Adrian Chua, the founder of Traditional Arts, has 10 years of entrepreneurial experience.


What we want to achieve

For this project, our goal is to produce miniature size of the traditional Fo Shan lion head measured 6cm x 6cm x 6cm in a set of 3 colours — Yellow, Red, Black. These colours represent the characters from the Three Kingdoms, Liu Bei, Guan Yu, and Zhang Fei respectively.

We have done prototype of the model with 3D printing and the goal is to finalize the product with a smoother surface made with PVC.

The funds raised will be used for the production, packaging, and distribution to you, our backers.

What is lion dance and its meaning

Lion dance is a part of Chinese culture with its origin dated back more than 1500 years ago. It is usually seen in auspicious and festive events such as opening ceremonies and the Chinese New Year. It is believed to chase away the evil, bring good luck, and wealth for the people who invited the lion dance performance. There are mainly 2 broad categories of lion dance, the Northern lion and the Southern lion. We are making the Southern lion, in this project. Southern lion originated from the Guangdong province as Fo Shan lion. This miniature is a Fo Shan lion.

In the early days, the lions were named after the characters of the Three Kingdoms, Liu Bei, Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, commonly know as Liu Guan Zhang, mainly because of the righteousness of these three characters. 


Why are we doing this

With the modernization of today's world, we realized that the children and parents are excessively addicted to mobile devices, and less engaging in hands on activities. We hope to introduce culture to the children, having them interested in understanding culture of their own or others.  Lion dance troupes around the world are finding it harder to attract new students, mainly because the younger generation are not interested in strenuous activities. Through our continuos effort in raising awareness, we hope that today's children will have an opportunity to learn about their roots and passing it on to their next generation.

Thank you for your support in preserving the Chinese culture! Your support is greatly appreciated.


Timeline to delivery

After the project is successfully funded, it will take us 2 months to get the first batch of miniature lions shipped. We really look forward to that and hope you can help us make this come true.

story:
Bridging the Gaps Youth Camps

                            May 21-25, 2015

                          Ahmedabad, India


Less than one month from now 125 teens and 35 coaches from across India will gather in Ahmedabad (Gujarat) for the third edition of Bridging the Gaps, a unique sport-art sleep-away camp designed to teach life skills development to its participants.  We facilitate their bonding as teammates over sport (Ultimate Frisbee*) and art-based personal development activities. During the course of the camp, they overcome barriers, challenge themselves to develop skills and relationships and learn to celebrate the diversity of other's experiences.

Our camp intentionally brings together participants and coaches from various socio-economic, geographic and cultural backgrounds. In fact, the majority of our participants have never traveled outside their communities and would not be able to afford to attend camp without financial aid. 


Why?

In India, we live in a tremendously unequal society. Our mission is to inspire a generation of Indian youth to bridge the socio-economic gaps created by poverty, gender and class, through a uniquely designed sport-art camp.  Our camps build and foster important values such as gender equality and open-mindedness, that translate into impactful benefits to both players and coaches.

Where?
This May's camp will be held in Ahmedabad, the largest city in the western state of Gujarat and home to many of the first Ultimate Frisbee players in India who spread Ultimate as part of Indicorps (a fellowship program based on sustainable development projects with grassroots orgs).    


We’ve done this before....and we'll do it again!

Our first two camps, held in Surat (May 2014) and Auroville (December 2014), each brought together 120 teen campers and 30+ coaches for a 5 day experience of a lifetime!  This May will be our third edition of Bridging the Gaps camp and we'll continue to run camps each year with your help!

Our three tier model - how participants, youth leaders and coaches benefit:

Many of our coaches and youth leaders are from the same communities as our participants. They face a similar uphill climb with regards to poverty, gender and class based discrimination.

Our coaches and youth leaders attend coach training sessions before camp begins. This prepares our coaches and youth leaders to facilitate meaningful discussions, teach the technical Ultimate Frisbee curriculum and conduct team building exercises.


How you can help: 

  • Contribute to our Indiegogo campaign and help us to:
    (a) cover costs of transport/accommodation/meals for participants/coaches;(b) purchase discs, cones, whistles, art supplies and plain t-shirts (for teens to create their own jerseys!)
  • Spread the word
  • Help us get in touch with other sponsors


*Why Ultimate Frisbee:

For this camp, we have chosen to use Ultimate Frisbee because of how well it lends itself to promote personal development and intercultural exchange.

Ultimate is unique and best suited for Bridging the Gaps because it is:

  • Co-ed & non-contact:  Boys and girls play together on a team - an aberration to cultural practices within Indian communities where boys and girls rarely mix in sport.

  • Self refereed:  Contested fouls are settled through discussion between the players involved. This facilitates open communication between players and teaches participants how to resolve conflict. It is rare for a sport to allow for this type of player-to-player dialogue.

  • Spirit Circles:  Unique to Ultimate Frisbee, Spirit Circles have players of both teams sit in a large circle post-match to discuss the level of sportsmanship during the match.


Meet the organizers:

Liz Haynes

Combining her passion for sports and expertise in nonprofit and corporate finance, Liz works with a sports-based after school program for underprivileged teens in Chennai, India as well as organizes Bridging the Gaps, India's first ever youth sleep-away Ultimate Frisbee camp. 

Mahesh Ramamurty

Mahesh is the Joint Managing Director at Vibromech. He is passionate about building educational opportunities for underprivileged youth in India and has held leadership positions in several projects channeling corporate expertise and funds for community development.

Sangeeta Isvaran

Sangeeta is a dancer-performer who has developed the Wind Dancer technique -  building programs in marginalized, underprivileged communities using the arts in education, empowerment and conflict resolution across 40 countries.

Manix Narayanan

Manix serves on the advisory board of UPAI (Ultimate Players Association of India). He is an avid Ultimate Frisbee player, creating sports for development programmes and helping grow the sport across India.

story:
We want to cover the costs for Everyone is going to dance!

We are so excited to offer you the 3rd International Al-Dunya Dance Festival on June 27th-28th 2015.
The 3rd Al Dunya Festival is supporting international guests teachers and performers but there are many other artists going to be part because they believe in the Art of Oriental Dance. It normally happens in every festival! Ok, we understand amateurs can perform just for the fun and experience of the stage, but not the professionals!

They are also worldwide wining artists with an amazing CV and we think they deserve to be fairly compensated for their performance or to have the travel costs covered. 

The festival has been built and sponsored by Isis Zahara Belly Dance Studio and the number of admires and participants grows each year. What is great!

But considering we are also artists we can’t afford to cover the costs for all the other professionals who are coming to our fringe and WE THINK IT IS NOT FAIR!

Every professional deserves to get payed for their performance or unless to have their travel costs covered.

How you can help:

- Buying one of our products this money will go directly to cover the artist expenses (travel costs, show cash).


Respect the creative profession

Your help will contribute to a new age for the Artist life. An Era where opening acts can be fairly compensated for their time, their labor and their talents.Make possible their living as a creative professional!

Your support is also crucial to the growth of the Oriental Dance as a Community!

WE TRULY CANNOT DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

Your suport is an essential element in maintaining the artist’s high level of innovation, in promote the network of other professionals nationally and internationally and to provide the work with the best talents in the world.

If you want to help your teacher, your friend  or a group you support - please let us know who you want to sponsor.  Your money will go directly to cover  their costs!

IF YOU CAN'T BUY

- please kindly spread the word to any friends or family to let them know about our campaign! Tweet it, post to Facebook, email your friends – whatever you can do to let them know!
As always, thank you for your ongoing support!

story:
- Who We Are -

The Paper Statement is an online marketplace that allows creators to sell and buy their handcrafted art; such as photographs, drawings, doodles and graphics. We want to encourage and empower all artists regardless of experience and skill to pursue their passion and make a profit while doing so. We believe in the abundant talent that can be found, whether its a doodle on a napkin corner or an old vacation photo, and want to help share these talents with world. 

The Paper Statements goal is to help cultivate and inspire current and future artists; as well as millions of new art fanatics.  The Paper Statement is helping prove that art is everything but boring and that a comprehensive cross section of artists from all walks of life can provide an eclectic ecosystem creating something to match every taste.  Whether you're looking for a piece to compliment your living room or decor for you're next birthday party, The Paper Statement has it all.


- How It Works -


- See It In Action -


- What We Create -


- What We Need -

We are building a unique platform for our creators to easily submit their designs for profit, this takes a lot of coding and programing--and that costs money. Our self taught web developer has been doing amazing things but talent and skills are limited, and we need the help of professionals. Every dollar collected will go directly into building a powerful online marketplace for our creators. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can provide nothing else, please help by spreading the word! We are relying on crowd-sourced creativity and there is no art without any artists! Visit www.paperstatement.com and sign up to become a member. Becoming an early member of The Paper Statement will allow you to have access to special sales and promotions, be one of the first to submit your designs and test the site before it goes live.

story:
I knew for certain that I wanted to do an exposition in 2015.  Though my last one-day solo show, “Kobiphysics,” had been a success, it has been over three years ago since I’ve presented a solo show.  Since then I’ve been able to exhibit in my work in London, New York, Thailand, Suriname, Slovenia and Amsterdam.  That was all so very lovely, and the experiences have changed my life… and I’ve evolved…

This year’s show is titled STATIC! and was initially inspired by the life of Fred Hampton and his assassination by the FBI.  The scope of inspiration broadened however, to incorporate the tense fight for change and the authoritative abuse of power and police brutality.  It's important to have this loud artistic conversation about it.


About Fred Hampton 

He was born on August 30, 1948 and was chairman of the Illinois chapter of the BPP, and deputy chairman of the national BPP. He was murdered while sleeping at his apartment during a raid by a tactical unit of the Cook County's State's Attorney's Office, in conjunction with the Chicago Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).  Hampton died, December 4, 1969.  He was 21 years old. 

This year I’m soliciting your help to make the event an even greater success and shine a pin light on the issue of human struggle.  I’d like to exhibit 15-20 new works this August in Orange County, California.  I'm working diligently on all the details to make the show as heavy and relevant as the issue.

I need your help.


What We Need & What You Get


Here is a rough estimate of the cost:
Display easels - I'm going to need about  15 display easels for STATIC!  and if I am able to get them around $20 each, then without factoring shipping costs, I will spend around $300 on these.
Room rental - I've been searching high and low to get the most inexpensive but efficient room for the event.  For this I've budgeted $500.
Food and drink - The budget is  around $200.
Printing and Framing - This is the biggest part of the budget.  As the work is still being created, I can only give a rough estimate based upon past experiences.  Allowing for a little wiggle room, the budget for the actual art work is around $1,000.
Marketing and incentive gifts - Because I LOVE my contributors and we have to make certain that the word gets out, the budget for these two areas total $500.
 But I need your help...

Here are the contribution incentives:


  • $1  - Thank you email – because I appreciate your contribution and every little bit helps.
  • $5  -  STATIC! Postcard that embodies the spirit of the event
  • $10 - One 8” x 10” print of the STATIC! pre crowd funding launch flyer

  • $25 - One STATIC! writing pen, to remind you of the event each time you sign your name
  • $50 -  STATIC! writing pen and art book. The book is a sample representation of retrospective work.
  • $75  - Poster print and writing pen.  This includes a 24” x 36” advertisement poster of the event.
  • S100 - 24”x 36” poster and art book.
  • $200  - One 8” x 10” print of the featured work titled “Hampton” matted and framed.
  • $300  - One unframed 20” x 24” print of the work titled “Young Mr. Little.”
  • $500  - An original work from the Sacrifice 38 series (chosen by contributor)
  • $800  - One art print from STATIC! series from the actual show.
  • $1000 -  Original work of choice; STATIC! writing pen; art book; 24” x 36” poster and special invitations.  The special invitations include exclusive showings.


The Impact

The organization for STATIC! has been in the works since late January, when I reached out to family and friends requesting their support.  The goal this year was to plan far enough in advance to pull off a show that, looking back, will be considered historical – just as the subject matter my work itself addresses. 

In April 2012, “Kobiphysics: An Art Show” was also held at the Huntington Beach Library in Huntington Beach California.  Though a crowd funding financial goal had not been met at that time, the event proved still to be a success and one of the paintings from the show titled “Newton’s Attraction” sold for $500. 




Risks & Challenges

This is a one day art exposition, and I’m throwing eight months of working morning to night into one day – but this does not guarantee success.  I understand also that showing work with provocative themes in Orange County, a very conservative area, places me at risk of having a lower than desired turnout.  Fortunately I have a few elements on my side.

  • I was born and (for the most part) raised in OC and have access to a rich spring of supporters in the community.
  • I’ve already show my work in 2012 (Kobiphysics).
  • I’ve not only used letters and email from friends and family to garner support, but I’ve regularly distributed press releases to other media outlets.
  • WE DID STATIC! WAVE!!  (If you happen not to know what STATIC! Wave is, feel free to Google it)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, there are other ways you can help: 

- Spread the word about the campaign

- Spread the word about the show

- Attend the show in August


THANKS!!!

Please help to make this show happen!

story:
Beschreibung

Wir, 15 junge Künstler_innen, haben in diesem Jahr die Chance, im L.A. Satelite Space ( http://satellitespace.biz/Satellite_Space/main.html ) eine Ausstellung zu realisieren.

Wir sind Studierende und reisen in diesem Herbst unter der Leitung der international bekannten New Yorker Video- und Performancekünstlerin Shana Moulton ( http://www.shanamoulton.info ) zu einem künstlerischen Austausch in die USA.
Zuvor stellte unsere Künstlergruppe, die sich auf Performancekunst und Videoarbeiten spezialisiert hat, unter anderem beim Internationalen FrauenFilmFestival in Dortmund aus ( http://www.frauenfilmfestival.eu/index.php?id=2319&L=0 ) und sind nun voller Tatendrang unsere Arbeit weiterzuführen. Nach einigen Überlegungen, was wir gerne in den USA präsentieren wollen, kamen wir auf die Thematisierung der "Squeezed Identity" (Hiermit ist letztendlich unsere digitale Präsenz gemeint, welche unsere Realität in veränderter und gekürzter Weise darstellt). Letztendlich führten unsere Überlegungen zu dem Handeln des "Quetschen" selbst. 
Das Quetschen ist eine Forschungstechnik, die es uns erlaubt, einen Einblick in das Innenleben des Ausgequetschten zu werfen und es somit von Innen nach Außen zu dekonstruieren. Wir wollen mit dieser Technik verschiedenste Themen in Erfahrung bringen und visualisieren. Die Themen reichen von der Analyse eines einfachen Gegenstandes, wie einer Banane bis hin zur Hinterfragung des Inhalts der Realität. Mit Ihrer Unterstützung wird es uns ermöglicht in unserer künstlerischen Forschung weiter Voranzuschreiten und unsere Ergebnisse der amerikanischen Öffentlichkeit zu präsentieren. Zusätzlich unterstützen Sie einen künstlerischen Austausch auf internationaler Ebene.

Jede Unterstützung hilft uns weiter - auch das Teilen der Kampagne.

Wir danken Ihnen für Ihr Interesse und Ihre Hilfe!

-

Description

We are 15 young artists. We have the opportunity to realize an exhibition in the  L.A. Satelite Space this year ( http://satellitespace.biz/Satellite_Space/main.html ).


We are german art students ( http://www.klassemoulton.de ) and going to travel to the USA under the leading of the international known video- und performance artist Shana Moulton who is living in New York and teaching in Germany ( http://www.shanamoulton.info ).

Our art group, which is specialized in Performance and Video Art had already exhibitions, for example at the international FrauenFilmFestival in Dortmund ( http://www.frauenfilmfestival.eu/index.php?id=2319&L=0 ). We are now motivated to present our artworks in the USA. After some mind mapping we made the "Squeezed identity" as a subject of our discussions (This means the our digital presence, which shows our reality in a shortened and changed way). Finally our reflections ended by the "squeezing" as an action.

The squeezing is a research technique, which allows us an inside view in the "squeezed things" so that we can deconstruct it from the inside to the outside. By using this technique we would like to gain new experiences and visualize them. The topics range from the analyzation of a simple object, like a banana, to the critical review of the content of the reality. Your support allows us to continue our artistic research and to present it in the USA. Additionally you are supporting an artistic exchange on an international level.

Every support is helping us - even sharing our campaign!

We thank you for your interest and your help.

story:
Short Summary

Esther's Follies has been in the business of entertaining audiences for over 37 years. With satirical humor that takes on both sides of the political divide, pop culture, and Texas itself, plus large-scale magical illusions, Esther's stands in a class by itself.

The city of Austin is growing and evolving at a dizzying pace, welcoming hundreds of new Austinites a month, as well as thousands of visitors, and each and every one of them deserves to know the history and legacy of Esther's! That's why the time is right for a colorful, coffee-table book.  Our team, is sending a proposal to UT Press for publication.


What We Need & What You Get

Our team needs to secure funds to cover the time needed for research and to gather archival documents--an enormous amount of archival photos and video footage must be sorted through—and, of course, to pay author Jesse Sublett, who will be interviewing Esther's performers both past and present, politicians, and notable Austinites who were/are part of the evolution and growth of Austin's favorite comedy club.

  • At this time we are looking to raise $30,000
  • By donating to this campaign you know you have funded a part of Austin's rich history.
  • The funds will be instrumental in getting this project off the ground.

The Impact

This campaign will underscore the impact Esther's has had on Austin and vice versa. As Esther's founder Shannon Sedwick says, "Esther's wouldn't be Esther's without the support from this vibrant city."

  • The history and stories of early Austin are an important bridge from Old Austin to New Austin.
  • Esther's succeeds because they love what they do and the community loves them right back. The laughter and memories they have brought to generations of fans cannot be measured, but by distilling that joy in a single book, we hope to share some of that joy with an even wider audience and to preserve their legacy for the future

Risks & Challenges

We do believe the proposal is a great fit for UT Press--however, if they choose not to publish our manuscript, we fully intend to self-publish.

  • Stephanie Chastain, Esther's Director of Communications, has successfully created strategic marketing partnerships between Esther's Follies and the Austin Tourism Bureau as well as Capital Metro and the Austin History Center. She has excellent communication and community outreach skills and will be in charge with writing a winning proposal.
  • Self-publishing as another option has gained much traction and we have several reputable companies secured, should we need to take that route.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute but if you want to help this campaign, please share it on your social media. Don't forget, it's super easy if you use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Here's the short version:

I've been dyeing spectacular cotton fabrics for over a decade, for quilts and fabric art. 

  • More artists are clamoring for my fabrics.
  • The current studio is cramped, and weather dictates my dye schedule.
  • The equipment needs an upgrade and the roof leaks heavily.

The temporary problems are easily solved with a more permanent solution!

What We Need & What You Get

How your generosity is going to help:

  • First, we will secure indoor space without the need for acceptable weather, enabling year round dyeing.
  • Next, we will upgrade our washer to a more efficient model.
  • Finally, we will acquire a rotary press to enable us to deliver the best quality product, faster, and with an even more spectacular finish.
  • In exchange for your generous support, we have a wide variety of perks, some of which have never been offered previously, and others which are offered at a substantially great value.
  • Take a look at the many perks!

  • Spectrum and Shadow Quilt

  • Spectrum and Shadow close up

  • Giovanni Quilt

    Giovanni detail

  • Skull Quilt

  • Cosmopolitan Quilt

    Pop art quilt portrait


  •                             And, of course, our glorious hand dyed fabrics!


The Impact of Your Support

Full Frontal Quilts and Dyeworks has been providing goods and services to quilters and fabric artists in all 50 states and 3 countries:

  • Our recent equipment upgrade to an APQS Freedom longarm machine made it financially impossible to upgrade the dye studio before it became necessary, but it has enabled us to take on more quilt finishing jobs, so while we're well on track to reach the goal, it didn't come fast enough to meet the demand for the fabric side of the business.
  • A new studio space and equipment will allow for a steady and reliable dye schedule, and a much shorter wait time for restock requests.
  • Blank fabric is in stock now and ready to dye, and your help is going to allow those bolts to fulfill their fabric destiny.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are plenty of ways to help, from zero budget to unlimited:

  • Share this campaign with your friends, family, and social contacts, and help get the word out. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Starting from Scratch 

Hi! I'm Jessie Nilo.... I love art, artists, and God.

Eleven years ago there was no visual art at my church, so I launched a visual art ministry. People were skeptical. When we first started, we had:

No art studio... so we used the lobby, the chapel, the lawn, the classrooms...
No artists on staff... I volunteered 5 hours a week.
No art budget... people gave donations.

I've led this amazing, fun, and spiritually deep art ministry at my church for 11 years (we have a studio now!) and the number of lives I've seen impacted is unbelievable-- in the hundreds! And I've helped many other churches create art ministries and art environments of their own.

A Different Kind of Model 

I long for artists all over the world to be loved and welcomed into their own church communities. That's a big deal, and sadly neglected in most churches. The flip side is that most churches have a huge, gaping hole where their artistic side should be. Churches need artists to show them how art can help their congregations grow spiritually.  

That's why I'm launching Art Fruition.com -- to help churches love artists, and to help artists love the local church, wherever God calls them. My model centers on Christ and emphasizes "everyone gets to play" (there are places for all levels to participate). 

Art Fruition will be completely online, so people around the world will engage right where they live, applying what they're learning in their own creative communities!

What I Have 

  • 11 years running an art ministry with a team of 20 artists
  • 8 years teaching visual art for the city
  • 3 years teaching visual art curriculum in private art high schools
  • 2 BFAs (Illustration and Graphic Design)
  • 50+ art ministry videos on my YouTube channel since 2009
  • a jillion art topics to teach on and piles of Moleskine journals filled with ministry stories, drawings, courage, and God-insights to share
  • the Art Fruition team and faculty
  • an awesome curriculum ready to train future art ministers

What We Need 

A few months ago my Canon camera and Mac laptop were stolen downtown. Undaunted, I took out a loan and bought another camera and laptop to make art lessons. My insurance didn't cover the theft.

Our most immediate expenses are:

  • Replacement camera $1000
  • Replacement laptop $2500
  • Recording and editing gear $1000
  • Online learning platform $1000
  • Business, internet, administrative costs $2000
  • Art faculty and contributors $3500
  • Books and supplies $1000
         -------------------------
      Total:  Twelve thousand smackers. And if we get more, we can give scholarships!

What You Get

A terrific feeling knowing God is on the move, as well as beautiful artwork of your choice! To see the art perks, keep scrolling down to the end of our story. Thanks for contributing! 

But whether or not you contribute financially: Please enjoy this FREE 25-minute art lesson on "plein air drawing & painting" outdoors. You could say it's about finding freedom in mistakes. Watch full-screen if you like, and share with ANYONE who needs a bit of creative courage.


The Impact of This Art School

Movements begin small. But this one is growing quickly. I want to train people so churches can do this thing responsibly. Many hearts are at stake.

By contributing, YOU will:

  • help regular folks discover creativity, 
  • introduce artists around the globe to a God who loves them, and
  • teach churches TONS of practical ways to embrace beauty with wide-open inclusiveness and breathtaking excellence. Yes, it can be done.

Bonus: In our Indiegogo "Updates" tab, I'll post each time a new student enrolls in Art Fruition! :) 

A Humble Stretch Goal

I've made many personal sacrifices to keep Art Fruition VERY low-cost and accessible, knowing that many artists struggle financially. I'd love to provide partial SCHOLARSHIPS for low-income artists, especially artists who live in low-income countries, if you want to help with that!

Risks & Challenges

Keeping my gear updated and running without getting stolen. I carry extra vigilance and insurance now.

Making video lessons will be challenging. But I made 52 videos on YouTube without knowing if I had an audience. A New Zealand art minister contacted me after watching through every one of my videos, and she urged me to PLEASE. KEEP. MAKING. VIDEOS.  How could I not?

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with the world!!! There are many lonely artists and broken people out there who need to discover beauty in the name of Love.

-

Images for Perks in Sidebar:

No art studio... so we used the lobby, the chapel, the lawn, the classrooms...No artists on staff... I volunteered 5 hours a week.No art budget... people gave donations.

story:
My name is Alan and I am a student at Hot Rod Institute. I am a retired US Army Soldier who was wounded in combat while fighting our enemy in Afghanistan. When I was in the Hospital in Bagram, I was in a bed across from a young Soldier who lost his leg. We didn't speak, but it left a mark on me. That kid was in a bad place. To say he was having a bad day is a horrendous understatement. I just wish I could go back in time to take some of the load off his shoulders. I am hoping by building this car it will do that for a fellow combat veteran. I hope that perhaps hot rodding will help him or her as it has helped me. When I turn a wrench or hear the rumble of that big V8, I forget about my troubles. Maybe it will help this Soldier. Maybe it will make his/her pain go away too - if only for a little while. If you are reading this I hope you don't know what that means. I hope it is only empathy that helps you understand this pain. I know. I feel it everyday. Help me do this for a Soldier. I can't do it alone.
Here's what I have. I have fellow students (mostly vets, but some who aren't ) who will dedicate their time to build the car. I have the body (1927 Model T coupe). It is being paid for with my first CRSC (Combat Related Special Compensation ) check. I have the engine (Ford 400 Cu In) and the Trans (C6). I have an 8.8 Ford rear end. I can't afford to buy more. I need the funds to finish the build.
I am working with a wounded warrior program to identify the Soldier who best fits this build.
What you'll get: Your name on the car, an invitation to the presentation and for large donations - a desk trophy using the pistons/connecting rods from the 400. (We will be rebuilding it completely). Large donors will also get a ride in the car during shakedown /test drives (you must get here on your own)
Thank you very much for your time and consideration.

Alan Scarlett 

For further information and/or to make sure this is NOT a scam, please contact Doug  LaRue,  President of Hot Rod Institute 

School: (605)342-1195

Cell: (605) 415-8340

Email : Doug@HotRod.edu 

PO Box 1456 Rapid City SD 57709 (for Mail only)

Physical address:

2402 N. Maple Ave Rapid City SD 57701

Www.HotRod.edu

story:
Short Summary

Remember that scholarship and artistic boost that Mount Gretna School of Art provided students in the inaugural summer of 2013?

Now the school needs your help to purchase its first artist cottage.

What We Need

Here's the details:

  • We need the "class of 2013" to raise more than $500 to help reach our goal to purchase and renovate a cottage in Mount Gretna.
  • Every donation will be matched dollar for dollar by a challenge grant. So if we raise $500 then it gets doubled by the grant to $1000!!! If we raise more than that the dollar for dollar match continues up to $150,000 (just in case and we're not kidding)!
  • If we don't reach our goal we run the risk of being unable to secure housing next year and thereby jeopardizing the program.  Show the greater community of Mount Gretna how much you valued your experience at MGSoA with a donation.

The Impact

Your contribution will:

  • help stabilize housing which has been increasingly difficult and unstable to secure, putting the program in jeopardy.
  • place a foundation under the intensive program that has skyrocketed in reputation, attracting more and more applicants every year and recognition nationwide.
  • motivate other supporters of the school to give even more. It will have a big impact for supporters to see former students pitching in.
  • activate a dollar for dollar challenge match from a foundation grant.  If the "class of 2013" can raise $500, for example, it will be matched by the foundation dollar to dollar having a $1000 overall impact with the match!

Risks & Challenges

We need to act quickly as we have only until August 31st to reach our goal.

  • We already have the BIG donor.  All we need now is for lots of other donors to pitch in their fair share.
  • If everyone in the class of 2013 gives $25, $50 or $100 then we'll meet our goal EASY.
  • Donations large and small are helping.  It all adds up (especially with that matching grant)!

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to know how to help even more?:

  • Ask friends and family to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Remind them about the support you received from MGSoA and the impact the intensive program has had!

That's all there is to it.

story:
The Activists

The Abolition Movement is an activist group based at the S.H.A.P.E. Community Center in Houston. We fight, educate, and organize for the end of capital punishment. We are primarily friends and family members of those on death row.

The March

Each October since 2000, people from all walks of life and all parts of Texas, the U.S. and other countries have taken a day out of their year and gathered in Austin to raise their voices together and loudly express their opposition to the death penalty. The march is a coming together of activists, family members of people on death row, community leaders, exonerated former death row prisoners and all those calling for repeal of the Texas death penalty.

The annual march is organized as a joint project by several Texas anti-death penalty organizations and their allies: Texas Moratorium Network, the Austin chapter of the Campaign to End the Death Penalty, the Texas Death Penalty Abolition Movement, Texas Students Against the Death Penalty, Witness to Innocence, Kids Against the Death Penalty, the Journey of Hope ... from Violence to Healing, and Texas Democrats Against the Death Penalty.

On Saturday October 24th, after a short pre-march speaker's program beginning at 2:00 pm, we will march through the streets of downtown Austin with a stop in front of the Texas Governor's mansion and return to the Texas Capitol to hear more speakers against the death penalty.

Why We Need Your Donation

Every year dozens of activists from Houston travel the 3 hours to the Capitol to participate in this march. The Abolition Movement does our best to raise money to provide a bus for many of these participants to travel together, but as we are entirely community funded, we need support to afford this goal! We believe that we will need $1,500 to charter our bus this year. Will you help us by giving 5, 10, 25 or 50 dollars?

story:
Back Story

Hi, my name is zen Sutherland and for the last 8 months I have been on a quirky little mission to create hand-painted oval magnets and put them on random cars - mostly in the Asheville, NC area, but wherever I travel.  Each one is a little art oval created with love and placed around town on vehicles and anything they'll stick to - for people to find and share if they want. I do not sell them and I encourage people to swap them or take them for their own. They will never be sold, only randomly given (and as perks here). The art project itself has been featured in the news-site Ashvegas and in the book "Only In Asheville."


It’s all about play. Using spray paint, stencils, rollers and pens, I create little works of art on 4x6” oval magnets. Each is mostly unique in color, composition and design, though some have been similar as I explore images and abstracts that I like and play with.


Each handmade ROMP has a sticker on the back with the address of the Facebook website where people can share photos of found (and lost) and a QR code with the same information. It's kind of a secret community - or maybe it's not-so-secret group as some parents have said that their kids watch for them on the backs of cars and call them out when they see one.


What I Hope to Create

I’ve already spend a good deal of money putting out some 400-500 random magnets in the Asheville area, and now need to bump up production to at least 1000. At this quantity I can get blank magnets at the most reasonable bulk rate. So the money will go to buy the blank oval magnets, spray paint, markers, blades and template material that I’m almost out of.  I’ve been using the cheapest spray paint I could find, but want to upgrade to decent low-pressure, quick drying paint that will not only help the ROMPs last longer, but will allow me to ramp up output.

I’d also like to create a decent ROMP website.  While the Facebook page has been helpful in getting the word out there about this, but I long for a larger community that can post their own photos of ROMPs seen and on the places people decide to put them.

Just as importantly, I would like YOUR involvement. Many of the perks include extra hand-made ROMP magnets to put on random cars in your area – this is what I hope for most – that people will get to swapping magnets and borrowing them on this ever-moving motorized canvas.

I even put many on the back of my car (above) and encourage people to take one.

Even if you decide that contributing to this crazy project isn’t for you, please watch the progress on the ROMP Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/ROMPasheville and share this campaign with friends, family and arty-types to get people involved.

Thanks so much for reading this far. Please contribute if you can or share the love and links if you feel so inclined.

story:
1000 masks in remembrance and hope...


My name is Hilary, I am an American artist originally from California. I have been living in Southern Sicily for the past 9 years. During this time I have witnessed the increasing crisis of refugees stranded on overcrowded boats trying to find sanctuary on our shores. In 2013 there was a terrible tragedy off the Island of Lampedusa, with the loss of over 300 lives in sight of land. Some of those people are buried in the town where I live: Cianciana. Last year I finished a small project composed of 10 masks, commemorating the nameless victims. I am a migrant myself, although my journey to Sicily was far less harrowing. We feel a personal connection to people seeking either through choice or need a new existence. We are all each other in some way.  A Sea of Humanity


THE FIRST 26. . . .The masks will represent the many nameless victims of these journeys, you can lend your name.

These are the first 16 masks, I have created.  IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN A SPECIFIC MASK, THAT IS FINE. JUST REMEMBER THAT THEY ARE PART OF A LARGER PROJECT AND WILL NOT BE DELIVERED UNTIL AFTER THE EXHIBITION. 20% OF EACH PURCHASE WILL BE DONATED TO MEDICI SENZA FRONTIERI (DOCTORS WITHOUT BORDERS).  GRAZIE!


Number 1 - claimed

Number 2 - claimed

Number 3 - claimed

Number 4

Number 5

Number 6 - claimed

Number 7

Number 8

Number 9

Number 10 - claimed

Number 11

Number 12

Number 13

Number 14

Number 15

Number 16

Number 17

Number 18

Number 19

Number 20

Number 21

Number 22

Number 23

Number 24

Number 25

Number 26

974 to go ....

1000 Masks

Why this particular art piece?

I would like to create 1000 masks, to be displayed here at Passareddu Artist Residency as a sea of faces. An installation titled "Sea of Humanity" I have been  planning  this piece for the last year, bending the ear of anyone I could get to listen. It is an extension of a small piece completed last summer, composed of 10 masks. We have the ideal setting for the installation.  Passareddu is constructed of second hand shipping containers, my vision is to install the masks at head height and above, as well as along the ground like waves, both inside and outside of the container, to mimic the journey and the sea. Visitors can then walk 'into' the sea and into the voyage.

What you receive

An individual work of art

To produce a thousand individual hand made plaster masks, is definitely an undertaking. It is very close to my heart, I plan to complete them by September 2016. Inspired by the idea of selling the ceramic poppies from the Tower of London. I will be selling each mask, which will be numbered and signed. Masks will be allocated on first come first serve system. The price of each mask is 50 euros: 40 for materials and creation, while 10 euros will be put aside for a  donation to Medici Senza Frontiere. Each mask is individual. Be assured that they will all be lovingly created, able to be hung on a wall, the color scheme as shown in these photographs: colors of the sea. The masks will represent the many nameless victims of these journeys, you can lend your name. Each mask will be tagged with the first name of the buyer for the exhibition.

I will be posting groups of completed masks  in the update section, so you can all follow my progress and be confident the project will be on time and successful.

I AM DOING THIS PROJECT IN 10 PARTS. 100 MASKS BEING PRODUCED IN EACH STEP. EVERY LAUNCH WILL INCLUDE IMAGES OF THE NEWEST MASKS.  IF REQUESTS EXCEED THE SET GOAL, OF COURSE I'LL MAKE MORE AS THAT WILL HELP SURPASS THE EXHIBITION GOAL OF 1000.

The Impact

The news is filled with  negative and fear inspiring bias concerning the movement of people. Whether from war torn or impoverished countries, I think we have a common humanity that obliges us to assist each other where and when we can.

Art can be a profound and personal way to share our opinions and visions, and to understand more about our relationships as fellow human beings. I hope this Sea of Humanity piece will promote discussion about more positive and humanitarian solutions. I am also raising money for Medici Senza Frontiere (Medicins Sans Frontiere), which has consistently been on the front line of humanitarian disasters, offering the most necessary and humane assistance.  Note: I am in no way connected to or funded by this charity, it is just the group that speaks to me most profoundly.

The exhibition will take place here in Cianciana at Passareddu Artist Residency.
We formed Passareddu last year, as place for art exhibitions, cultural exchange and local and visiting events. It is constructed from second hand shipping containers, pallets and love. Passareddu has hosted numerous successful events during it's inaugural year, and is the ideal setting for this project.

The Challenge

The primary challenge is the individual creation of so many masks by next summer.  It is a challenge worthy of our combined efforts, and exactly the kind of spirit and cooperation I hope to inspire with the completed project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even small amounts can help this project become a reality. If you're not interested in having a mask, I appreciate your support. Spread the word, share the project. One woman, One year and 1000 masks. 

Thank You - Grazie! -Hilary
