I am so blessed to already have an amazing following of people who love and support me and what I do so I can't wait to see what's all this has in store for me next. I plan to pay if forward and make sure that I do all I can to help others who also want to fight and not give up on their dreams.

story:
The Liberace Museum Collection is on the move

Elton John, Michael Jackson, Lady Gaga.  The top recording artists of the past 40 years credit Liberace as inspiration, catalyst,  Mr. Showmanship.  His name is mentioned over 3 million times on the internet.  "Liberace" is named in the lyrics of well over 1,000 songs spanning 60 years, across all genres. 

The Foundation started by Liberace himself in 1976 closed its famed museum five years ago, citing top-heavy expenses  and an outdated and outmoded facility.  In the past two years, new leadership has taken over and brought the Liberace brand back to a position of prominence in society and pop culture.

The Liberace Museum Collection has contributed to film, stage and other museum productions with unprecedented success.  A multi-million dollar Liberace show in hologram, licensed by the Liberace Foundation and in production, has been in the national press

A massive restructuring since 2013 put the organization on much more solid financial and policy footing.  In the mean time, the Liberace Museum Collection has grown larger by more acquisitions of artifacts, and is now so vast it has never been seen at any one location, ever.


A MAJOR PRIVATE LIBERACE EXHIBIT

Now, a major donor has contributed an extraordinary facility to store much of the Liberace Museum Collection, and to house an exhibit more elaborate than any ever previously offered.   It will include the most famous stage costumes, jewelry, pianos of both the stage and rare antique types, mansion furnishings, fine art, fine china, crystal, chandeliers, candelabras, historic original documents, awards, correspondence, photos and more, all orchestrated by Liberace Foundation archivists in a private tour de force of the 6-decade career of Liberace. Special invited guests of the Liberace Foundation, including Foundation members, exhibit venue owners, brand licensee candidates, and contributors to this campaign will be invited by the property owner to tour the exhibit, in support of the Foundation. The exhibit will not be open to the general public.


THE FRIEND YOU MAY NOT KNOW

As were many other entertainers, Michael Jackson was a friend of Liberace's.  The influence of the King of Bling on the King of Pop is apparent in the costuming and showmanship techniques of Michael Jackson beginning in the late 1980's.  This will be apparent in the photos from the era, within the exhibit.


THE VENUE

Now, the most extraordinary of Liberace Museum Collection exhibits is being constructed in the massive, mysterious Subterranean Artists Vault at Thriller Villa, the former Las Vegas home of Michael Jackson.  This is the underground keep where Jackson kept his legendary billion-dollar art collection, until his death in 2009.



Why the Liberace Foundation is a great investment, and how we feel we've earned it

WHAT EXACTLY IS THE MONEY FOR?

We are NOT asking you for money to pay ourselves.  We are NOT seeking funds to spend in salaries or overhead.  These funds will be invested directly in development of the exhibit, completed at deep discounts, due in part to the donation of significant amounts of time by our renowned designers, and the donations of many thousands of dollars in rent by the owner of Thriller Villa.  Exhibiting here will not only cut our expenses by eliminating storage rent, it will also provide a spectacular and private venue for VIP supporters, brand licensees, Foundation members and other supporters to see the collection in all its glory, in private visits.  The intention is to bring about more public exhibitions by inviting key decision makers and financial supporters of the Foundation to experience the Collection first hand.  Donations paid by viewers will also support this initiative.

WHAT IS THE CONDITION OF THE FOUNDATION?

Since February 2014, the Liberace Foundation has emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy virtually debt free, while re-structuring its business model to reduce its overhead by over $250,000 annually, to an all-time low of under $50,000 per year.  At the same time, we have increased our income by over $120,000 through sponsored exhibits and brand licensing.  While we were at it, we have exploded our online and interactive presence, and flooded across the pages of the national press.

Now, the Foundation is in the enviable position of having

  • NO RENT - This venue will not cost us any rent whatsoever, and will house the bulk of the Liberace Museum Collection
  • NO SALARIES - Our Board is now unpaid, and our staff is hourly
  • NO DEBT - We have eliminated virtually all long-term debt
  • GREATER EXPERTISE - Rather than one or two curators on staff, we now three trained archivists who are recent graduates of UNLV, plus a business graduate, all augmented by a stable of world-renowned curators, archivists, historians and veterans of Liberace's own show, serving as volunteers and directing exhibits, as members of our Advisory Board
  • OPTIMUM LOCATION - The new exhibit is scheduled to occupy the space for the next year, where it will enjoy perfect temperature conditions and the best in security, while providing a private environment for high-profile or celebrity supporters to visit without concern.
  • NEW PRODUCTIONS AND BRAND LICENSING - The venue allows the perfect opportunity to invite show production and brand licensing partners to continue our expansions in those and other markets.

WHAT IS YOUR BUSINESS MODEL?

Our business model is to continue to utlize the Liberace Collections and brand licensing to generate all operating income.  We will seek funds from donors only for our scholarship endowment fund (never to be spent on overhead or expenses), and for specific, defined projects such as this.  In short, this Foundation has tremendous earning power which your contribution will help us to permanently establish for the benefit of students of the performing and creative arts. Everything is in place.  Its your turn to take the stage.

With your help, we will remain debt free.  The income generated by donations will continue the scholarships and grants program which have placed over $6 million in the hands of students of the performing and creative arts, at over 100 universities, over the past 30 years.

  • Take a look at our video which includes a peek at the level of care provided by the archivists of the Liberace Museum Collection
  • The perks we have arranged are completely unique.  They include the last runs of items never again to be licensed or sold by the Foundation or museum gift shops.  These are truly collectors items.  Substantial donors will also enjoy naming opportunities for certain exhibit rooms during this exhibition, and ability to utilize Thriller Villa for your own events.  We have put significant thought and effort into the perks to make them of  sort that money alone truly cannot buy.


Your Impact Assured

Donations and event sales at this exhibit will support the Foundation and its missions as defined by Liberace himself.  Your generosity secures our existing earning power so that it can provide scholarships, grants and performance venues for students of the creative and performing arts.  

Remember:

  • We are a virtually debt-free foundation with no salaried employees and no rent overhead at this, our largest location
  • Funds raised will not be spent on overhead such as rent or salaries
  • Funds management by Nevada Trust Company
  • Brand management legal is handled by Brownstein Hyatt
  • Public relations by Vox Solid
RECENT PRESS

“Still Sparkling:  What’s Next for Liberace’s Diamond-Studded Legacy?”  by Kristen Peterson, The Las Vegas Weekly, July 24, 2014

“Liberace Jewels on Display”  FOX 5 Las Vegas, June 27, 2014

“Liberace Museum Back From The Dead?” by Outtraveler Editors, Out Traveler Magazine, June 26, 2014

“Liberace’s Legendary Car Collection May Soon Come Out of the Closet” by Neal Broverman, Los Angeles Magazine, June 23, 2014

“Liberace is going back on tour…as a hologram“ – Forbes.com, Jan. 18, 2015

“Hologram-like Liberace to appear in Las Vegas Show” – Hollywood Reporter, Dec. 18, 2014

“Liberace hologram to tour world“ – Rolling Stone, Dec. 19, 2014

“Restoration Neon” produced by Matt Christensen, PBS Las Vegas, October 27, 2014


Please share this campaign with others!

story:
The Problem

Hi! My name is Nana, but I usually go by tako or takoyaki on various art websites. I started this fundraiser because a few months ago BOTH of my tablets broke, which completely wrecked because one of them was meant to be a back up in case something like this happened. 

I usually don't turn to charity, but I'm so bogged down with school and studying that there is no where in sunny San Diego that wants to hire me and my parents are already helping me pay for my school books so I would feel terrible asking them to buy me a tablet on top of all of that.  

Drawing is something that's gotten me through a lot of things in life and it's something I enjoy more than breathing because it allows me to not only make other people happy, but it also makes me happy that people can appreciate something of mine that they don't need to. Even though I chose not to major in the arts, I don't want to lose this part of myself because of financial difficulties.

Examples of my work:


Why do I need exactly $642?

I don't. I need exactly $641.77, but I can't put fractional numbers.

What exactly I'm buying with the money:

  • Yiynova MSP19U+ Tablet
  • 2 Year Warranty

In the case that I don't raise what I'm asking for:

If I don't get all that I'm asking for, all the funds go straight towards a tablet of lesser value.

In the case that I do raise more than I need:

I'm not going to be greedy and ask for money that I don't need, but in the case that I do, it's all going towards art related things!

If I get $20 more:

  • Bumping up the 2 year warranty to a 3 year warranty
If I get $50 more:
  • Instead of bumping up the warranty, I will buy Clip Studio Pro
If I get $220 more:
  • I'll buy Clip Studio Ex instead! I've been extremely anxious to start a webcomic and I heard this is one of the beast programs to do that with! 

Thank you so much for reading!

Honestly! You taking the time to read this means a lot to me! Even if you can't donate, may you please help me by letting others know?
Thank you!

story:
Purpose:

Put on a show for 500 Black male teens during Black history month. Take 25 of them to be mentored by "Egypt" for an entire summer. Give them a chance to have a role model. Inspire them to be the prototype, not the stereotype. 

Black Men: Naked Truth One-man Show & Film

When President Obama asked the community to educate Black men in his "My Brother's Keeper Campaign", this show was created. 

One man and seven characters illustrate healing truths many Black men want to say but can't or won't articulate. Why won't they? If they did, society has already considered a man who speaks openly about his troubles as, "weak", "effeminate" or "soft." From HIV testing, colon cancer screening to the affects  and low expectations of being a fatherless child, all are things men are taught to fight alone. 

Many Black men are exhausted from defending stereotypes many don’t resemble or share. The world must be tired of the repetitive and false negative images of Black men. This show is not only debunking stereotypes but also disclosing an untold experience many live daily. 

From World Famous Apollo Theatre,  a TED talk, BET's 106 & Park to sharing stages with John Legend and Alicia Keys, Devin T. Robinson X "Egypt" has made his brand of acting a powerful tool to express social issues. 

(Egypt speaking on a panel with Arthur Wylie, John Legend, Dr. Del Rosario and Marc. Williams)

Contributing to this message allows for an untold story to finally be told. Your support creates history by giving an opportunity for a marginalized group of 500 Black youth to hear another side of their journey. 

                                                 ("Egypt" speaking at TEDx PSUT)

What We Need!

With 20,000$ we can put on a dynamic production, have it professionally filmed (very costly), send it to film festivals and have screenings at high schools to present this message. A bulk of the money will be allocated to marketing. With events pertaining to education, marketing is one area most organizations can't or fail to invest in properly. The remaining dollars will go to:


  • Renting a venue for 3 dates.
  • Production of promotional commercials.
  • Radio commercials 
  • Hiring a director and production company to film the live event.
  • The filming of the event.
  • Booking up and coming national artists to open up the event, (which will help build attendance) 
  • Awards to local young Black artists who reflect the image of positive men. 
  • Transportation, events & meeting space for mentoring 25 youth for 90 days

What You Get!

From personalized, "Thank You" videos, autographed posters, lunch with "Egypt" to having your business showcased to 5,000 Facebook friends, the perks are fun and worthy of your support! For the top contributors, Egypt will write, perform and produce a 3-minute video of their submitted LIFE STORY! 

What Happens If We Don’t Meet Funding?

If we don't reach our goal...THE SHOW MUST GO ON! We will put on a smaller show. Scaled to our funds, inspire the community and use a virtual approach to mentoring youth! 

The Impact!

" Gangs attract recruits by making them feel good for doing bad. What if we as a community made young men feel good for being good? The result would be a new gang. Call it, "Change." -Egypt

When we applaud misbehavior but are apathetic to the opposite, we indirectly encourage negativity. There are many young men who would have stayed on the correct path if they would have seen a show like this. If they would have realized there was hope, happiness or honor in doing the right things...maybe they would.

Many Black men have "made it" but their stories aren't told. The negative images of thugs, drug dealers or convicts own visual real estate on TV and computer screens. Therefore, they own mental real estate in the minds of children and many. 

What if they heard the stories of the men who were dealt horrible cards but still decided, "I will not be a victim of my circumstance or a statistic because of it."? What if that was an undeniable message which echoed across the world? The result would be a sigh of relief and a jolt of happiness as many would finally receive an applause for "doing right" instead of being grouped into a small box of those who care to do wrong or nothing at all. This is that message. 

Let's make these 7 stories the new normal. If we do...we will start to see more young and older men doing the right things because of your support, your attendance and your applause. 

                  (Egypt performing at Florida Memorial University)


Why Does Egypt Care and Is He Qualified?

Despite losing his mother at 12, having his father abandon him a week later then entering college as an orphan, Egypt is a prime example of taking the cards you're dealt and still being in the game. 

He's created several successful one-man shows from, *"God, Me...HIV?", *"From Property To President" and *"God Didn't Give Me HIV" all educating the masses about social issues. 

                    *(www.HIVShow.com and www.PropertyToPresident.com)


                                         Risks & Challenges

It's easy to have a vision, a goal many people support and believe in. What's difficult is being a voice for a marginalized body of people who may believe no one cares about their struggle. We're so used to being ignored, hearing about something like this may seem more fiction than fact. Therefore, marketing will be the key (Bulk of budget) to ensuring a successful event. Without a heavy media campaign, this may become just another ignored but needed "positive" production.

Since 2003, "Egypt" has put on successful one-man shows all across the world. From Johannesburg, South Africa to South Florida. On multiple occasions, 300-500 people were in attendance to witness a message about social issues. No matter the ethnicity or subject, if you are willing to take a leap of faith and risk losing it all for a cause, success is your only option. 

This is his message. Give people a reason to come out. Let them know it's not a "those people over there" issue but a "My" issue. Over 11 years of making the connection and Egypt isn't giving up now. 

                                        (Egypt performing at Stetson University)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially...don't fret! Money isn't everything. You can donate items as well. Please, use the Indiegogo share buttons to let the world know about this message.

"those people over there" issue but a "My" issue. Over 11
years of making the connection and Egypt isn't giving up now. 

                                        (Egypt performing at Stetson University)
Other Ways You Can
Help
If you aren't
able to contribute financially...don't fret! Money isn't everything. You can donate items as well. Please,
use the Indiegogo share buttons to let the world know about this message.

story:
OVERVIEW

Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre is a new Indigenous run exhibition and community space in ᐊᒥᐢᑿᒋᐩ ᐚᐢᑲᐦᐃᑲᐣ amiskwacîwâskahikan (Edmonton, Alberta.) Ociciwan supports the work of Indigenous contemporary artists and designers, and engages in contemporary critical dialogue. We value artistic collaboration and foster the awareness of Indigenous contemporary art practices.

Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre is a project that began with the Ociciwan Collective. Founded in 2015, Ociciwan Collective Core members originally formed the collective under the awareness that Edmonton is in need of more support for Indigenous contemporary artists, curators, designers, educators, and culture workers; as well as, the dialogue, criticality, and vision associated with this practice. Ociciwan partnered with local arts organizations, such as Latitude 53 Contemporary Visual Culture, dc3 Art Projects, the Art Gallery of Alberta, Maggie and John Mitchell Art Gallery and the Francis Winspear Centre for Music, to support and promote innovative and experimental Indigenous contemporary arts practices. This way of fostering exhibitions and creative projects has allowed us to build and engage with a broader audience. However, it has always been Ociciwan’s goal to open a centre and to operate in a permanent location within Edmonton, as a way to fulfill the mandate that was set forth at Ociciwan’s conception.

 

OCICIWAN CONTEMPORARY ART CENTRE

The goal of Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre is to present Indigenous contemporary art and creative practices within our city,  and to serve as a developing model for supporting and developing Indigenous contemporary artist-centred galleries and cultural spaces. This art centre will allow the city to fully engage in its relationship to Indigenous contemporary art.

The Centre will remain collective-run with a group of Core Members, advising and co-curating exhibitions alongside Director Becca Taylor, rather than operating as a traditional artist-run centre. Current members of the Ociciwan Collective include Halie Finney, Alberta Rose W./Ingniq, Tiffany Shaw-Collinge, Erin Sutherland, and Kristy Trinier. Becca is joined by two staff members at the Centre: Michelle Campos Castillo (Project Coordinator) and Tracy Bradley (Community Coordinator). 

Ociciwan Centre presents four exhibitions or creative projects annually, with additional community-based programming relating to our exhibitions program. The Collective will strives to support, value and foster contemporary Indigenous art practices, while continuing to engage and partner with the local Edmonton community.

In September, Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre will open our doors to the public with an inaugural exhibition, “amiskwacîwâskahikan,” featuring artworks by eight artists who reside in, or hold a strong connection to, amiskwacîwâskahikan (Edmonton), Alberta.

 

Ociciwan Collective has come together to provide the most excellent perks for our supporters, which will contribute funds to our exhibitions, creative projects and art centre operations. 

 

Ociciwan Swag Bag

Want a little bit of everything? Claim this perk and you’ll receive an exclusive gift bag including an Ociciwan pin and patch, the Ociciwan tote bag, the in memoriam vinyl set and publication, the Parallel Excavation text, and a custom Ociciwan handmade mask made by Victoria Hedin! 

Custom masks by Victoria Hedin

Victoria Hedin is of Cree ancestry based in Calgary, Alberta. Trained in Fine Art and Fashion Design, fabric plays a large part in her day to day life. She is actively sewing her way to an entire handmade and thrifted wardrobe! Tie dyed by hand near the shore of Lesser Slave Lake, these masks are made from 100% cotton. The cotton jersey ties are also tie dyed. A nose wire helps keep a snug fit and there is an opening on one side so an extra filter layer can be added. This fitted mask is adult size medium to large. Ociciwan has been lovingly stitched on the top, so you can show your support wherever you go!

 

In memoriam...Vinyl Set and Publication

Building off of the earlier production of American composer Robert Ashley’s original in memoriam… operatic scores, Ociciwan is excited to announce the launch of a three volume vinyl set that features recordings of the original in memoriams…  as well as newly created score honouring the lives of three Indigenous women from the land now called Alberta composed by Postcommodity and Alex Waterman. Claim this perk and receive the full vinyl set and the publication, along with special digital downloads! Read more about the project on our website.

 

Flash Tattoo by Halie Finney

Win a flash tattoo from Ociciwan core member Halie Finney (@Woof.wah.tattoo)! Since October 2019 Halie has been working as a tattoo apprentice at Pls Hurt Me. The imagery used in her flash is made up of fun and friendly animals, fruits, and flowers with some of her own original characters sprinkled throughout. As a someone who tattoos, Halie’s goal is to provide a positive tattoo experience in an environment that feels safe for all of her clients. Halie’s flash is available on Instagram. Placement is limited to arms, legs, and torso. No hands, neck, butt, or face placements please. Appointment time typically runs between 30 minutes to 2 hours (depending on chosen flash, size, and placement).

 

Lunch and Architectural Tour with Tiffany Shaw-Collinge

Claim this perk and you and 3 friends can enjoy a COVID-friendly lunch and Architectural Tour with Métis Architect Tiffany Shaw-Collinge! Take a tour of the new Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre, where you can learn about the various steps taken in creating this amazing space, followed by lunch graciously donated by Cindy Lazarenko of Culina!

Tiffany is an artist, independent curator, and architect with Manasc Isaac. Her practice develops ideas behind cultural memory and craft through analogue and digital methodologies. Shaw-Collinge was born in Calgary and raised in Edmonton, Alberta with Métis descent from Fort McMurray, Alberta.

Cindy Lazarenko is an award-winning Edmonton chef with Ukrainian and Metis roots. She has been in the restaurant and catering industry for almost 30 years. She is now enjoying teaching, both in person and online. Cindy is passionate about her community and loves to support local artisans and farmers.

 

4 Hours of Grant/Paper Editing with Erin Sutherland

Claim this perk to get 4 hours of grant proposal editing from Ociciwan Core member Dr. Erin Sutherland to help spruce up that application! Having completed her P.h.D. in Cultural Studies from Queens University in 2017, Dr. Sutherland is offering 4 hours of her time to help you get ready just in time for that grant!

Erin is an Assistant Professor of Cultural Studies at the University of Alberta, Augustana. Completing her P.h.D. in Cultural Studies, from Queens University in 2017, her research focuses on Indigenous curatorial methodologies and Indigenous performance art. She also works as an independent curator and has curated the performance series Talkin’ Back to Johnny Mac in Kingston, Ontario in 2015. She is originally from Grande Prairie Alberta and is of Métis and settler decent. 

 

Director Tour and Dinner

Enjoy an evening of art and conversation with Ociciwan director, Becca Taylor, and 9 of your friends! Experience a private tour of our current exhibition and building, followed by a COVID-friendly dinner. 

Becca is a multi-disciplinary artist, youth worker and curator with Cree, Scottish and Irish descent. Her practice involves investigations of Indigenous community building and Indigenous feminisms through various mediums including video, text and installation. She was awarded the Aboriginal curator-in-residence, from the Canada Council in 2015 at Urban Shaman, and was the Indigenous Curatorial Research Practicum at the Banff Centre in 2017. Becca co-curated the 2018 iteration of La Biennale d'art contemporain autochtone (BACA) in Montreal, QC, entitled níchiwamiskwém | nimidet | my sister | ma soeur with Niki Little. 

 

We are committed to keeping programming at the Centre completely cost-free and accessible to visitors. We are able to host art exhibitions within two designated gallery spaces of the building. Our second floor includes space for community gatherings, and a kitchen. Every entrance of the building is barrier free and all floors can be accessed via an elevator lift. Each floor contains accessible, non-gendered, single-stall washrooms.

While we feel so grateful to have an amazing building to call home, the art space does mean that Ociciwan Collective has grown; some of the implications of this incredible space requires dedicated additional staff support and added maintenance costs, associated with running an art space. 

Our goal is $25,000 CAD. These funds will go towards Ociciwan Centre’s daily operational costs, such as utilities and maintenance that are crucial in keeping the space operating and available to the public.  In addition to operating costs, this support will contribute to our ongoing programming, such as exhibitions, creative projects, artist talks, community workshops and engagements. 

 

YOUR IMPACT

Ociciwan formed under the awareness that more support is required for Indigenous contemporary art, experimental creative practices, and innovative research. Without you, our community - and the opportunities to share in thoughtful conversations and trust together, along with the essential contributions of your work, time and ideas towards our collective-run organization, we would not be able to continue to do the work at Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre. We hope to continue to support and honour the conversations, important and insightful creative work fostered within amiskwacîwâskahikan, to a broad community. 

If you are unable to donate at this time, please consider supporting us in another way - and know we appreciate any way in which you are able to contribute. Please share our campaign on your social media platforms. Connect us with others! Share with friends, family and community members that you know, who would love to support Indigenous Contemporary Art practices, research and spaces. Follow us on social media and join our mailing list to see our future events and creative programming. Your contributions will have a significant impact for Ociciwan Contemporary Art Centre, as we open Edmonton’s newest Indigenous art space.

story:
So far I have completed most of the pieces to exhibit such as the costumes and a few art pieces.
However there is a book, 3 songs, a video and editorial photoshoots to be finished.

After this is complete, printing, publishing, curatorial and promotional organisation for the exhibition and project in will commence shortly after.

Costume 1 : Ukwu Nwanyi Obowu



 

Costume 2: "Udoka" - Isiji Agbogho Mmuo

 

 

What I Need To Raise 

Equipment & Materials :
Some finishing touches needed to added to the costumes and paintings, from professional embroidery, art supplies to mannequins and the final few canvases, this will help to speed up the process in order to have them ready for exhibiting collectively.  

Professional Fees for :

Studio, Photography & Cinematography 

Music Production 


Other Ways You Can Help!

It takes quite a lot to accomplish any goal, and support is paramount! Whether it’s financial or promotional, every little helps. 
We have 30 days to raise the desired goal, so please share this on all or any social platforms you think might be useful.
If you love quality content with refreshing and affirmative representation of diversified narratives,  please support in anyway you can. <3

Thank you so much, I appreciate your love and support.

story:
Vanitas V. Regan Rosburg. 3D Resin painting (detail). Found plastic, wasp nests, wolf spider, lizard, paint, wood, resin. 30 x 35 x 5 inches. 2017. Permanent collection: Le Meridian Hotel, Denver, CO.

 

Who I Am

As an artist, my work blurs the boundary between nature and consumer culture. The Arctic is an intersection of these two things because it is ground zero for climate change, warming faster than anywhere else on the planet. Even more shocking, this remote area is seeing an influx of plastics carried north by currents.

My work is heavily influenced by both climate change and plastic, so I am compelled to explore this region. I intend to bring what I gain back to my work, my college students, and my community.

 

The Project

I will be a participant in the The Arctic Circle residency program. Aside from absorbing the beauty of this exquisite landscape, I will do research for two simultaneous projects. One involves Emiliania Huxlyei, a microscopic coccolithophore (see image below) moving north due to warmer temps. The other involves marine plastic that has literally been carried to the ends of the Earth via the Thermohaline current. 

In preparation for my journey, I have met with scientists from the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), The University of Colorado, Bigelow Labs (Michigan), and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

On the trip, I plan to write, photograph, film and record. I will scout and collect samples of plastics from the icy shores and water, as well as samples that may contain EHux. I am also hoping to meet with scientists at a few labs in Svalbard (NyAlesund and Longyearbyen).

I firmly believe that art is a crucial part of the conversation on climate change. By contributing to this project, you are connecting me directly to scientists and artists who are working diligently to help ameliorate these issues, and who are inspired by the Arctic. You are also placing me in a uniquely stunning landscape where art and science intersect.

 

Emiliania Huxlyei, photographed with Electron Scanning Microscope. http://www.mikrotax.org/Nannotax3/index.php?tax...

 

What I Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise money to help cover the cost of the residency itself ($6500), some final cold-weather clothing items I still need ($500), and cover the shipment of plastics/samples back to the USA ($500). 

For your contributions, I am offering art prints, handmade jellyfish pendants, and even a few unique resin sculptures and paintings at a discounted price!

I have been funding this trip ahead of time (privately and through donations), so any money collected will offset the overall costs of this trip -- even if I do not reach my goal.

These handmade Jellyfish Pendants are actually 3D miniature resin paintings. Get your own as a perk for supporting my journey! 

 

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign, you are investing in my education, my cross-disciplinary collaboration, and the hands-on field research that informs my work. In this trip, nature and culture once again overlap; plastic is my symbolic metaphor for humanity's manic state, and a tiny EHux phytoplankton represents the briliance and deep history of our planet. 

In the past I have created works with plastic materials to point out the magnitude of our choices. The 3.2 tons of black recycled HDPE pellets in Omega showed how one American's annual average plastic bottle purchases added to the overall global consumption. Projects like The Relentless Memorial provided a place to contemplate and mourn our planetary losses. 

My interests have expanded beyond my own work to include others. I have done this by inviting artists to comment on aspects of EcoPsychology in curated exhibitions like Axis Mundi, by participating in conferences like the Thinker's Lodge in Nova Scotia, and by co-creating the  Cayo art/science residency in Eleuthera so that more artists may learn from each other.

I promise you this: your contribution will spawn large, thoughtful projects like these, dedicated to a careful consideration of our place in the world and resulting in evocative, knowledgeable, honest artwork about what is at stake.

Omega. Regan Rosburg. Sculptural installation with 87 million recycled pellets, recycled and virgin plastic cast wings, antlers, wolf spider, cicadas, resin, wasp nest, paint, wood, dog skull, silk flowers. 50 x 50 x 10 feet. 2017.
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help me, but cannot contribute financially? Please share this campaign with your fellow concerned activists, art lovers, and science nerds! I would be eternally grateful! 

You can link to my website here, and follow my adventure on Instagram here! I am not on Facebook, but feel free to share my project there if you like! Thank you!!!

 

About the Artist

Regan Rosburg (b. 1977) received her MFA from Lesley University College of Art and Design (2016), and her BFA at the University of Colorado at Boulder (2000). She is an artist, curator, and professor. She currently teaches at the Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design. Her commitment to environmental causes is evident in her poignant artistic imagery, talks, and writing. Rosburg will be a 2019-2021 Artist in Resident at Redline in Denver, and is the co-founder and artistic director of Cayo Artist Residency in Eleuthera, Bahamas. She has exhibited her work nationally since 2006, and is represented by William Havu Gallery in Denver, Colorado. Her research has been published in the IGI International Journal of Civic Engagement and Social Change, and she has been featured in Truthout, CPR News Radio, The Westword, The Shambhala Times (Canada), and the Denver Post. 

Thank you!

Omega. Regan Rosburg. Sculptural installation with 87 million recycled pellets, recycled and virgin plastic cast wings, antlers, wolf spider, cicadas, resin, wasp nest, paint, wood, dog skull, silk flowers. 50 x 50 x 10 feet. 2017.
 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Want to help me, but cannot contribute financially? Please share this campaign with your fellow concerned activists, art lovers, and science nerds! I would be eternally grateful! 
You can link to my website here, and follow my adventure on Instagram here! I am not on Facebook, but feel free to share my project there if you like! Thank you!!!
 
About the Artist
Regan Rosburg (b. 1977) received her MFA from Lesley University College of Art and Design (2016), and her BFA at the University of Colorado at Boulder (2000). She is an artist, curator, and professor. She currently teaches at the Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design. Her commitment to environmental causes is evident in her poignant artistic imagery, talks, and writing. Rosburg will be a 2019-2021 Artist in Resident at Redline in Denver, and is the co-founder and artistic director of Cayo Artist Residency in Eleuthera, Bahamas. She has exhibited her work nationally since 2006, and is represented by William Havu Gallery in Denver, Colorado. Her research has been published in the IGI International Journal of Civic Engagement and Social Change, and she has been featured in Truthout, CPR News Radio, The Westword, The Shambhala Times (Canada), and the Denver Post. 

Thank you!

story:
Who we are:

Two years ago we entered the program as strangers. Together we've been through countless late nights, tough critiques, caffeinated drinks, etc. These experiences created an indelible bond between us. Now we are one family, each with a story to tell. This two-day show will exhibit our best works and reveal to you our individual processes. This show marks a point where we wave goodbye to our time together as students and welcome the uncertain future with open arms. 

 

Our Goal:

Et Cetera is entirely self-funded by the 25 students in our class. We’ve knocked on doors, hawked our wares, and cobbled our show together by our bootstraps. (But mostly, we emptied our pockets.) We now look to you, our beloved family, friends, and supporters for a little extra help in making the show everything we hope and dream it to be. Our goal is to raise a fraction of what we've paid out of our pockets. Every penny will go directly toward venue costs, rental fees, set up, print production, etc. A donation of any size will help us in furthering our goals for the show. As a token of our appreciation, every donor will receive an official Et Cetera sticker, pin, and personalized note.

We greatly appreciate you and thank you for your support. We hope to see you at our show December 14–15 so we can thank you in person!

 

Now what's in it for you?

On top of an official Et Cetera sticker, pin, and personalized note that you will receive in the mail upon donation, you may qualify to be recognized at the show! Yes, that means your name on the big screen in the entry of the show! It's the perfect photo op. Please refer to the tiers below to see where you can be positioned amongst all of our other great supporters!

If you donate and provide us your email address, we will contact you about shipping information. Make sure you do not donate anonymously! If you donate anonymously and don't provide us with an email address, we are not able to send you your gift!

Top Tier: Donation of $125 and up

You're the best in show. Your name goes on the tippy top of the list. You might even need a ladder to see it. 

Mid Tier: Donation of $75 - $124

The ETC MVPs go here. You could've spent this money on a fancy dinner, but you spent it on our show, and that's what makes you so great. Still plenty of time for a fancy dinner AFTER the show.

Tier 1: Donation of $25 - $74

Our notable mentions. We don't need to say it, but we will anyway. We appreciate you! You deserve the bragging rights that come with a spot on the sponsor list.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand a donation may not always be possible. Any bit of support would help us in furthering our goals. 

Share this page. By sharing this donation page or our website, etc.show on your social media, you'll be helping us to spread the word.

Come to the show. Hang out with us and help us celebrate this moment.

Sponsor us. We are actively seeking corporate sponsors. If you have a lead, please email Angela Glenn at aglenn@thegaspcompany.com. 

Volunteer. Have a passion for volunteering? Good with people or behind the scenes? Have an extra ladder, power drill or folding table? Many tasks, supplies and materials are needed. Please email Angela Glenn at aglenn@thegaspcompany.com.

Keep in touch! We are building our mailing list and would love to know what you're up to.

story:
We are Stephanie + Kekeli, the founders and editors of a new type of publishing imprint called The Object Press.

Kekeli Sumah is an artist and designer currently pursing a Masters in Architecture at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC). He also holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts and a Bachelor of Arts in Visual and Critical Studies from SAIC.

Stephanie Lin-Sumah is a painter and artist exploring the intersecting dynamics of race, culture and identity in her work. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in Arts Studio from the University of California, Davis (UC Davis) and graduated from SAIC with a Masters of Art in Art Therapy. She currently works at SAIC.

 

Short Summary

This past November we were notified that our project idea: The Object Press would be included in a student exhibition organized by Ann Lui (faculty at SAIC and co-curator of the US Pavilion at the 2018 Venice Architecture Biennale) and Iker Gil—an associate curator. This exhibition is the first of it's kind in the history of the Venice Architecture Biennale and we're really excited to seize this opportunity to show alongside leading thinkers and practitioners in the fields of art, architecture and culture.

Our first issue as publishers: Home/Lands, will curate research artifacts from 10 local and international artists and designers, whose work addresses questions of citizenship and belonging through lenses of origins, personal narratives, geographies and physical acts of place-making.

Your contributions to this campaign will not only launch The Object Press by getting Stephanie + Kekeli to Venice, but more importantly, it will cement creative research in all forms as a legitimate line of critique and inquiry capable of addressing the issues of our times.

 

What We Need & What You Get

As makers, we've already started prototyping box designs and layouts for the 10 contributors we are publishing. We've put a lot of work into seeking advice from curators, designers and fabricators on how best to build and support the contents of the box. Now we need materials, special equipment and supplies to complete the box.

Since the student exhibition is organized as an SAIC study trip, Kekeli will be traveling with his classmates first and Stephanie will be joining him later. The $5,000 cost of school tuition and trip program fee will be covered by family contributions. But we will need help with traveling and living expenses. Here is the break down of anticipated costs:

  • Research + Development (design testing for the box): $200
  • Material Costs (wood, acrylic, display equipment, etc): $500
  • Mailing Costs (receiving and shipping contributor work local + international): $130
  • Shipping Costs (taking the box to Venice and back): $120
  • Round Trip Flight from Chicago to Venice (for two): $1700
  • Room + Board (for two): $2100
  • On-the-ground/canal Travel in Venice & Italy (ferry, public transit, rental car, gas): $620
  • Miscellaneous + Incidental Costs: $250
  • Indiegogo Fee Estimate: $280

Total Campaign Funding Sought: $5,900

We're excited to offer incentives to our campaign donors so check out the perks in the right-hand column, which include: an early access preview of the box, as well as a written mention in our exhibition donor list in Venice!

 

The Impact, The Risk, The Challenge

The Object Press is an answer to a need we identified when it comes to understanding the research and process of creative people; and we're poised to make a positive impact. Our biggest challenge will come from the The Object Press being such a novel idea—every step leads us into uncharted territory. Fortunately, we're plugged into a community of artists, designers, curators, mentors, business leaders and entrepreneurs who are willing to support our goals and visions along the way.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, but will still like to help our cause, here are a couple easy ways to support our journey to Venice!

Share Our Campaign: Spread the word and invite friends using these canned messages! Just copy and paste these templates to your platform of choice. Share our stories and posts on Instagram, spread the vision by word-of-mouth!

  • Facebook: It's not often that something new has the power to change our we think about art, design and publishing. Stephanie + Kekeli, founders of the object-oriented publishing imprint: The Object Press @theobjectpress, are trying to do just that with their first issue, "Home/Lands", which will be launched at this year's Venice Architecture Biennale! Support their exciting project here: bit.ly/2uVYVSB

 

  • Twitter: Interested in the intersection of publishing, art + design? Stephanie + Kekeli, founders of the object-oriented publishing imprint: @theobjectpress, are trying to take their first issue to the Venice Architecture Biennale. Support them at: bit.ly/2uVYVSB

Follow Us: Keep up to date with our work and progress on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram or simply sign up for our email list.

 

Thank you again for your time and support! If you have any feedback or questions, please contact us via email.

story:
MORE THAN A FESTIVAL.

Join us Sept 1-2 as we transform the block around the Temple Arts Center into an audacious smorgasbord of full sensory experiences. The Temple Tantrum Festival is a festival celebrating all manner of alternative creative cultures.  Featuring crazy fun DIY Funhouse, musical performances, hilarious comedy, and puppetry, this is a festival of alternative artists. This year’s program features national and local performers, Check our lineup so far:

 

WE ARE CREATING CULTURE

 

 

 

One part music festival, one part alternative arts festival, one part comedy festival, one part costumed extravaganza,  The tantrum is what happens when artists come together to make a crazy weekend.

The Tantrum looks to make space for gritty creatives in a growing city where it is becoming increasingly difficult for organic and DIY events to survive, especially without risking their artistic integrity. We are making a space for people to be whomever they choose and letting our artists and performers express freely while maintaining a safe environment.

 

YOU ARE INVITED:

 

This campaign is raising $10,00 for the Temple Tantrum Festival through presale tickets with sweet incentives!. Your contribution will enable us to give back to our artists, our neighborhoods, local businesses and our art. The funds raised by this campaign will allow the festival to maintain its creative integrity by allowing us to curate our sponsors and maintain our artistic integrity  while allowing ticket prices to be low. Your donations will contribute to:

 

Production:

We are closing the down the whole block! To turn the street into a party, this means many hard costs associated with providing a high caliber and exciting event.  We want to use the funds to grow our footprint and bring more art into the mix.

At 4k

 

Creative Talent:

Our goal for the festival is to produce that maintain its creative integrity. Unfortunately a lot of festivals are being changed by major corporations by sponsors who drown artistic content under advertising messages. We are reaching out to our community to help fund the festival to the festival is for the community by the community.

 

HISTORIED IMPACT:

Temple Arts Center is a social venture established to preserve and revive an important landmark, while providing affordable art studios and workshop facilities, housing creative organizations and community non-profit art spaces focused on underserved youth.  It is a former synangogue, the birth place of the United Way, and for a time, a legendary rave venue.

PlatteForum (the Temple's root foundation and benefactor of the Tantrum)  is a 501c3 dedicated to supporting contemporary artists and under-served youth in metro Denver through innovative, long-term arts programs. This award-winning nonprofit organization provides a nurturing space where creativity and artistic excellence are highly valued and where artists and youth partner together to plan, produce, and exhibit a body of work to the public. The overall experience transforms the lives of the youth, the artists and the community.

story:
Let's Take a Trip...

Let's Take A Trip is an 108 psychedelic oracle deck based off personal trip experiences with magic mushrooms, LSD, & cannabis. She is meant to be a full immersive experience through all the senses, sight, sound, touch, taste, & our sixth senses of course. Let's Take A Trip was born shortly after experiencing an intense magic mushroom trip, opening Rainbow Liz in unexpected ways. A Meaningful Dream has always wanted to create an oracle deck, but the idea never came for the theme until Penis Envy entered our life. The deck came through as a major download, & I received countless signs from the Universe that this NEEDED to happen. Let's Take A Trip is truly unique, as its very "trippy & abstract" in nature & strongly embraces psychedelics & their sacred medicine they offer the cosmic consciousness. No deck has been created purely like this before.

 

Below are some of the oracle cards from the "Hoxeyville" series, the very first time A Meaningful Dream was introduced to magic mushrooms. Each of them have very specific messages with great depth, & meaning.  

It's Not JUST a Deck...

Let's Take a Trip is meant to be experienced through all the senses. A Meaningful Dream created additional offerings, inspired directly from potent moments while under an altered state of consciousness. These items are meant to be used in correlation to enhance the experience with Let's Take A Trip! 

The Call...

A Meaningful Dream is on the path to awaken consciousness on a cosmic level. When Rainbow Liz attended the very first Entheofest in Ann Arbor, Michigan, she received another call. Her ancestors were singing out to her, begging her to expand this offering beyond what was already created. To continue standing up for nature & her magic she offers. To be a protector & educator of Mother Earth. Which is why $11 per deck will be donated to Decriminalize Nature Michigan. To help make these plants legal, allow them to be more accessible to our community, & to the stop the unnecessary war on plants. So far, Decriminalize Nature Michigan has successfully decriminalize magic mushrooms in Ann Arbor, & Hazel Park, Michigan. Visit their website to learn more about their work: www.decrimnaturemi.org

Risks & Challenges

In order for Let's Take A Trip to come to life, we HAVE to make this $11,000 goal. This will allow A Meaningful Dream the funds NEEDED to simply order the deck from the printer. Along with the money needed to purchase "Music of the Plants" which is a bamboo box that allows the recording of plants that then converts it into music. Thank you so much for your support!

story:
So...the book.

104 pages of sketches, never before seen work, and alternate versions of published works by illustrator Brandon Yowell.

What are you getting?

A full color book of artwork. High quality, perfect bound, silk stock gallery quality paper. All the money goes to printing and shipping the book.

Can I see some of the pages?

Here you go.

Risks & Challenges

The book is completed and being proofed by the printer. This campaign is just a pre-order for those of you who want the book.

Can I get it in hardback?

No. Super stupid expensive.

story:
►WHY BY A CARGO SHIP?

The last two times, UuDam traveled to Europe and Australia by airplane.

This time, by traveling to America on a cargo-boat, UuDam would like to put himself in the shoes of earlier travelers (pre airplane era) to experience the vast time, space they were in. In addition, he wishes to feel the energy that moves huge amount of world commerce in the expansive blue of the Pacific Ocean.  Instead of jet-lag, he will probably experience boat-lag when reaching America.

   The type of cargo ship artist UuDam will take to come to Los Angeles (a 30-day trip)

► WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORT?

The cost of this ambitious Pacific Ocean crossing and performances is above and beyond the UuDam Studio and OCMA budgeted funds. This Indiegogo campaign is the catalyst to rally additional support needed to pay for the UuDam and his  assistant 6 weeks journey on a cargo ship and launching the third fingertip into California ocean. By donating to this campaign, you will help fund his and his assistant travel costs & equipment and provide modest housing during the 4-week long ocean travel & 2-week performance in California and airfare back to Việt Nam. Your support will also help provide honorariums for project collaborators, videographer, photographer, hotel and car rental, insurance, accommodations as well as video post-production, etc. The goal is to raise 19,000 USD to cover that cost.  

Your gift will radically enhance the Time Boomerang exhibition project at OCMA by making it into reality in American continent. UuDam believes that art with a good cause can touch people and make positive changes. TIME BOOMERANG will.

Help us spread the word, whether by word of mouth or social networks. Follow us on our Facebook page:  

Bản tiếng Việt: http://tinyurl.com/yxoytndv 

Note: tiếng Anh: http://tinyurl.com/y23pp8l5 

https://www.facebook.com/UuDamStudio/

https://www.instagram.com/uudam_tran_nguyen/

https://twitter.com/UuDam

https://www.UuDamStudio.com

► CONTEXT & STORY FOR TIME BOOMERANG

 THE COW TONGUE:

The "cow tongue" -  The New York Times - A Game of Shark and Minnow - by Jeff Himmelman

In 1947, Taiwan & China drew the famous “cow tongue” (as known as the nine-dash line) to claim all the Islands in the South China Sea all the way to Philippine and Indonesia. These islands (atolls) are also claimed by Vietnam, the Philippines, Brunei, Indonesia, and Malaysia. This bold overlapping exercise of powers with territorial map on an international scale made UuDam Tran Nguyen rethink the concept of measuring. He finds that exciting when the real distances of things being measured is not necessarily reflected scientifically or lawfully especially when it is influenced by desires, beliefs & national needs. He thinks about what one did when one was a child. One would measure things around them with their outstretched fingers: the first act of almost pure measuring. That’s when he made the first sculpture in the first phase of Time Boomerang. He casted his hand, fingers fully outstretched in his childhood measuring gesture, in metal. When it was completed, he cut out the five fingertips, and moved them away from the hand, symbolically extending his ability to measure (or mark new territories). These five places could be 5 corners of a museum, a university campus, a country, a continent, 5 continents of the Earth, 5 places in a Galaxy, or 5 Galaxies and so on.

 Phase #1: Cast hand and five fingertips ready for five continents

 

►INTRODUCTION TO TIME BOOMERANG, AMERICA PERFORMANCE

Over a period of several years, UuDam will place the 5 fingertips in the oceans of five different continents. 

Until this moment, UuDam has successfully launched 2 of the 5 bronze fingertips into the waters of Europe and Australia continents as part of Phase #2 . By measuring the world, the artist wishes to elevate a regional conflict onto a vast time and space where mediated dialogues can take place without impassioned fistfights based on heated patriotism. The Time Boomerang is an on-going project made up of 8 phases. UuDam is pleased to present Phase #1, two parts of Phase #2, Phase #3 and Phase #4 for the first time in Orange County Museum of Art. 

This August, UuDam Tran Nguyen would like to complete the third part of Phase #2,  bring his third bronze fingertip to America. California will be the chosen destination.

PHASE #2: The New Conqueror with a Good Passport. Part 3 of 5: America Performance  

    Phase #2: 30 days crossing the Pacific Ocean trip for the America performance - July-August

In July and August 2019, in conjunction with his exhibition currently on view at the Orange County Museum of Art,  the acclaimed Vietnamese artist UuDam Tran Nguyen will carry out his historic symbol-laden trip crossing the Pacific Ocean on a cargo ship. After that 30-day voyage, he will reach Los Angeles port. UuDam then will perform the dropping the third bronze fingertip into the California Pacific Ocean. Those two activities will complete Part 3 of Phase #2 of this 8-Phased Time Boomerang project.

As the chief critic of OC WEEKLY Dave Barton wrote “Starting with the idea that a child uses his hand to measure things—and the image of a land grab is the perfect childish symbol for an empire—the artist has cast his hand, then cut of the tips of all five fingertips. Those sculpted fingertips will be dropped into bodies of water bordering five of the continents, as a performative way to reclaim territory. It’s essentially a nonsense gesture, but just as with many useless things signifying hope, he persists in doing it anyway.”

    Phase #2: Europe Performance (picture by Polly Yassin)

The crossing of the Pacific Ocean and the America performance later in California are continuing parts of the US debut of Time Boomerang at the Orange County Museum of Art from April 7, 2019 — Sept 1, 2019. This is a very special occasion to bring the TIME BOOMERANG's third bronze fingertip to the USA shore. Please join us in bringing this timely message of hope to California, a place that has prided itself on independent thinking, demographic diversity and home of the biggest Vietnamese-American community oversea that closely connected to the conflicts in the South China Sea, where this project got inspired from in the first place.

     Phase #1, #2, #4 of Time Boomerang installation at National Art Center Tokyo, in the         SunShower exhibition

 

► AN OVERVIEW OF TIME BOOMERANG

TIME BOOMERANG CONSISTS OF 8 PHASES:

PHASE #1: The Real Distances of Things Being Measured

 Phase #1: Gilded bronze hand inside an engraved plexiglass box (picture by UuDam Studio)

PHASE #2: The New Conqueror with a Good Passport, 5 parts 

    - Part 1: EUROPE (completed)

On the 22nd of September 2015, UuDam traveled from Viet Nam to Sweden to launch the first of the five fingertips into the Gulf of Bothnia. The European performance is part of the TIME BOOMERANG Phase #2. During that time, Phase #1 was on display in the Miền Méo Miệng exhibition at Bildmuseet Museum.

  Phase #2: Europe Performance (picture by Polly Yassin)

- Part 2: AUSTRALIA (completed)

On the 29th of November 2015, after two cancellations due to bad weather, the second bronze fingertip was launched into the Moreton Bay in Brisbane, Australia. UuDam was part of the 8th Asia Pacific Triennial while carrying out his second performance of the TIME BOOMERANG Phase #2.

 Phase #2: Australia Performance (picture by Chloë Callistemon)    

- Part 3: AMERICA Performance (to be performed in August, 2019. This is where your funding is going to support). 

    - Part 4: AFRICA (to be announced)

    - Part 5: ANTARCTICA (to be announced)

PHASE #3: Digital Body Print - commissioned by OCMA

 By CAT scanning his body and extracting the bone part into digital files with his initial UDN carved all over. UuDam's skeleton could be printed in 3D on demand. This mimics the old practice of many war where one need to find the reason to occupy new territory. Once the bone is ready, the artist can bury them on any territory where he wants to possess.

   Phase #3: Digital Body Print

PHASE #4: Cartography 101: Creating the Next Freaking World Order

Be our guest at the weekly breaking maps performance at OCMA.

After "conquering" all five continents with his bronze fingertips, we have the power to turn it up side down and break it up. As the old world orders are destroyed, we can created the next one. 

  Phase #4: Breaking Map performance at OCMA (picture by Lauren Hillary) 

 

► ABOUT UUDAM TRAN NGUYEN

  Phase #2: Australia Performance - picture by Chloë Callistemon     

UuDam Tran Nguyen is a Vietnamese-born conceptual artist. He grew up in different parts of Vietnam and the USA. UuDam was trained as a sculptor at the HCM Fine Art University until 1994. He later got his B.A. from UCLA & MFA from the School of Visual Arts. He is now living and working in HCMC.

UuDam Tran Nguyen’s artwork reflects his wide interests in many aspects of social issues. He transforms the boundaries between urban myth and popular legend to both celebrate - and warn - of the role and impact of human progress and its desire for social advancement. He is working with video, performance, photography, remote controlled sculpture robotics and new media. Nguyen’s playfully & provocative practice is today one of the prominent voice of Vietnamese contemporary art.

UuDam has been exhibited internationally in the 4th Singapore Biennale, Asia Society Museum, RISD Museum, Kadist Art in San Francisco, the White Chapel gallery, the Jewish Museum NYC, Bildmuseet Museum, Jim Thompson Art Center, the Asia Pacific Triennial (APT8), Art Stage Singapore 2016, at QGOMA, FCAC, the High Line Art, the Aichi Triennale 2016, Yokohama Museum of Art, The NTU CCA residency in Singapore, Goethe Institute in Ha Noi, Singapore Art Museum and SUNSHOWER at the National Art Center in Tokyo in 2017, the show in Esplanade Theater on the Bay & Kuandu Museum of Fine Art (KdMoFA) in Taipei, Shanghai Biennale 2018 in China and the show Serpents' Tails at Galerie Quynh, HCMC, Vietnam.

His works have been mentioned and reviewed in Art Forum, Degree Critical, Flash Art, Hyperallergic, Vietnam News, Blouin Art Info, The New York Times, Singapore Today Top Pick, Saigoneer, Los Angeles Times, Phnom Penh Post, Vietnam TV: VTV3 & HTV9, Art Radar Journal, LA weekly, Time Out New York, ArtTribune Italy, etc.

He won the Jury Selection prize of the prestigious 18th Japan Media Arts Festival for his robotic app artworks License 2 Draw. UuDam is a co-founder of the experimental art magazine XEM. He is preparing for this Pacific Ocean crossing and America Performance from Ho Chi Minh City

 

►ABOUT THE 6 NEW EXHIBITIONS OCMA EXPAND AT ORANGE COUNTY MUSEUM OF ART

 For this second season at ​OCMA​EXPAND-SANTA ANA, OCMA will continue the strategy of considering its interim location as a laboratory for artistic experimentation, taking the idea of the Pacific Rim as a research question. “The season of exhibitions by artists Diego Berruecos, York Chang, Victoria Fu and Matt Rich, Fritzia Ir​í​zar, UuDam Tran Nguyen, and Hiromi Takizawa continues OCMA's proud history and trajectory as a leader in presenting the freshest art of our time,” says Todd D. Smith, OCMA’s director and CEO. “We look forward to a robust exchange of ideas born out of showing these artists, especially in such a public-facing space.” Located in South Coast Plaza Village, ​OCMA​EXPAND-SANTA ANA is the Museum’s temporary venue while it builds its Thomas Mayne-designed new home at Segerstrom Center for the Arts. 

 

► REWARDS

With his rich body of works, UuDam Studio is pleased to offer these exciting rewards to our invaluable backers:

Name recognition on UuDamStudio website ($5 or more)

 

Digital Wallpaper ($10 and $25)

 

Sticker of the world's first crowd-sourcing, award-winning art project  License 2 Draw ($25)

 

Graphic TIME BOOMERANG tote bag ($100 or more) 

 

Name recognition and attendance in UuDam’s August Artist Talk at OCMA  ($200 or more) (picture by PSA)

 

A private tour of UuDam’s Time Boomerang exhibition at the Orange County Museum of Art ($300 or more) (picture by Laurence Hillary)

 

1 sketch of UuDam’s 30 days activities during his sea voyage to reach the shore of the America ($600 or more) (TIME BOOMERANG)  (picture by Chloë Callistemon)    

 

Mock-up of UuDam Studio limited edition glass bottled sculpture (TIME BOOMERANG) ($1000)

 

Name recognition during speech on the boat, during the ceremonial launching the fingertip into the ocean. The backer who contributes $1,500 will receive a special edition hanging bronze Buddha sculpture from UuDam Buddha collection - gilded bronze ($1,500 or more)

 

A sculpted map of California as an island (TIME BOOMERANG) ($2,500 or more)

Join The UuDam & other VIP on the day of the performance on one of these boats (36 Tiara boat or if we are lucky, the Catamaran sail boat) along the coast of California. ($3,500 or more)

 

► OUR PARTNERS

Boat owners:

Depends on our schedule, we could be on either a 36 Tiara boat or the Catamaran sail boat to observe this whole historic performance of Time Boomerang in August.  We would like to thank them for their generous support.

 

Draco Film

Founded in 2015, Draco Film is a Saigon-based production house for films, media productions, commercials and digital assets. Not just an ordinary production house, they create, consult, and bring client's stories to life. Draco Film has partnered with UuDam Studio since 2015 in Project Time Boomerang in Tokyo SunShower, Japan.

Draco Film is consider one of the most active and dedicated Production & Post-Production House in HCMC, Vietnam. Their diverse service provide creative videos such as TVCs, Viral Videos, Corporate Videos and Animations for direct clients and advertising agencies. Their team is made up of dynamic filmmakers, designers, animator, dreamers and do. Again, they are looking forward to partnering with UuDam Studio on their next journey to TIME BOOMERANG, "Conquering" America Performance .

 

XEM Magazine:

From 2013, XEM collective with 5 founding members: Nguyen Thanh Truc, Phan Quang, Hoang Duong Cam, Quang Lam and Nguyen Tran UuDam. XEM Magazine has been featuring artists in Vietnam community and abroad  on their magazine platform. It is an experimental and photographic platform. Their support of the mission will result in the form of a special XEM Magazine edition to spread the news about this event on Social Media and XEM Facebook page.

 

► ADDITIONAL SPECIAL REWARDS

*For collectors who would like to invest and own part of or all of this ambitious 8-phased  TIME BOOMERANG project at this early stage, this is a great moment to do so. You will enjoy a special early bird investor rate. Items include videos, sculpture and all the items above and more below. Great rewards for Collectors who wish to support our 30 days trip across the Pacific Ocean and "Conquering" America performance:

Please view Special Collectors' Items below.

Launch Tube (Time Boomerang) - Plexiglas and bronze fingertip 

 

Engraved Plexiglass box + bronze hand (TIME BOOMERANG)

 

 Buddha (A Portrait of Emptiness) - Polished bronze (small version)

 

Video Serpents' Tails - 3 Channels, color, sound -  15 mins

 

 The 3D clouds (Serpents' Tails) - photo on archival paper - 93 x 140cm 

 

I Love You Forever (Serpents' Tails) - Foam sculpture photo on archival paper - 60 x 80 cm

 

No VACANCY sculpture - (Serpents' Tails) - Neon light and chromed bronze

 

The Long Serpents (Serpents' Tails) - Archival print on  paper  - 300 x 123 cm

 

Shadow Puller - Gilded bronze 

 

 World's first crowd-sourcing Robot + App drawing series (License 2 Draw)

 

Laser drawing (License 2 Draw)

 

Thinking Rock - Led light, aluminum and plaster, steel.

 

PHASE #2: The New Conqueror with a Good Passport, Part 1: EUROPE  Performance - Video of launching the 1st bronze fingertip into the Gulf of Bothnia, Sweden - Duration: 14' 56''

PHASE #2: The New Conqueror with a Good Passport, Part 2: AUSTRALIA  Performance - Video of launching the 2nd bronze fingertip into the Moreton Bay in Brisbane, Australia​ - Duration: 15' 06''

 

Feel free to contact us at UuDam Studio's Facebook or artist UuDam Tran Nguyen for any further information on the works above.

Thank you for your interest and support for TIME BOOMERANG - America Performance project!

LET'S BE PART OF HISTORY!

  With the team from Bildmuseet Museum - Umea - Sweeden (from the left Polly Yassin (photographer),  Brita Täljedal (curator), Thuy Nguyen (photographer), Gunnar Asplund ( (boat owner)​, Ida Hansson (video), UuDam Tran Nguyen)

 

UUDAM STUDIO
story_txt: ►WHY BY A CARGO SHIP?The last two times, UuDam traveled to Europe and Australia by airplane.This time, by traveling to America on a cargo-boat, UuDam would like to put himself in the shoes of earlier travelers (pre airplane era) to experience the vast time, space they were in. In addition, he wishes to feel the energy that moves huge amount of world commerce in the expansive blue of the Pacific Ocean.  Instead of jet-lag, he will probably experience boat-lag when reaching America.   The type of cargo ship artist UuDam will take to come to Los Angeles (a 30-day trip)► WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION SUPPORT?The cost of this ambitious Pacific Ocean crossing and performances is above and beyond the UuDam Studio and OCMA budgeted funds. This Indiegogo campaign is the catalyst to rally additional support needed to pay for the UuDam and his  assistant 6 weeks journey on a cargo ship and launching the third fingertip into California ocean. By donating to this campaign, you will help fund his and his assistant travel costs & equipment and provide modest housing during the 4-week long ocean travel & 2-week performance in California and airfare back to Việt Nam. Your support will also help provide honorariums for project collaborators, videographer, photographer, hotel and car rental, insurance, accommodations as well as video post-production, etc. The goal is to raise 19,000 USD to cover that cost.  Your gift will radically enhance the Time Boomerang exhibition project at OCMA by making it into reality in American continent. UuDam believes that art with a good cause can touch people and make positive changes. These islands (atolls) are also claimed by Vietnam, the Philippines, Brunei, Indonesia, and Malaysia. This bold overlapping exercise of powers with territorial map on an international scale made UuDam Tran Nguyen rethink the concept of measuring. He finds that exciting when the real distances of things being measured is not necessarily reflected scientifically or lawfully especially when it is influenced by desires, beliefs & national needs. story:
Who I am, & what is this?

My name is Mirra Esther Shapiro. I was born in Philadelphia. I have meditated, studied, danced, gardened, birthed and  reared babies in the watersheds of Kentucky's Appalachian foothills. Now I am curating an artist journal in this place.

R.O.U.T.E.; Volume One will feature a diverse range of artists; many from this place and also from neighboring regions. Lindsay Windland, Angela Davis Johnson, Carrie Davis,  C. Philip Willett, Terra Luna, Judith Faulkner, April Simmons, Joana Amorim, and more, will grace the pages with their stories, art, and writing. Artists' works connect to the themes of the journal's five sections; Rhythm, Observation, Understanding, Transformation, and Expression.

I have received grants from Kentucky Foundation for Women and from Alternate Roots to fund the artists' work.  Your contributions will now help to bring this publication into fruition. Funds from this campaign will go directly into the supplies and workforce necessary for drafting and publishing; for bringing Route Volume #1 to the table. Your contributions are VITAL to the expression of this artistic force.

We need $7,200 to publish R.O.U.T.E. Volume 1

$2000-  in formatting & editing costs ( editing program & labor )

$3200- in printing costs ( high quality scanner/printer & labor )

$1800- in Binding costs ( binding materials, ethically sourced paper, & work-force!)

$200- a much needed drafting table!

Exciting Perks for this campaign include postcards,  patches, and T-shirts with the hand carved prints of  the of the r.o.u.t.e. symbol. Contributors can also gain connectivity with the publication to receive updates and get involved when the Journal goes to print!

If we don't reach our fundraising goal, all funds present will go directly to the equipment and materials necessary to bring  R.O.U.T.E. into print.

R.O.U.T.E. (volumes 1,2,3,4...&)

The first volume of  R.O.U.T.E. will require the biggest push, both financially and in the required work effort. This first publication is a  valuable opportunity for artists and readers alike! With this first journal we will begin a conversation among artists and readers, inviting the route-holders, to contribute inspired works to future publications.  This artist journal will then become a forum for the inspired stories, art, and writings that continue to blossom from the roots of Volume 1.

The aim of R.O.U.T.E. is to demystify art, and to crack open our creative process, so that creativity can be a language that we learn how to speak together.  Our collective creativity forms a collective voice, one of inclusivity and diversity; strengthened by every new voice and by every one who is listening.

Risks & Challenges

As a the sole caretaker for three young children, the most monumental challenge for me will be to be able to prioritize the work space to make  R.O.U.T.E. possible in this coming year. I am fully confident that I can do it, as I have been moving steadily on behalf of R.O.U.T.E. since its  conception. I will continue to move steadily with this goal before me. With enough funding I will be able to bring in a few new key players to help move the process along in the formatting, editing, binding, and printing. Having the help will determine the scale of production for R.O.U.T.E. 

If you cannot contribute financially, but you would still like to help , please share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools, social media, and let your people know that we are enR.O.U.T.E.~Get the word out!
