story:
Step Inside

Beautiful Life is a gigantic, 12 m long, kaleidoscope powered by a projector which creates tessellations that move and change as you walk inside of the work. This interactive installation invites you to be the creator as you get lost in the world reflected around you.

We want to share Beautiful Life Project with you all, by touring it around Australia and then the world but we need your help to get it off the ground. Support us so we can bring it to an event near you.

Our Rewards

To thank you for your amazing support, we are excited to offer rewards directly inspired by the Beautiful Life Project. The amazing team of artists, designers and engineers behind this project chose the things that most excite and inspire them about the project to create all the gifts on offer.

 

Project Origins

This started as a joke, but sometimes a joke is the only way to believe in the impossible. I was talking to a friend and we were discussing crazy project ideas and I asked, “Imagine what it would be like to walk inside a giant kaleidoscope”. Fast forward a few months and I was in Russia with my family and we started playing around with one from a local toy store. Drawing inspiration from the world’s most advanced artist – nature – we found that kaleidoscopic art was effortless, self-creating, limitless and gave everyone the opportunity to become an incredible artist.

Building some larger prototypes exploring different shapes and sizes, I knew the idea was something I should pursue when my grandma stuck her head inside and started playing like she was 5 years old again! This was going to be a project that engages all ages.

We are inspired by art that enables the observer to be a co-creator and technology that brings people together rather than keeps us apart. The art that blurs the lines between artist and audience, child and adult, creator and consumer. By breaking down these walls we want to invoke a childlike joy in every person who steps inside, as the simple images move around them, reminding us all that there is indeed is Beautiful Life all around us.

 

Project Description

We've ordered some materials and started construction but we need your help to get us across the finish line. Help us bring this project to life!

Beautiful Life Project is a massive undertaking, standing at 12m long and 3.7 m tall at its highest point. A complex steel frame underlies the structure with cladding on the outside and mirror panels covering the interior. A projector and screen set at the back of the structure provide a base for the kaleidoscopic tessellations.

Stepping inside, the viewer is enveloped in mirrors, where they experience the kaleidoscope’s tessellations all around them. Their reflections become incorporated into the image, drawing them further into the artwork. A camera, provided, allows participants the option of filming themselves and world around them which is then projected back into the space.

Most kaleidoscopes produce a flat, 2-dimensional image, however, by tapering the structure we worked out we could use the mirrors to produce a 3-dimensional experience. The reflections within Beautiful Life create a sphere 18 meters in diameter around the viewer. This represents our earth, within our beautiful life, and the many facets that come with it. Through this imagery and by playing videos of nature, we want to remind the audience that beauty and nature are intrinsically linked and how important it is to take care of this precious resource.

 

 

The artwork on the exterior walls is created in collaboration with muralist Karri McPherson. Karri’s design was inspired by her love of geometric shapes and the underlying geometry and tessellation at the heart of a kaleidoscope. Using 34 different colours, her artwork hints at the multifaceted colourful experience within.

We want to share this project with you so much that we’ve taken a gamble and started construction, but we need your support to fully bring it to life. The project requires:

  • More than 500 m of steel 
  • 84m2 of external cladding
  • 84 m2 of mirrors 
  • 80 cans of spray paint 
  • 1.5 tons of steel ballast 


Plus projectors, nuts, bolts, screws, glue and hours of loving labour to bring it to life.

To date we have generously been supported by friends in lending us tools, time and a space to work but we need some further financing to get the project over the line. The more money we raise, the more awesome an experience it will be.

 

Opportunities

Any money in addition to our goal will go to improving the technology and making it more interactive including:

  • An external light experience (as envisioned below)
  • An interactive sound component


But the sky is the limit – our dream additions include changing our ballast to solar charged batteries to help festivals and other events minimise their impact on the environment.

 

Several festivals have shown interest in the work and we are determined to take it all around Australia, and then the world, so you all can experience the childlike joy of Beautiful Life. But given its size, we are going to need the help of everyone to make this happen. We are expecting a final build cost to exceed $50k plus labour and transportation. The crowdfunding will go towards material costs and overheads during this initial stage.

 

Design Details

The design of the kaleidoscope is significant both mathematically and artistically.

The pentagon shape is key to the design. Beautiful Life is a floret pentagon, one of the most beautiful forms, characterised by symmetry about its peak, and all other angles are at 120 degrees. There are only a few types of pentagons that will tessellate in a way that allows the kaleidoscope reflections to occur. It is called a floret pentagon because the shape tessellates as a flower, which unfolds before you as you step inside the kaleidoscope. 

The floret shape is also significant because it is the shape which most closely matches the human body. By shaping the work this way, the kaleidoscope becomes physically accessible to all people. More than that, the work is inviting to the audience and without audience participation the artwork is incomplete.

As environmentally conscious engineers, we also looked at how we could minimise the amount of material used without compromising on the experience. Compared to other shapes, the pentagon provides the most efficient material usage to space ratio.

 

The Team

Nikita Shtepa is the creative director of Beautiful Life Project. He is an engineer turned artist, creating interactive digital installation. Based in Australia, Nik has displayed at the Brisbane Street Art Festival in 2019 with Sound of Touch, an installation which allowed participants to use the human body as a musical instrument. Sound was created by holding hands and exploring how to create melodies through touch. Nikita has a background in R&D working on industrial sized solar projects and has a lot of experience in large scale installations.

Karri McPherson is a contemporary painter and muralist. She explores geometric art in relation to different special confinements. Beautiful Life is the largest canvas she has worked on to date and her geometric style makes the outside of the project an artwork in its own right. Karri has been involved in over forty exhibitions throughout Australia and the United States. She has been awarded two prizes: the Emerging Artist Award at the University of Southern Queensland graduate exhibition in 2017 and the 2018 Biennial Emerging Artist Award. https://www.karrimcpherson.com

Liz Scott is the project strategist and communications director. As a mechanical engineer she brings an eye for detail and a love of process to Beautiful Life. Dividing her time between engineering support and project operations she provides the practical counterweight in the project. Liz and Nik originally met experimenting with solar farm design and their collaborations have carried through to the present.

Mark Swartz is a highly acclaimed sculptor as well as the owner/operator of Feather Edge, a business that designs and creates works beyond his own artistic practise.  He has exhibited several prestigious events including Sculptures by the Sea in 2017. Mark has been an invaluable mentor and supporter of the project, providing not only advice and manpower, but his workshop space to get the project kick started. https://www.featheredge.com.au/

Jade Fennell is an engineer and illustrator specialising in water colours and her work is inspired by nature, curiosity and art. While working together on solar, Nikita and Jade started brainstorming big art projects when they discovered they were both inspired by artworks that combined technology with play. Jade is our visual designer, managing our social media and making sure we share every step of this journey with you.  @biiniprojects

 

 

And now... You!

This art piece is all about connection, curiosity and play- it is incomplete without its audience. Please support us in any way that you can, through liking, sharing, and telling friends and family about our little (now very big) dream. 

Christmas is just around the corner, and our rewards make great gifts as well as works of art in their own right. All rewards are made locally, by our team and independent businesses in Newcastle and Sydney. Every dollar you donate gets Beautiful Life one step closer to you. 

We would love to bring this larger than life experience to your doorstep! Follow along at @wearebeautifullife

story:
Background

Living in Norwich, Siris is a strong advocate for mental health awareness. His mission is to challenge public stigmas and create opportunities for people to engage in their community through art.

Since 2017, Siris has created exhibitions that focus on offering a personal insight into living with mental illnesses, to create conversations in public spaces and normalise talking about mental health. 'I deliberately pick public spaces, where people go organically, I want to challenge people by bringing mental health into their day to day lives.' - Siris Hill.

Due to his health, working in a scheduled environment is near impossible for him. It’s his dream to become recognised as an artist and to be able to make a living from something he can do that fits around his health.

‘I just want to make enough to live on and to fund my ideas continue to do what drives me, which is improve the lives of others with mental illness by challenging stigmas and creating opportunities and events to engage people in the arts and to share the power of creativity for well-being with others. I have so many ideas, I just don’t want anyone else to feel like I have and to feel like they’re on their own. It breaks my heart.’ Siris.

In 2018 Siris collaborated with Rethink Mental Illness after gaining their attention by inviting them to one of his previous exhibitions. Alongside Stuart Hellingsworth and Joe Haynes who work for Rethink mental Illness, Siris helped direct and curated 'Art of the Mind', an exhibition in Norwich showing works from artists from Rethink's various art groups around the country.

Following on from this he has been developing an arts class that will be hosted in Norwich and supported by Rethink to offer a place to come create and have fun for anyone struggling with their mental health, starting in April this year.

To date, through sharing his own journey from the worst times to his recovery he has been able to empower thousands through social media, creating a movement centred around his art and offers opportunities for other people in their communities to share their artwork with the public.

He has also attracted the attention of high profile artists, galleries, local press and TV and curators including Penelope Hines, a former curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum, all of whom have either offered opportunities or guidance and shown support in furthering his message through exposing his work.

In 2018 Siris' work was also discovered by agent Oliver Squirrell, who got in touch after experiencing Siris' work at the NUA degree show. The work at the show and on Siris' website resonated deeply with Oliver and he felt compelled to help Siris in his mission of challenging mental health stigmas and developing his artistic career further.

 

The Opportunity

Siris has now been offered the opportunity to exhibit his work at the Moniker Arts Fair, which is hosted on Broadway, Manhattan in New York.

Having reviewed his work and connected with his story, the arts fair got in touch and offered him a unique space. Moniker only select a handful of individual artists each year, the majority of the space is taken up by galleries around the world to showcase the best in urban contemporary arts.

This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for Siris, and potentially life changing. You can help get him there by backing this campaign!

 

Siris' Story (in his own words) 

I was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease as a baby when I was given a lifesaving blood transfusion I spent the first 15 years of my life in and out of hospitals and doctors surgeries and the treatment I received and the feeling of having no control or understanding of the things that were done to me have become to root cause of my mental health. At 19 I had my first panic attack. From there my life completely changed overnight. I went from being outdoorsy and adventuress to being confined in my bedroom afraid to leave and struggling to not hyperventilate constantly. This increased the bad relationship I had with my mum and she ended up asking me to leave. I didn’t have anywhere to go, between sofa surfing and sleeping rough I basically lost my mind.

When I was willing to take my life I remember thinking to myself if you are willing to end everything you must be willing to start again. I decided if I couldn’t find happiness within myself that I would help others and find meaning through that. Shortly after this I curated an exhibition for Rethink Mental Illness in my hometown. This provided an opportunity for artists from their art groups to share their work with the public the response the received and the conversations I had with the public regarding mental health was incredibly positive. It showed me how important art is and how it can be used to not only help people suffering but to educate the public and challenge their ideas of mental health, that I too had when I was younger. Challenging that fear and creating empathy as a replacement is powerful. It strengthens communities. I started sharing my work online and have gained a small following of people who often message me to thank me for speaking out and sharing my journey or that they’ve been able to connect with family members by showing my work and then opening up and talking with them about themselves.  Not having a home or a safe place to go when you rest is terrifying, but the hardest thing for me is not having a place to go that’s away from my mind. Art has given me that, it’s one of the very few things that brings silence to me.

I continue to make art because it has given me a voice, a purpose and taught me discipline, which in turn has strengthened my mind and allowed me to take the same approach I have used to learn to paint to tackle my recovery head-on.

During my degree, I have continued to develop my practice and push my personal boundaries. I’ve created a small community who seem to feel empowered by my work and that has encouraged me to continue to speak out and tackle the stigma those with mental illnesses face in our society. To give a voice not only to myself but the thousands of people out there who are suffering, feeling lost and let down by their country and community.

I have been focusing on raising the profile of myself as an artist and a mental health awareness advocate in an attempt to reach more people to share my story and my message. As a result of this I have been offered a place to exhibit at Moniker Arts fair in New York, Manhattan in May.

This is a dream come true, to be able to exhibit my works and share my message with people not only internationally, but on Broadway in New York, it’s unbelievable. This is not only an achievement for myself but also a great opportunity to help challenge mental health stigmas at an international level and create a personalised insight on topics that are incredibly important.

I would be extremely grateful of any support that you could provide with regards to promoting my crowdfunding campaign.

 

REWARDS

A3 Print available prints: When donating to this reward, please comment on the title of the Print you would like to receive: The options are shown below. 

Ashes



Faceless Maiden

Print details...

Archival giclée print

Printed on Hahnemuehle Photo Rag 308gsm (smooth)

A3 Print - Size Includes border for framing. 

Print may vary slightly due to variation in monitor screens

 

Signed Limited Edition Prints: When donating to this reward, please comment on the title of the Print you would like to receive: The options are shown below. 

La Muerte Seductora

Cruciation

The Weight of Silence

Print details...

Each image is limited to 30 copies 

Archival giclée print

printed on Hahnemuehle Photo Rag 308gsm (smooth)

A3 Print - Size Includes border for framing. 

Print may vary slightly due to variation in monitor screens

 

Private Tutoring:

Siris will offer 3 sessions of one-hour video calls one a week for three weeks to discuss your artistic work and current goals, critique and offer guidance. Prior to these calls, Siris will review your work and structure an individual plan to help you improve. The one-hour sessions will be spent going through this plan and reviewing your improvements. 

 

Private or public talk at your event:

Book Siris to come and discuss his work and his journey with mental health. Available only to those in the UK, excluding Ireland.

 

Join me in New York:

2x Tickets to the Moniker Arts Fair, a meet and greet and a tour by Siris and dinner at a 5-star restaurant (to be determined).  

Donators of this perk are to make their own way to New York

 

Original Piece of Art:

For a catalogue of available works please email: art@oliversquirrell.com 

 

Patron

Flights and 5-star accommodation in Manhattan for two.

2x entry to Moniker Arts Fair Meet and greet with Siris as well as a tour of the show

Dinner with Siris at a 5 star Resturant

Choice of original work whether from the available catalog, the workat the New York show or commissioning a new piece.

5% share of Siris' earnings for 12 months

Monthly contact with Siris via video call.

To discuss this reward in detail please make contact with art@oliversquirrell.com
story_txt:
Background
Living in Norwich, Siris is a strong advocate for mental health awareness. His mission is to challenge public stigmas and create opportunities for people to engage in their community through art.
Since 2017, Siris has created exhibitions that focus on offering a personal insight into living with mental illnesses, to create conversations in public spaces and normalise talking about mental health. 'I deliberately pick public spaces, where people go organically, I want to challenge people by bringing mental health into their day to day lives.' - Siris Hill.
Due to his health, working in a scheduled environment is near impossible for him. It’s his dream to become recognised as an artist and to be able to make a living from something he can do that fits around his health.
‘I just want to make enough to live on and to fund my ideas continue to do what drives me, which is improve the lives of others with mental illness by challenging stigmas and creating opportunities and events to engage people in the arts and to share the power of creativity for well-being with others. I have so many ideas, I just don’t want anyone else to feel like I have and to feel like they’re on their own. It breaks my heart.’ Siris.
In 2018 Siris collaborated with Rethink Mental Illness after gaining their attention by inviting them to one of his previous exhibitions. Alongside Stuart Hellingsworth and Joe Haynes who work for Rethink mental Illness, Siris helped direct and curated 'Art of the Mind', an exhibition in Norwich showing works from artists from Rethink's various art groups around the country.
Following on from this he has been developing an arts class that will be hosted in Norwich and supported by Rethink to offer a place to come create and have fun for anyone struggling with their mental health, starting in April this year.
To date, through sharing his own journey from the worst times to his recovery he has been able to empower thousands through social media, creating a movement centred around his art and offers opportunities for other people in their communities to share their artwork with the public.
He has also attracted the attention of high profile artists, galleries, local press and TV and curators including Penelope Hines, a former curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum, all of whom have either offered opportunities or guidance and shown support in furthering his message through exposing his work.
In 2018 Siris' work was also discovered by agent Oliver Squirrell, who got in touch after experiencing Siris' work at the NUA degree show. The work at the show and on Siris' website resonated deeply with Oliver and he felt compelled to help Siris in his mission of challenging mental health stigmas and developing his artistic career further.
 
The Opportunity
Siris has now been offered the opportunity to exhibit his work at the Moniker Arts Fair, which is hosted on Broadway, Manhattan in New York.
Having reviewed his work and connected with his story, the arts fair got in touch and offered him a unique space. Moniker only select a handful of individual artists each year, the majority of the space is taken up by galleries around the world to showcase the best in urban contemporary arts.
This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for Siris, and potentially life changing. You can help get him there by backing this campaign!
 
Siris' Story (in his own words) I was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease as a baby when I was given a lifesaving blood transfusion I spent the first 15 years of my life in and out of hospitals and doctors surgeries and the treatment I received and the feeling of having no control or understanding of the things that were done to me have become to root cause of my mental health. At 19 I had my first panic attack. From there my life completely changed overnight. I went from being outdoorsy and adventuress to being confined in my bedroom afraid to leave and struggling to not hyperventilate constantly. This increased the bad relationship I had with my mum and she ended up asking me to leave. I didn’t have anywhere to go, between sofa surfing and sleeping rough I basically lost my mind.When I was willing to take my life I remember thinking to myself if you are willing to end everything you must be willing to start again. I decided if I couldn’t find happiness within myself that I would help others and find meaning through that. Shortly after this I curated an exhibition for Rethink Mental Illness in my hometown. This provided an opportunity for artists from their art groups to share their work with the public the response the received and the conversations I had with the public regarding mental health was incredibly positive. It showed me how important art is and how it can be used to not only help people suffering but to educate the public and challenge their ideas of mental health, that I too had when I was younger. Challenging that fear and creating empathy as a replacement is powerful. It strengthens communities. I started sharing my work online and have gained a small following of people who often message me to thank me for speaking out and sharing my journey or that they’ve been able to connect with family members by showing my work and then opening up and talking with them about themselves.  Not having a home or a safe place to go when you rest is terrifying, but the hardest thing for me is not having a place to go that’s away from my mind. Art has given me that, it’s one of the very few things that brings silence to me.I continue to make art because it has given me a voice, a purpose and taught me discipline, which in turn has strengthened my mind and allowed me to take the same approach I have used to learn to paint to tackle my recovery head-on.During my degree, I have continued to develop my practice and push my personal boundaries. I’ve created a small community who seem to feel empowered by my work and that has encouraged me to continue to speak out and tackle the stigma those with mental illnesses face in our society. To give a voice not only to myself but the thousands of people out there who are suffering, feeling lost and let down by their country and community.I have been focusing on raising the profile of myself as an artist and a mental health awareness advocate in an attempt to reach more people to share my story and my message. As a result of this I have been offered a place to exhibit at Moniker Arts fair in New York, Manhattan in May.This is a dream come true, to be able to exhibit my works and share my message with people not only internationally, but on Broadway in New York, it’s unbelievable. This is not only an achievement for myself but also a great opportunity to help challenge mental health stigmas at an international level and create a personalised insight on topics that are incredibly important.I would be extremely grateful of any support that you could provide with regards to promoting my crowdfunding campaign. REWARDSA3 Print available prints: When donating to this reward, please comment on the title of the Print you would like to receive: The options are shown below. AshesFaceless MaidenPrint details...Archival giclée printPrinted on Hahnemuehle Photo Rag 308gsm (smooth)A3 Print - Size Includes border for framing. Print may vary slightly due to variation in monitor screens Signed Limited Edition Prints: When donating to this reward, please comment on the title of the Print you would like to receive: The options are shown below. La Muerte SeductoraCruciationThe Weight of SilencePrint details...Each image is limited to 30 copies Archival giclée printprinted on Hahnemuehle Photo Rag 308gsm (smooth)A3 Print - Size Includes border for framing. Print may vary slightly due to variation in monitor screens Private Tutoring:Siris will offer 3 sessions of one-hour video calls one a week for three weeks to discuss your artistic work and current goals, critique and offer guidance. Prior to these calls, Siris will review your work and structure an individual plan to help you improve. The one-hour sessions will be spent going through this plan and reviewing your improvements.  Private or public talk at your event:Book Siris to come and discuss his work and his journey with mental health. Available only to those in the UK, excluding Ireland. Join me in New York:2x Tickets to the Moniker Arts Fair, a meet and greet and a tour by Siris and dinner at a 5-star restaurant (to be determined).  Donators of this perk are to make their own way to New York Original Piece of Art:For a catalogue of available works please email: art@oliversquirrell.com  PatronFlights and 5-star accommodation in Manhattan for two.2x entry to Moniker Arts Fair Meet and greet with Siris as well as a tour of the showDinner with Siris at a 5 star ResturantChoice of original work whether from the available catalog, the workat the New York show or commissioning a new piece.5% share of Siris' earnings for 12 monthsMonthly contact with Siris via video call.To discuss this reward in detail please make contact with art@oliversquirrell.com

story:
CONCEPT
 The Mexican American 'Welcome Wall' will be a 2000 ft long physical wall along the US/Mexico border, designed by artists and activists to be a conceptual message board for an ongoing discussion about the wall, border, wildlife and immigration issues. A temporary art installation to fuel the resistance against Trump's racist monument.

TIME FRAME
 Ron will start building this spring and the wall will stay up till 2020 Election night. On Election night he will auction the different sections. Part of the proceeds will go to wild life charities, indigenous communities and non-profits. 

ART
 Ron made original limited pieces of art you can only get through this crowdfunding campaign. 

MONARCH BUTTERFLY



Monarch Butterfly spray paint and oil paint on faux brick - 24"x24" limited edition of 100. Signed and numbered.

 

MOTHER SHOULD I BUILD A WALL?

Mother, Should I Build a Wall? (and get Mexico to pay for it) - 11"x14" Gilcee print with prisma colored embellishment, signed and numbered.

Trunk the Orange Elephant (purple edition)

Edition of 100. 50 pieces will be made available as premiums in the Go Fund Me Welcome Wall campaign for a donation of $100. I will also include The Rabbbits new CD, ELEPHANT. Thank you Ben at Retro 3-D! 

 

 


CERTIFICATE OF SPONSORSHIP
 
Certificate of sponsorship of the Tex Mex Welcome Wall - print. Signed.

PRELIMINARY DESIGN 
 The wall is designed to be build in plywood sections. Three sheets of plywood stacked on top of each other. The design was made so that Art can be created off site and easily shipped by means of a flatbed. Of course we encourage the artists to come to the site and make the art locally.


 

COST
To cover the cost of material and labor of every 100 foot section of wall we need $15,000.  Additionally we can pay the artists a stipend and cover their stay at the border. We are initially starting with 20 artists.  $300.000 for a 2000 ft section. 

As soon as we have enough money to build one section Ron English will head to the border. 

“A wall is the perfect physical and metaphoric gift from a cult leader to his followers. It positions him as the great protector of his chosen people from the unwashed, unenlightened others!” ~Ron English

story:
Overview

Chrome & Toned LLC is the creation of Crystal Bogan and Samantha Wilson. Chrome & Toned is a dance studio located in Little Rock, Arkansas specializing in all forms of movement related to performance and pole. Chrome & Toned’s unique, holistic approach to artistic expression caters to physical, mental and emotional support where ALL are welcome.

 

How You Can Help

It’s one thing to have a great idea. It’s another thing entirely to execute such an idea. We have put in a great deal of work to determine the essential elements needed to give our customers an amazing and unmatched experience. We are only as strong as the community and tribe (#communitribe) that supports us so, any amount you feel inclined to donate is a blessing and very appreciated. As professionals, we want to be transparent with our supporters so you can ensure your funds are going to necessities and not luxuries. Any and all funds received will go to the following to make our studio as efficient and safe as possible:

  • Studio Quality Mirrors;
  • Music Licensing;
  • Insurance (Health and Liability);
  • Soundbars;
  • Televisions;
  • Poles;
  • Crashpads;
  • Yoga Mats & Blocks;
  • PPE;
  • Studio Rent;
  • Lighting;
  • Flooring;
  • Furniture;
  • Security System.

(*List is not exhaustive) Customer satisfaction and safety are our main priorities and your assistance will allow us to make that happen.

 

What You Get

Your gift means everything to us! As a result, it is our pleasure to gift you with a few items of appreciation.

  • Brass 38 ($50 Donation) – Personalized, handwritten note of gratitude from owners and custom Chrome & Toned drawstring bag
  • Titanium 40 ($100 Donation) – Previous package + Chrome & Toned T-Shirt
  • Silicone 42 ($200 Donation) – All previous packages + Chrome & Toned Backpack
  • Steel 45 ($450 Donation) – All previous packages + 3 free classes of your choice (in-person or virtual)
  • Chrome 48 ($750 Donation) – All previous packages + 5 free classes of your choice (in-person or virtual)
  • Toned 50 ($1,000 Donation) – All previous packages + custom hydro-dipped Pleasers dance shoes (colors of your choice)

 

Your Impact

If you’ve ever dreamed about starting your own business, then you know how we feel. We have breathed life into this company. It occupies our thoughts and our daily decisions. While we have done a significant amount of work on our end, it is difficult to press forward without assistance from the communities and audience we intend to diligently serve. By assisting us with our dream, you are possibly making someone else’s dream of feeling accepted, appreciated and unapologetically themselves a reality.

 

Risks & Challenges

We believe transparency is extremely important. As a result, we would be remiss if we did not mention the risks associated with this new venture. We cannot guarantee that we will appeal to everyone. What we can say is we will offer an experience that is unmatched. No one can do what we do or provide the energy and personality that we can. While risk is always present, we have the confidence—and hope we’ve instilled the same in you—that this business will be successful.

 

Additional Ways to Help

Funds are a blessing, but you can bless us in a variety of other ways. First, you can share this campaign with all of your friends and family. Second, you can like, comment and repost our social media page and posts. Third, take a class! We’re continuously working to create content for EVERYONE. Fourth, rent poles from us! We have stage poles available for your next event! Fifth, RENT OUR SPACE!! Book our studio for your next photo shoot, bachelorette party, or audition. Sixth, interact with us on social media. Don’t be afraid to send us a message to let us know how we can better serve you as a company and studio or just to leave some words of encouragement.

Thank you for all of your generosity,

Chrome & Toned

Overview

Your paw friend is always wanting attention? Always wanting you to play with him/her, but you are busy or in the middle of something? We've got your back! Our multi-feature Boba Tea Plushie will keep your pet entertained!

 

  Coming from a Taiwanese/Belgian family, I have always loved bubble tea since a young age, I would patiently be waiting every summer to go back to Taiwan to drink bubble tea at night markets every single day for 2 whole months!

And on top of that, I have always loved animals since a young age!

Fast forward to today, I have a new family member: an Australian Shepherd puppy!

I decided to name him Boba (short for bubble tea), and this whole idea of making a toy started when we went to have bubble tea together when Boba was only 2 and a half months old. 

We decided to take a few pictures of him with the bubble tea, and saw that he had pocked a little hole on the side to lick the milk tea. He was definitely loving it and it was so cute. At that moment, I knew I had to make a bubble tea plushie toy for pets!

Fast forward to today, he is now 6 months old and 10kgs heavier, loving his own Boba toy!

 

If you’re like me, you buy so many toys trying to entertain your dogs but there is never one toy that satisfies them for long. 

Some dogs prefer soft plushies to hard ones; some prefer ropes to balls… There’s not one toy that is perfect. 

So… Your prayers have been heard! This bubble tea plushie is made of everything they can possibly love!

 

Having a really smart and high energy dog, I am always thinking of how to exercise him not just physically but also mentally.

“A tired dog is a happy dog” as they all say. 

This toy offers your furry friend hours of entertainment and the opportunity to use their mental energy by trying to retrieve the 2 tapioca shaped balls inside the bubble tea. Entertaining and fun way to exercise and stimulate their brain right?? And that's not all!

 

1) The texture of the straw is strong and hard, as it has a rope inside it.

2) The bubble tea plushie has a softer texture.

3) One of the tapioca ball is soft and squishy with a squeaker inside.

4) The other tapioca ball has a hard spiked squeaky ball inside for a totally different texture.

 

Strong and Durable plushie

Tired of buying toys that break in 5mins?

This plushie has been made with a double layered fabric and is inverse stitched. Meaning your furry friend will not be able to break it as easily as normal toy plushies!

100 % Machine washable

Dirty plushie? No worries, just put it in the washing machine for 15mins gentle wash (no more than 30 degrees C)! You’ll have a new looking toy once again!  

CERTIFIED NON-TOXIC TOY

Our plushie is made with non-toxic materials, safe for your family and paw friend!

 

 

 

This toy is not to be given to your pet without supervision, please keep an eye on your pet while playing with any toys. Please remember that no toy is indestructible.  Remove damaged toys immediately.

 

 We will start the production of the plushies as soon as our Indiegogo campaign ends, and it takes usually about a month for the production to be done. As soon as they are done, we will ship them out to our distributors around the world and they will then be shipped out to you.

Please note that the shipping we charge is a standard untracked shipping method. This shipping service does not provide tracking and is shipped at your own risk. Tracked shipping is available as an "add-on" at check-out if you prefer to be able to track your package.
 

I am now starting this project with only one plushie but I hope to be able to share more of my pet toy designs in the future with you all! 

If you want to see more of them, please help and support this project!

Thank you all so much for your time and your support!

Ann & Boba

story:
Who?

I'm a young interiors and furniture designer from Lithuania. I graduated from Glasgow School of Art and Politecnico di Milano, studying Bachelors of Interior Design. At the moment I'm working as a freelance interior designer on various projects. It is my dream to participate in such an event as Salone del Mobile as a furniture designer and I would be so happy if you could help me to make it happen! 

 

What is my project? 

I'm going to exhibit my piece of furniture - a dressing table at the Salone del Mobile event at Lambrate Design District on the 9 - 14 April 2019. 

 

Where will the money go?

I am raising money to fund this project which is divided into these parts: 

 

  • Production costs - 1100 €

The dressing table is made of natural oak wood combined with brass legs and frame for the mirrors, leather tabletop and porcelain knobs for the drawers.

Everything is handmade by local artisans and porcelain knobs are handmade by me. 

 

  • Participation fee - 1305,4€

This amount covers the fee required for the registration and the exhibition stand.  

 

  • The patent - 600€

This amount covers the fee of registering my design with a lawyer to protect the concept in the European Union. 

 

If I'm lucky enough to raise beyond that amount I will use the money to cover all the extra costs such as transportation fees, stand design, setting up the website, ordering business cards and all the costs related to the travel - plane ticket to Milan, accommodation, etc. 

 

How do I thank you?

Every little helps so I decided to make little gifts for my backers:

For 10€, I will send you a digital personalized thank you image via email.

For 15€, I will send you a personalized and signed postcard from Milan. 

For 50€, I will send you a handmade porcelain object of your choice. It will be handmade by me. 

For 100€, omg, I will love you to the moon and back and send you a handmade porcelain object of your choice as well as a personalized and signed postcard from Milan.

All the gifts will be sent after Salone del Mobile.

 

 See you guys at Salone del Mobile - Lambrate Design District on the 9-14th of April! 

♥ LET'S MAKE IT HAPPEN!!! ♥ 

with love,

 

Auste

story:
My Story

Few people are lucky enough to have been blessed with both the means to hone their craft, the passion to shape it, and the exposure to make a difference in this world. Art. Passion. Love.

Even fewer are given a second chance to pursue their passions. I am proud to say that for the second time in my life I feel empowered to try and, if the universe wills it, to impact the world around me through my art.

After earning my theatre degree at UCLA, I traveled to Turkey to rediscover my roots since I’m half Turkish and half American. I ended up working professionally there as both an actress for the State Theatre and a faculty member/director for a conservatory.  Art. Passion. Love.

Due to a set of events best described as “larger than life” I decided to fight for the right to adopt as a single woman in a country that did not allow it.  After changing some laws and adopting my son, I relocated back to the United States. I needed stable income but still wanted to feel passion, so I chose nonprofits and then went into Human Resources. I could continue to help and serve others while growing as a business leader. Humans. Passion. Love.

Then tragedy set in when my mother was diagnosed with cancer. As I cared for her and continued to work, I found art once again. I started creating miniature worlds in lanterns – I found that I could protect these worlds from tragedy.  I, also, started painting and the colors I used became an extension of my being.

Struggles in life continued but in the quiet moments, I realized that by focusing on my passions in a new way, my art hobby had blossomed into a small business. I was amazed when someone liked one of my creations enough to take it into their home to look at every day! Wow, this still amazes me.

Then more setbacks for all of us!  COVID19.  Lost my job.  As I looked for work in panic and distress, it would all disappear in the moments when I created.  Art. Passion. Love.

With the support and love of family and friends but against their sound advice (!), I have decided to make this an even bigger part of my life.

My Art, The Goal & What You Get

My creations range from abstract acrylic paintings to jewelry created from those paintings to three-dimensional works through my miniatures. Colorful. Hopeful. Jovial. 

We may not always be able to keep tragedy away but sometimes out of tragedy can come a greater Hope. Passion. Love.  

The initial seed of $3000 can help me share my art with the world.

As you read my story, I hope you see that I have demonstrated skills but, most importantly, tenacity and persistence. I created a business plan to make this dream comes true. Now I just need some help. The first part of the plan is to create a professional website and implement other marketing strategies to show (to the world and myself!) that I can create a business out of Art. Passion. Love.

If you choose to support this project, aside from the perks provided, I will keep you up-to-date as I work through this dream and, hopefully, my success can be an inspiration for you or others to ‘work’ through their passions.

Together, let's show the world that we can create a better world, and a business, through art!

Other Ways to Help

I understand not everyone is in a position to help financially.  Whether you are able to help financially or not, please share my mission with your circle of influence to help the campaign.  A little share can go a long way. 

*Share this campaign on your Instagram, Facebook or other social media channels! (Make sure to use the INDIEGOGO share tools.)

* You can also follow me on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/Art-by-Lale- or at https://www.instagram.com/Art.by.Lale/ & tag me when sharing the campaign.
story_txt:
My Story
Few people are lucky enough to have been blessed with both the means to hone their craft, the passion to shape it, and the exposure to make a difference in this world. Art. Passion. Love.
Even fewer are given a second chance to pursue their passions. I am proud to say that for the second time in my life I feel empowered to try and, if the universe wills it, to impact the world around me through my art.
After earning my theatre degree at UCLA, I traveled to Turkey to rediscover my roots since I’m half Turkish and half American. I ended up working professionally there as both an actress for the State Theatre and a faculty member/director for a conservatory.  Art. Passion. Love.
Due to a set of events best described as “larger than life” I decided to fight for the right to adopt as a single woman in a country that did not allow it.  After changing some laws and adopting my son, I relocated back to the United States. I needed stable income but still wanted to feel passion, so I chose nonprofits and then went into Human Resources. I could continue to help and serve others while growing as a business leader. Humans. Passion. Love.
Then tragedy set in when my mother was diagnosed with cancer. As I cared for her and continued to work, I found art once again. I started creating miniature worlds in lanterns – I found that I could protect these worlds from tragedy.  I, also, started painting and the colors I used became an extension of my being.
Struggles in life continued but in the quiet moments, I realized that by focusing on my passions in a new way, my art hobby had blossomed into a small business. I was amazed when someone liked one of my creations enough to take it into their home to look at every day! Wow, this still amazes me.
Then more setbacks for all of us!  COVID19.  Lost my job.  As I looked for work in panic and distress, it would all disappear in the moments when I created.  Art. Passion. Love.
With the support and love of family and friends but against their sound advice (!), I have decided to make this an even bigger part of my life.
My Art, The Goal & What You Get
My creations range from abstract acrylic paintings to jewelry created from those paintings to three-dimensional works through my miniatures. Colorful. Hopeful. Jovial. 
We may not always be able to keep tragedy away but sometimes out of tragedy can come a greater Hope. Passion. Love.  
The initial seed of $3000 can help me share my art with the world.
As you read my story, I hope you see that I have demonstrated skills but, most importantly, tenacity and persistence. I created a business plan to make this dream comes true. Now I just need some help. The first part of the plan is to create a professional website and implement other marketing strategies to show (to the world and myself!) that I can create a business out of Art. Passion. Love.
If you choose to support this project, aside from the perks provided, I will keep you up-to-date as I work through this dream and, hopefully, my success can be an inspiration for you or others to ‘work’ through their passions.
Together, let's show the world that we can create a better world, and a business, through art!
Other Ways to Help
I understand not everyone is in a position to help financially.  Whether you are able to help financially or not, please share my mission with your circle of influence to help the campaign.  A little share can go a long way. 
*Share this campaign on your Instagram, Facebook or other social media channels! (Make sure to use the INDIEGOGO share tools.)
* You can also follow me on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/Art-by-Lale- or at https://www.instagram.com/Art.by.Lale/ & tag me when sharing the campaign.

story:
About us...

We are the owners of Viridian Art Academy,

Bronwyn Birk & Maria Galloway.

We are both visual art instructors in local elementary schools. As public schools struggle with cutbacks, art programs are often targeted even though studies have shown time and time again that participation in creative activities increases critical thinking and problem solving skills. We were inspired to create a community art school. We teach art classes for children, teen and adults, and art workshops & camps. Our instructors are made up of several local artists who provide their unique perspective in our weekly classes. In addition to teaching hundreds each week, we are preparing a non-profit foundation to provide visual art programs and art supplies for schools with out the necessary funding. 


Since our creation in 2011 we have quickly become a thriving part of our community. We have outgrown our current studio in which we have filled every inch. We jumped at a fantastic opportunity to move down the street to a larger building on February 1st.


18709 Topham st, Tarzana, Ca 91335

In our new location we will be able to employ additional local artists to teach classes and specialized workshops, we will have a separate teen & adult studio space and offer open studio time for artists in our community to create in a social setting. We will be able to expand our curriculum to offer classes in acrylic, clay and toddler & pre-k art classes. We will have social art events for students and the community. Help us become the community art center the west valley is lacking. Your contribution will help to make this a reality.


Why we need your help...

We are planning to move without interrupting our students art education, which means we have four weeks to furnish 2 new studio spaces for teens, adults, and kids. We also want to hire new teachers before the move so they are trained and ready to start teaching as soon as our new facility is opened. 

Viridian Art Academy has set the goal of raising $8,500. With these funds we will allocate $5,000 to cover the necessary equipment for our new teen & adult studio space and little kids studio space (easles, art benches, tables, lighting, stools), 2 exterior signs for our building and moving expenses. $3,500 will be used for training and curriculum development for 2 local artists to teach weekly classes. Any extra funds will be directly donated to our non-profit, Viridian Arts Foundation, (401(c)(3) pending), to provide visual art programs for schools without the supplies and necessary funding.


What you get...

We have created some great perks for our contributors. If you can not contribute financially at this time, you may know others that can. Please, please share this by email or social media sites, like Facebook and instagram.  Ask your family and friends to help.  The more people that hear about this the closer we will get to our goal. You can also help by leaving a comment on this page, which helps boost our ranking on Indiegogo's pages.


The impact of you contribution...

We care about our community and providing a space for young and old to unleash their creativity as they learn and grow. As we continue to grow we strive to provide art programs for our community. The arts have such an impact on people of all ages. We see it happen everyday. We are proud sponsors of our local schools and are committed to providing art enrichment programs for students. 


For more information, please visit our website at www.viridianart.com

story:
Mettiamo in moto La Giostra



Se siete artisti e contadini nell'anima e volete un progetto di arti e orti da seguire in campagna vicino alla città, a Roma dove coltivare i vostri ortaggi, co-creare e presentare le vostre attività, fatevi avanti con un contributo... 

Visto che non ci sono camion eolici o elettrici dobbiamo  affittare un camion normale per trasportare le prime due strutture che consentiranno l'inizio delle attività della Giostra a Marzo 2015. Mi presento:



Mi chiamo Emiliano Campagnola sono un attore e regista e da qualche anno sto sviluppando un progetto che si chiama Ecovillaggio La Giostra Vite9.                          Un Ecovillaggio creativo è un luogo che sa donare esperienze, saperi e uno spazio dove stare, provare, confrontarsi...
L'intento è di unire la creatività artistica, il vivere naturale, le nuove tecnologie, verso l'autosufficienza energetica, idrica e alimentare. Un luogo dove formarsi e sperimentare queste attitudini.
Uno spazio dove mettere in rapporto sinergico vita e arte. 


L'avvio di questo motore di fantasia alla Giostra , concretamente potrà avere inizio a breve, manca solo un piccolo passaggio, il trasporto dei materiali sul posto. Questa primavera è previsto l'arrivo di due strutture semipermanenti: uno Chapiteau (tenda da circo francese) e il materiale del Big Bambù, (Opera-installazione del Macro). 

Più info sullo Chapiteau sul sito - Theenthusiastics

Lo Chapiteau col suo rosso fiammante è uno spazio scenico, è festa, è magia. Al momento si trova in Sicilia e per farlo arrivare dobbiamo affittare una motrice per un rimorchio che arriverà via mare a Civitavecchia intorno al 20 marzo in tempo per il Solstizio di Primavera. Con il vostro aiuto potremmo far nascere insieme lo Chapiteau alla Giostra con una iniziatica esperienza di allestimento.



Il Big Bambù è un opera dei due artisti gemelli americani Mike e Doug Starn esposta per 3 anni all'entrata del Macro a Testaccio. Abbiamo proposto ai responsabili della struttura di prenderci cura di tutto il materiale che sarà smontato a breve, per rigenerarlo in altre strutture che ne mantengano il valore. Rigenerando il meraviglioso materiale che compone l'opera, per realizzare strutture utili all'Ecovillaggio e altre creazioni. Tutto il bambù sarà materiale per un laboratorio di progettazione e costruzione tenuto da Stefan Pollak di AK0, architettura a chilometri zero.

Per questa fase imminente è necessario raccogliere 3500€ 

il soldi raccolti serviranno per:

Trasporto Chapiteau 1000€
Preparazione terreno e allacci per lo Chapiteau 500€
Trasporto Big Bambù 1000€
Preparazione terreno e stoccaggio Bambù 500€
Preparazione casetta di appoggio per lavori e laboratori 500€
Se non vuoi usare PayPal:  iban IT65D0760105138276650776653
I costi degli affitti dei camion possono essere differenti da quelli indicati, garantiamo comunque tutti i fondi raccolti in questa fase saranno utilizzati per le spese di avvio e messa in moto della Giostra.
In cambio di una donazione offriamo passeggiate, spuntini, seminari, orti, spettacoli, feste...  


E molti altri doni che riceverete o verrete a ritirare alla Giostra come il poter coltivare i propri ortaggi in un ambiente amico e festeggiante durante i solstizi e gli equinozi , dove creare la propria bacchetta magica ad ogni età, dove trovare amuleti nascosti, dove potrete degustare o meno quello che arriverà dai carri e carretti in giro per prodotti buoni, ci dispiace un po' dover dare la scintilla al motore della Giostra ancora col petrolio, che come dice il saggio; "Non ci prendiamo per il culo, è finito!" 
La Transizione è da queste cose che comincia e da questi luoghi si impara a farlo reciprocamente.




English summary
The Joust, an Art Camp in Rome, a creative Ecovillage, to start has to carry the Chapiteau and the material of the Big Bamboo .
My name is Emiliano Campagnola, I used to work as actor and director in cinema and theatre. I got a piece of land very close to Rome, a beautifull countryside near via Appia Antica; La Giostra. I'm trying to realize a dream : Ecovillagio vite9, a place to experience an alternative lifestyle within the nature ,an EcoArtCamp, to take care about people and earth.  We are about to receive a big quantity of Bambù material, very big, it was part of the Big Bambù, an art installation realized by Mike e Doug Starn for Macro museum and city of Rome. Plus at the beginning of the spring we are waiting for a Chapiteau to come: a big circus tent made by a french artisan.
  • We ask you for a contribution to cover the transporting of  the Chapiteau and the Big Bambù to LaGiostra
You can come when you want

story:
My name is ally and i am a stay at home mommy of two. Guess what i want to do this year? Make daddy stay at home with the kiddies on the weekend so that i can get some freedom on the road and hit up the...awesome handmade shows and crafty markets MUAH HA HA

BUT i need a hand. I need to buy supplies. I want to buy some lovely soap supplies from a mail order company in the neighbouring town. I want to buy some cute unique soap moulds and funky wood and glass jewellery supplies from favoured etsy shops. I want to buy some quality felt and candle materials from businesses two hours away. I want to buy local origami and scrapbook paper.

I've already applied to three handmade shows, Artisan Dreams, She Creates...One of a Kind, and the Mama Market, and been accepted to all three!!! I am also applying to The Mother of all Craft Shows and The Hand of Man. Then I will bunker down and work work work!

With four vendor and craft shows under my humble belt, I am ready to take on bigger ambitions. I have already begun by opening up my soap shop Iris & Luna Soaps on Etsy, http://www.irislunasoaps.etsy.com, and Facebook, http://www.facebook.com/irislunasoaps, and at my shows i started dabbling in selling my origami. I have made necklaces for family members and i am inspired by new designs all the time. I also realized at my shows that a lot of the people interested in my soaps would love the same smells in candles! I also have a growing fascination with all things made out of felt, first thing being donuts HAHAHA

SO if you will believe in me, i will make this all happen and in return i will pay you in fine handmade by yours truly goods :-)

story:
Short Summary

My name is Amanda Page Stephens. A large group of my friends call me APS and I'm a mixed media artist, raised by an artist and his muse in Norfolk, Virginia.
I love making my art with the public so I'm honored that I've been invited to set up a table at South By South West (SXSW). SXSW is a music, and film festival in Austin TX that is being held March 13-22. Check it out at www.sxsw.com. At that table, I hope to engage the public by having them participate in my art making process. My targeted audience will be children and I will be sharing this experience with adults too. 

What I Need & What You Get

I have arranged for a free place to stay.   (Thanks Emma and Phillip!!!!)
I need funds for art supplies, airfare and food. If I could raise additional money to cover the week that I'll be taking off of work, that would be great. I'm taking a roll of canvas so all I'll need is paint costing around $30. The plane ticket is $350 plus the cost of bringing luggage. I've estimated $150 for groceries and maybe 1 meal out.  I'll be taking 4 days/roughly 40 hours off of work which equals around a $350 pay check. 
The perks you can choose from range from a little sticker collection of art to an actual vinyl sticker stating "Love, APS". That sticker is a statement for the world to see that I LOVE YOU and appreciate any contribution. You could also get a variety of artwork in the form of mailed postcards to actual paintings made at SXSW. At the highest donation level you get to dictate the exact size of the painting (up to 3ft X 3ft) and your preferred color scheme. 
In the event that I don't raise enough money to cover a trip to Austin, the funds will go towards a summer festival trip in Portland, ME.   (Of course, you can follow my blog to see how this goes.....)

The Impact

I will not be making any money on this venture. It is purely a way to bring this unique experience the audience of SXSW to join-in and get creative. 
I've set up art-making stations at numerous events such as CRAFTED at O'Connors Brewery, The Renewal Art Show at The Warehouse, at the opening weekend of Alchemy's Pop The Trunk event and various other arts and craft events in Coastal Virginia. The children embrace the projects and dive right in. Some adults eagerly contribute but others are very apprehensive. They state "I can't even draw a stick figure". I then explain that there's no messing it up to take the pressure off. That breaks the ice and art is made. When the adults walk away, I hope they gain a new creative outlook.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't monetarily contribute, please spread the word instead by sharing on your social media platforms. Maybe someone in your circle of friends would be interesting in contributing.

story:
About

We are very excited for this new product line because it comes from a year of development and perfection of glass mosaic manufacturing techniques. What makes FaceMe pendants innovative is that they are unique and exclusive pieces of design, customized specially for each client from the creative vision of the artist based on the face of the future owner.


Project

The purpose of this campaign is not only to complete the development of a new product line but also the creation of the official online store as well as the broadcast channels and advertising necessary.

With your support we will be able to give the Talisman and FaceMe series the final touch that is fundamental for this pieces, adding a silver edging and a little ring to give them a nice finish.

We will also create the online IkoMozis Art store and work on the advertising and social channels to generate presence around the world.

   


IkoMozis Art

IkoMozis Art is the result of four years of work on perfecting the technique of glass mosaic combined with art and design.

Currently, in IkoMozis Art, unique decorative art pieces are created from our own designs, custom requests and reinterpretation of classic art pieces.

IkoMozis Art pieces reinterpreting Water Serpents (Gustav Klimt), Starry night (Van Gogh) and El Bañador (Pablo Picasso).

FaceMe series

The new product line will consist of two series. The Big FaceMe and little FaceMe pendants, this series come from a unique and custom design made by me, based on the face of the future owner and are available in two presentations:

1.The little FaceMe pendants measure approximately 2 ½ "x 2 ½" . In this presentation the hair is cut piece by piece and the face is carved and painted by hand, carrying a metal edging and a little silver ring.



2.The big FaceMe measures approximately 7 ½" x 7 ½". In these pieces the hair and face are more detailed and its manufacture is more complex, carrying a metal edging and a support so it can be hung or placed on any surface.

These FaceMe are perfect for personalizing spaces, can be embedded in a cabinet, or just above the bedside table with a candle at the base.

The possibilities are as many as objects surrounding you.

                                  


Talisman series (Special Edition)

The Talisman series is a special edition for the perks of indiegogo, currently has four models and all the designs will be completed by the end of February, it will feature 10 talisman models crafted in glass mosaic, each one measuring approximately 1 ¾" x 1 ¾" (with a metal edging and a little silver ring).


Our special way to say thank you



Ikomozis Art wallpapers.


Customized FaceMe style designs.


*Keep in mind that some perks including the Talisman, Big FaceMe and FaceMe pendants are crafted by hand, therefore a certain period of time is required for the elaboration process.


OBJECTIVES

In April we will start the edging manufacturing, It will be necessary to contact artisans from the region of Taxco to co-work with them on the process (Taxco is the place where the finest silver is made).

After the most suitable strategy is decided for the manufacturing process we will be on a testing stage to ensure that pendants are fully wearable and resistant.

If everything goes fine by May we will start with the production process.

The online store will be ready to open by August as well as the appropriate advertising channels to generate presence around the world.


The artist

A. Lucrecia Vélez is the founder of IkoMozis Art. She has gained recognition throughout her art career exposing at international Biennales and local contests.


If you have questions or want to know more about this project you can contact me at:

escribamonos@hotmail.com
zoyalguien@gmail.com

ikomozisart@hotmail.com



If you like my work and you cannot assist me financially, please add me to your social networks so more people can know this campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Hey everyone, we are Gemma and Harry. We are artistic, creative people from different backgrounds. Gemma designs and makes furniture and clothing. Harry is an urban artist, originally street art, before moving onto gallery shows and canvas work.

Our dream is to open up a studio, Studio 263, not only so we have enough space for ourselves to work but also to get others involved with all forms of art. We want others to get the amazing satisfaction we get when making art. Secondly, we would also like this space to hold galleries for up and coming artist, and finally we would like to have an art supplies store involved in this project.

We have spent a number of hour working out this project and even more hours dreaming about getting it up an running.  And thats why we are here. We need your help to turn our dream into a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

The £13,000 will be used as followed:

-£5500, stock the art supplies store.

-£4500, 1st months rent and deposit.

-£3000, building work to create the spaces.


Below is a couple of pics of the perks we are offering in return for your amazing donations, which will hopefully all add up to gaining Studio 263.

30cmx30cm Lips Canvas - £85


Stickers x3 - £6

30cmx30cm Character Canvas - £85

30cmx30cm Personalised Canvas - £85

90cmx90cm Personalised Canvas - £400

Fat cap paint can with lips - £15

Fat cap paint can with character - £15

These are just a couple of the perks you can get with your great donation. All Perks will be signed and are one offs. They will be sent to you within two months of the final day. With regards to the personalised perks, we will try our hardest to create what you want, but please bare in mind the size of the canvas and what you would like put on it.

The Impact

This studio will help us both in our arts by providing us with enough space to carry out work without falling over each other. Currently we both work in a single garage,  full of art materials as well as general garage junk. The studio will also provide us with warmth and correct lighting, which we don't have in the garage.

The other purpose for the studio is to involve others in the community, to create art. We would aim to run classes in various fields for the community to get involved in. This space will also allow for art shows, bringing up and coming artists work into the public eye and showing the potential of their work.

The final part of Studio 263 will be the art supply store. This will have a range of different art materials. However, the main products will be for street art. These products are nearly non existent in Andorra and the surrounding areas. Having these products will bring people in from the surrounding areas, bring in new artists and possible gallery shows.

Risks & Challenges

The risks we have opening up Studio 263, is the art itself. Street art and urban art is only just beginning to be recognised in Andorra, with the movement in its infancy. We would love to be at the forefront of this movement. 

A challenge we have is the population of Andorra. With only around 80,000 people in the country, we will try and attract other artists from the surrounding areas of France and Spain to use our art store, gallery and studio. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would like to firstly thank you for viewing our campaign and any donations are greatly appreciated. We understand that not everyone can donate, so if you could please just make some noise about our campaign via the sharing links or through your own social media, that would be amazing. 

If you can't see something you want or the one you wanted has already sold out, then please head to the website www.artbyarii.com. To see what else we have to offer.

Thank you.

story:
Background on the Mural and the WPA

The Milford Arts Council, a 501(c)(3), located in New Haven County, Connecticut, is raising funds to restore a historical WPA (Works Progress Administration) mural.  A professional art conservator is needed to save the mural from further deterioration and restore it to its original appearance. The mural will then be framed and installed in the Milford Public Library. 

Some background information:

  • Commissioned in 1937, 'We Shall Pass This Way But Once', designed by Louis Agostini & painted by Frank Rutkoski was installed on April 2, 1940 on a wall at the entrance of Milford's Central Grammar School.
  • A 7’8” x 5’ portion of the mural (oil on canvas mounted on fiberboard) was saved before the school was demolished in 1986. The fragment depicts male students engaged in a variety of activities with two buildings in the background; Plymouth Church (demolished in the 1950s) and what appears to be the Sanford-Bristol House (c. 1789 house still in existence).
  • For the past decade the mural was stored behind a filing cabinet in a Milford government building, hidden from public view and slowly deteriorating. The mural has recently been carefully moved to a safe and secure space, where it is laid flat.
  • The mural artists were employed by the WPA (Works Progress Administration), WPA (Works Progress Administration), which was the first major attempt at government patronage of the visual arts in the United States and the most extensive and influential of the visual arts projects conceived during the Depression of the 1930s by the administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
  • The WPA employed struggling out-of-work artists during the Great Depression. Artists competed to create murals in public properties such as post offices, schools, museums, hospitals, housing projects & colleges. A few famous WPA artists include Grant Wood, Mark Rothko, and Jackson Pollock.
  • In Connecticut, it is estimated that 160 artists created over 5,000 pieces of WPA art.  According to the State of Connecticut's WPA Art Inventory list, eight artworks were created in/for Milford, however only three can be located, including this mural.

                                                                                                                                                            What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise funds to hire a professional art conservator to restore the mural and to frame it so it can be hung at the Milford Public Library for the public to enjoy once again. We have bids from two professional art conservators with experience conserving WPA murals. If we do not raise the funds through this campaign, our committee will continue to fundraise.
  • This art belongs to US- the PEOPLE. Let's conserve this Milford treasure for the public to enjoy once again! Any contribution helps, whether you can give $20, $50, or higher. We are offering some "perks" to donors who can give $100 to $1,000.

The Impact

  • This historic artwork will be saved! By restoring the mural, Milford will join many towns in the U.S. that have already restored their WPA murals, which are regarded as culturally significant works of art.

  • Inspire other towns to save their WPA art.

  • It will hang in the Milford Public Library, where the public can once again admire it.

  • Lectures, tours, and other educational programs can be planned to teach students and community members about WPA art.

  • Preserves the visual memory of Milford. Ex: The church in the mural no longer exists.

Challenges

  • Only a fragment of the mural exists, which is what will be conserved. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share a link to our Indiegogo page.
  • Like our Facebook page.
  • Write to a local Milford newspaper and be an advocate for saving the mural.

story:
www.calicalientedesigns.com

My name is Marina Aguilera, I founded Cali Caliente Designs to represent our beautiful Latino community.

One of my fondest childhood memories is when my father would come home after a long hard day of work picking oranges. No matter how tired he was, he would sit down with his pocket knife and whittle a sharp pencil, dig up a scrap of paper and and teach me to draw. He was an artist in his own right and although he did not have the opportunity to pursue his art, he planted the seed and became my inspiration. Through him I learned to never forget my heritage. It is now my pleasure and my passion to offer you Latino inspired Greeting Cards. Thank you Gente, for your support. May we continue to grow and always represent.

LaArtista, Marina

Our time has come and we want our place in in the sun.

The sleeping giant has awoke. Our goal is to have you walk in to any store and be able to find an appropriate greeting card that suits your needs and connects you to your culture. Settle for nothing less. To achieve this we need funds to get the word out by attending trade shows, marketing, printing costs, advertising throughout the United States and developing future card lines.

Other Ways You Can Help

Gente,  support our cause by  buying  our product, telling your familia and your friends and spreading the love.

Gracias y Abrazos,

La Artista... 

Marina Aguilera

story:
What do Johns Hopkins University and Hospital, Greenmount Cemetery, the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, the Marine Commandant’s House in Washington D.C., the Maryland Zoo in Baltimore, and countless Baltimore-Washington streets, houses, businesses, monuments, and institutions have in common?  The answer is G. Krug & Son.



For the past 215 years, the blacksmith shop has been producing, preserving, and restoring ornamental ironwork in the Baltimore-Washington area and beyond.  For the past 4 years, we have been very actively trying to preserve the rich history that accompanies the blacksmith shop with G. Krug & Son Ironworks Museum.

Part of that preservation is making sure the building is still there, and we cannot do it without YOU..or a roof!


Like the image above shows, we are eventually looking at an almost $80,000 endeavor to make sure all of our leaky roof problems are dealt with, but right now we are focusing on the roof that is at the top of our four-story building (the one that houses all of our important records, drawings, and exhibits).  We are receiving a $19,000 loan from the Maryland Historical Trust, which leaves just a little over $6,000 for us to completely fund this project.

$6,000 is going to help preserve these beautiful works on paper that just so happen to be some of our past jobs.


$6,000 is going to help preserve our collection of tools, patterns, and objects to share with everyone who comes to visit our shop.


And, most importantly, $6,000 is going to guarantee that we can continue to share Krug's history with you and the generations to come.


Your Money is Preserving Baltimore History

If you have ever looked around Baltimore City, you have had to notice all the metal work.  Railings, fences, gates, window guards, fire escapes, tree planters, archways, etc.  The fun fact is, the majority of that was made or at least restored in this building.

G. Krug & Son restored the fence around the Washington Monument at Mt. Vernon and the gates at Greenmount Cemetery.  We have put doors, window guards, or railings on almost every building in the city.

So now we are asking you to help make sure this building stays here so we can keep providing for Baltimore.


We know everyone can't donate, but there's still plenty you can help us do.


Show your support by leaving us a comment, and we promise you'll get a personal response right back.

Tell anyone and everyone about this.  The more people that know, the more notice we gain, and the more money we can use to restore the building.

So bring it up at the water cooler, share our link to your friends on Facebook, Tweet your support and the link to our fundraising page, send out a memo at the office, print out some of our flyers and hand it out in your neighborhood, or do whatever creative thing you can to help spread the word!
